One of the first digital-only games I ever bought on Steam.

Challenging platformer. Way beyond my skill capacity but still fun, elegant, and heart-reaching to play. There's almost something spiritual about it in my opinion.

$10 is steep, though. Wait for a sale; $5 is more the ticket.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993334380', 'num_games_owned': 789, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1429153266}
review:
Shucks! What a darn shame I haven't reviewed this game in all the years I've owned it haha. It's going on 9 years to a decade since I last played it now, and this gem still pops up in my mind since then. Well the time is now! NOW to say, Game ROCKS!

It's like Super Meat Boy, but more complex and challenge mechanics, with a both soothing and KNUCKLE TWISTING gameplay of cleaning crap! It's beautiful! Between the visual aesthetic and the entrancing and boppin' chill-hop soundtrack they got, this title is well worth your time. Like I said, both a relaxing to challenging game, it all depends on how much you get into it really, and the hours I play, I GOT INTO IT, Baby Boy!

5.5/5 Bussin' Janitors! ~  üë¥üèΩüõÉüßπüåÜüßºüíØüçÅüçÇüçÉ

author: {'steamid': '76561197983552150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1706485345}
review:
At first glance, Dustforce is a platformer with a meditative soundtrack to accompany it.

The early levels are rather simple and mainly serve to let you get used to the controls, but you will very quickly run out of levels to play. Other levels are locked and require keys to access. So how do you get them? You get a single key for doing a 'perfect run' of any single level (SS Rank). This is a game that wants and demands your mastery.

This unfortunately makes it an extremely niche game. A casual playthrough will only last about 5ish hours at most.
However if this seems up your alley and you're willing to attempt the grind, there's a lot to enjoy even if you don't reach the summit of what it has to offer.

This is a hyper-specific comparison, but if you're the kind of person that plays fighting games and enjoys spending hours in training mode. This is a game for you for certain.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973535672', 'num_games_owned': 1341, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1705855880}
review: A challenging platformer with almost fluid enough controls to make you feel awesome but good enough ones that you keep trying over and over. If you enjoy the genre, it is worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024962947', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1703920906}
review:
Game feels a bit clumsy to control.  The controls are nowhere near tight enough for me to enjoy the precision I can tell the game wants from me.  That aside, there are several issues here as well.

Game-pad functionality does not work out of the box.  You have to go to the menu and personally key-bind everything yourself the make things work.  There are no resolution options either.  The game defaults to a full screen approach and can't be forced to run in widescreen.

I would give this game a skip; controls are too slippery for what the game demands of you, and the port itself is a bit wonky.

Edit 12/30/2023:  Turns out the game does have a windowed mode.  Take that out of my review; I'll take the L on missing that one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100339768', 'num_games_owned': 505, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1433390919}

author: {'steamid': '76561198869458064', 'num_games_owned': 102, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1703770362}
review:
I'm not good at writing reviews or writing in general but i just HAVE to say something about this game.

Dustforce is the most timeless game I've ever played. I just started playing this game for the first time almost 11 years after it's release and it seriously holds up so well. The mechanics are so deep and unique, all your actions have a real sense of weight and lag to them and it feels so satisfying to play around with. The art style is literal eye candy and the soundtrack is such a joy to listen to, it never gets old. The level design is extremely well done, every failure feels like it's my own fault and not the levels being unfair.

I highly recommend that you give this game a shot if you like Precision Platformers, i'm been having a blast playing this so far and it's a unique experience I've had like no other in this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976385067', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1701552074}
review:
The game I feel doesn't do a fantastic job of mechanic explanations. I have been left wonderful multiple times as to why the character didn't grab a roof in certain cases, and why if you slide off a roof it takes your jump away, you have to jump BEFORE the end of a roof grab to get vertical momentum or drop off before the end of the roof which is a strange choice. To be honest, I thought for double S rank was time and completion, but it was apparently Completion (how much of the level you cleaned) and Combo which made progress a little strange. In spite of this, the game is certainly a gem, the levels are challenging and fun, and the moves after you complete them can feel very thrilling.

This is the perfect game to put off doing chores for.

author: {'steamid': '76561199043475530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 74421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5743, 'playtime_at_review': 45142, 'last_played': 1710906222}
review:
good game. massive time sink. 
After 750hrs, still haven't SS ranked every level.

Community content adds so much to the game. Dustmod, atlas and the dustkid website add so much extra to the game (it's unbelievable). 
Dustmod uploads all your runs to the leaderboards instead of just main category PB's (useful for dustkid leaderboards/achievements), adds community created mappacks and nexuses (i.e. hubs with their own maps, my personal favourite is clunkforce which is just the regular game with reeeeally janky physics), allows the use of various tools and cosmetics, helps with frame rate, has a daily map to play (the dustkid daily), allows installing other modifications and much more.
atlas.dustforce is owned by the devs (i think) and is a level sharing site where players can install, play, rate and upload maps.
dustkid.com stores the leaderboards and replays for every level for many categories (with both a score and time run for each category) and the combined leaderboards for many categories for every/any/all characters for over a dozen levelsets, and also has achievements to collect, and more.

I spent most of my playtime on the 5 low% categories on dustkid. Currently got a top 10 leaderboard rank for any character overall and WR for dustworth overall on all 5 of them for stock levels (although low% dustworth is a really weak WR). Whereas, in the overall ranking for the main category I am only rank #370. You can really find your niche and be awesome at it. 

Small but great community who are very supportive. Shoutout to idyll for being so nice and supportive even though I haven't even joined the discord. I even got to be a part of a 48hr mapjam (available to play on Dustmod or via atlas).

The replay system is amazing and watching other players makes it so much easier to learn how to improve. As a mapmaker it is also really great watching other players beat your maps.

The controls are difficult to get used to but have real depth.

Routing out maps for super niche categories is so so much fun.

Sadly, no in-game microtransactions (To be fair, dustforce came out before they were a big thing), still would have liked some way to support the devs more for the 100's of hours of fun I have had at least.

Even worse, it costs actual money to try with no demo or freemium (money is really hard to come by for anyone who isn't a boomer, you know).

Still, it is definitely worth the cost although I would probably never have bought dustforce if I didn't have benefits money that I needed to burn to avoid losing my benefits (the system really sucks, lol) or became interested in it when randomly looking through tvtropes.

Could easily see people spending 1000's of hours on dustforce (although I am currently suffering from burnout).

Hope this helps other people make their mind on whether to buy this.

Would really recommend. Hidden gem. 9.9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198796185854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 19, 'playtime_at_review': 1743, 'last_played': 1709809419}
review:
I'm nearly at the X-levels, which are supposed to be the toughest in the game. To be honest, I'm somewhat scared to reach this point. This game is extremely challenging, and in my opinion, it's not because of the game's complex level design or difficulty. The biggest challenge isn't the levels themselves, but the controls, which are absolutely terrible. I can navigate through difficult passages only to fail at an easy section, and it's always for the same reason: the controls are clunky, unresponsive & imprecise; and yes, I set the fps to 60 ;).

Many levels don't appear or feel difficult, yet it takes me multiple attempts to achieve an SS ranking because my character either floats off a platform or refuses to run up a wall or along a ceiling, despite pressing the correct keys/buttons. This game constantly frustrates me due to poor controls rather than the actual level difficulty.

When I complete a level with an SS ranking, I don't feel happy, but rather relieved. Playing and failing in games like Celeste or Trials feels like it's my fault for lacking skills or precision, whereas in Dustforce, it's more like the game controls are simply too inadequate.

I'll continue playing because I want to see the X-levels and, obviously, I want to achieve an SS rank, but it's hardly enjoyable, and I somewhat regret starting to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986896634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4426, 'last_played': 1637240616}
review:
An incredible 2D platformer with charming aesthetics and a steep difficulty curve!

This game has a great flow to it, the movement mechanics are super solid, and the level design is top notch as well.

It also features one achievement, one that I'm probably most proud out of all I've earned. Initially I deemed "Double S+" out of the realm of possibility for me, but for some reason I gave it a try a couple years ago and was able to grind it out! It's instilled a sense of confidence that I can overcome any video game hurdle, which is pretty cool and I have this game to thank for that!

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes 2D platformers, especially if you enjoy challenging but rewarding game play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202844119', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1691256144}
review:
VERY good platformer. Most negative reviews say that the physics are floaty, which may be true early on but later the game does not give you enough wiggle room to ""float"". The game also does not demand frame perfect accuracy. I have beat about 1/4 of the hardest levels before the "DIFFICULT" final levels and none of these demand that level of accuracy. Despite only being 1/4 through these levels, I feel i have easily gotten ¬£7 of value.

TLDR: Buy the game

review:
Super challenging platformer. It lacks tutorials so I would recommend watching some videos to see how to reach levels or clear levels as they are technicques that are not shown in the tutorial. There is a github link with lots of explanations on movements and mechanics. If you are up to a challenge, I would recommend it.

The music is really good and when you master the levels, its super satisfying as it looks super smooth. 
For the achievement, you need SS on all levels and the first one that unlocks after you collect all keys, so be prepared for a challenge if you want to get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055712749', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1684372932}
review:
[h2]Dustforce is a stellar and incredibly unique 2D platformer that is bogged down by attempts at great design that end up falling flat to newcomers. I VERY tentatively recommend it and only IF you have difficult platformer experience. I have not and likely will never finish this game.[/h2]

[h3]Background:[/h3]
I played this with keyboard, and have currently SSd all levels in Bronze and Silver.
I have 320 hours in Celeste focusing on doing deathless runs of the individual chapters. I have 80 hours in N++.
Celeste is my favorite game of all time. I heavily enjoy games made in the Source engine, specifically ones which allow for skill-based movement like Bunnyhop, Surf, Rocketjumping, etc. I heavily enjoy N++. I think Super Meat Boy is overrated and not good when stacked up against other 2D platformers we see today.

[h3]Review:[/h3]
I'll keep this short; I doubt I'll ever get to experience a lot of this game.

Primer: Dustforce has a ranking system: F to SS. It also has different tiers of levels, in order of difficulty: Bronze, Iron, Gold, etc.

Dustforce starts out with a couple of tutorials. 1 and 2 are very easy, but 3 is surprisingly difficult to get an SS on. I had to come back way later after SSing all of the Bronze level section to defeat Tutorial 3 once and for all. It is very odd that Tutorial 3 is more difficult than a lot of the Bronze levels.

Bronze and Silver for the most part are a breeze. There's occasional difficulty spikes due to a weird trick you have to learn, but it's not insane. It then starts to get tricky at the Gold levels. Not all Gold levels are similar in difficulty though; some are way more difficult than others. But where the real kicker is is getting to these levels. Dustforce is unique in that it makes you work just to GET to the difficult level. A difficult level is blocked by a trickjump that you have to figure out. Some of these you HAVE to look up (once is mentioned on the one (1) newbie guide for this game on Steam because it's so obtuse and unintuitive). I've had to ask for help in the Dustforce Discord. I've seen some other reviews praise this game for not "holding your hand", but damn I'd love some fucking guidance every once in a while.

Overall, I ended up losing steam and stopping at around some of the Gold levels. There's a lot of depth and skill-based movement here, but the difficulty imbalance and poor guidance stops most players from ever getting there. This is easily one of the greatest platformers ever made, I know it. The problem is just having places to learn how to get good in a way that doesn't require you to just try a difficult level over and over and over again that's far beyond where you're able to comfortably attempt.

So, if you're very experienced with platformers and want to try this one, I highly recommend. Just get ready to have the learning curve whip back around and punch you in the face.

Also:
-Amazing soundtrack.
-Unique menu system combined with a hub world; very cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149636033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2930, 'last_played': 1685916165}
review:
A really good precision platformer!
Heavy physics, challenging levels, and an emphasis on getting the PERFECT run,
and then once you've done that, getting a good time on the leaderboards!

The gameplay is fun, though admittedly hard to get used to at first? INCREDIBLY heavy, you drop like a ROCK and you have to get used to how the dash mechanic works if you want to get any sort of distance out of your jumps. Once you get used to it though, it's SO satisfying, i've spent HOURS trying to master single levels~

gameplay aside, the art is pretty, the music is really good, and there's even a level editor! so you can make your own levels or browse through a wealth of player-made content!

in short the game slaps and you should play it :0

author: {'steamid': '76561198016922330', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1684829740}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980392217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 42979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 282, 'playtime_at_review': 29271, 'last_played': 1710885825}
review:
Extremely fun game, initial learning curve is quite steep, but ultimately very rewarding.
The game often gets me in a zen-like state due to the satisfying movement system paired up with the perfect soundtrack.

Also, the community is still very much alive, there's still plenty of customs maps being released as well as events being organised!

author: {'steamid': '76561198061125151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1687664860}
review: The second most fun repetitive strain injury I've endured

author: {'steamid': '76561197975720697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1683576417}
review:
A fun diversion for couple hours, but the deep moveset was ultimately too much for me. I'm much more of a Mario fan than a Sonic fan, and Dustforce is clearly from the latter's lineage. Momentum-based movement leaves me feeling out of control. No fault of the game's. It has an excellent soundtrack paired with levels that were more forgettable than anything.

Two minor complaints. I wish the level doors marked when they were complete. Navigating the hub world became more of a chore than I'd like.

Check Dustforce out if you like momentum based movement and some really tough levels. If either of those aren't your thing, I doubt this game will change your mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198867830242', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1709243463}
review: Muy buen juego. Gameplay fluido y satisfactorio, y la soundtrack es genial, encaja perfectamente con la atmosfera del juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993699776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1683350621}
review:
I'm utterly terrible at this game, but the moments when it all clicks & somehow I'm able to sweep through a level like I'm at least good at the game is [i]such[/i] a satisfying feeling. The art and music are so pleasant too, and it makes for a hilarious contrast as you grumble over failing a jump or missing some dust as you try to complete or master a level. 

As a bonus: there's a level editor as well and I suspect if you were to do some digging you might find a bunch of community created levels to enjoy as well, if somehow you manage to master all the base game's levels and find yourself yearning for even more. I don't know when, if ever, I'll find myself at that point, but I'm happy that even if I can't find levels other have made, I could make my own to challenge myself, or simply toy with the game's movement without regard for mastery. 

I highly recommend this game, especially if you ever found yourself dashing and dash-jumping constantly in the Mega Man X games and wished there was a game that leaned into that style of movement, because that's almost exactly what Dustforce does, and goes even further to make for a wicked experience.

One of these [strike] days months years decades [/strike] centuries, I'll have the motivation to finally get the achievement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051952385', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1773, 'last_played': 1438228951}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069910692', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1815, 'last_played': 1700701609}
review: This isn't an approachable, instantly satisfying platformer. You have to really love the genre and have the intrinsic motivation to climb the steep learning curve and master the somewhat unique controls. If you're one of the few who can appreciate that, then Dustforce is one of the deepest platformers you'll find. Doesn't hurt that the soundtrack and visuals are incredibly unique and appealing. This game is a big transpiration for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042132497', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1981, 'last_played': 1691954310}
review:
Absolute platforming masterpiece.

Weaving absurdly deep and broad and fun movement together with intuitive, well-flowing and extremely distinct levels together effortlessly. Dustforce has a LOT of hidden mechanical details under the hood, ranging from the meticulous attention to making level restarts as painless and engaging as possible, to the clever use of the overworld. The way characters offer a unique spin on every level, but work completely different for low-skilled players and high-skilled players. The way every mechanic finds a different use in every level, the way enemy encounters interact with your platforming moveset in different ways ( the only game that matches Sly Raccoon 1's execution of combat in a platforming game ).

After thinking it over, there is 2 tiny things I think are worth criticizing :
1. Ceiling corner jump boosts are not sufficiently onboarded. I didn't need a tutorial, but there needed to be a level or a better designed section of the overworld to teach this. It is absolutely neccessary for later levels and anything resembling good times, and as it is, it's too convoluted and figuring it out feels unorganic.
2. I think the difficulty gap between gold levels and silver levels was too big. It helps when you understand that the golden forest levels are easier than the golden lab levels, but I would have liked a little more in between. Also, I don't really think the mechanics shine in the super tight jumps in the Red levels. Stringing together movement in crazy ways and optimizing every corner is awesome, doing the final section of Giga Difficult was just cruel and not fun in any way.

Lastly, I want to talk about one way this game surpasses Celeste, my other favorite 2D platformer : The goal of shorter level times. Celeste has more rigid movement and once you beat the game, you will annihilate it on further replays. Of course I can easily SS earlier Dustforce levels now, but improving your times is so much more engaging than trying to go for golden Strawberries or doing Celeste speedruns. Celeste is a great speedrun game, but its not built for it in the same way Dustforce is based on the movement mechanics.

One tip if anyone should ever read this before going in: If you get stuck in a new category of level, go download some custom levels in the Nexus. "Meark"'s levels often surpass the base game in quality and originality and are mostly pleasant in difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095341414', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1671858208}
review:
Disclaimer: I own this game on GOG with DustMod, which explains why my hours are low on steam. 

This is a criminally underrated gem of a precision platformer. Can easily sink 100's of hours into improving your skill and movement. The soundtrack is so good you may have heard it before playing this game. The art style is easy on the eyes, and the whole package promotes kind of this relaxed grind to improve. Especially coupled with the soundtrack. 

Even with a smaller fanbase, it will always have some longevity. This due to the level editor, which allows for community made levels. Along with the replay system, which is automatic. You finish a level and are scored based on completion and speed. This is automatically saved as a replay, and you can compare against others all in game. Honestly just checking out the a replay better than yours will open you up to a lot of different techniques to learn and master.

I recently stumble on to a Youtube video that said this game still had less than 1000 reviews on steam 10 years after release, so I decided to finally write one out. 

There's something special with this game and I think it should hang with the best indies in the business even to this day. I hope someone makes more like this someday, but until then I'm happy to always have Dustforce.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078288511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2280, 'last_played': 1696740325}
review: Honestly one of the best games I've ever played and criminally underrated, idk how this game isn't more popular. I don't have a lot of hours but this game is hard as balls if you care about scoring well. I guess that's what deters a lot of players, and I will admit it was frustrating to learn but once you're any bit good it's an extremely satisfying experience. I had to stop because I was addicted for the short time I played but I'd love to pick it up again sometime soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039500206', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4463, 'last_played': 1695795428}
review:
Mechanically I think this is the best platformer ever made and it isn't close. The sheer height of the skill ceiling of this game and how easily accessible the knowledge needed to ascend those heights within the game are things other platformers dont come close to providing. Dustmod is a must-install, it improves the game in every capacity, adds even more custom levels, and adds an "advanced tech" training hub that teaches you stuff you'd only be able to learn about in youtube tutorials otherwise. 

Despite the recommendation, and also thinking the game genuinely is one of the best games ever made, I do think the game has a big problem in terms of teaching the player exactly what they are doing wrong. The biggest thing that keeps the average player from enjoying the game from what I've seen is the lack of clear indicators of how many jumps you have remaining in a string. Once you play the game for 10's of hours it becomes clearer, but even after all my time playing and getting the SS+ achievement I still have those "What the fuck why didn't my character have a second jump there?" moments that were and still are my main source of frustration when playing this. You could easily add some "pips" to the ui to clearly indicate how many jumps you have remaining at any given time. This would more clearly communicate to players when exactly they lose their second jump when dashing off of ledges and such.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128239804', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2052, 'last_played': 1666219942}
review:
Dustforce es un juego de plataformas con una dificultad endiablada, tan recomendable para jugadores con experiencia como no recomendable para jugadores casual. En este juego prima tanto la habilidad que se olvidaron de realizar un gui√≥n m√≠nimamente atrayente.
Los gr√°ficos est√°n bastante trabajados aunque √©ste no es el punto fuerte del t√≠tulo. Los detalles en los escenarios y el acertado colorido, lo hacen ameno a la vista.
La banda sonora no est√° mal, acompa√±a, pero no me parece demasiado pegadiza. T√≠pica m√∫sica electr√≥nica bastante trepidante que casa bien con el ritmo de juego.
La jugabilidad no puede decirse que sea mala, pero tampoco me parece excelente, por dos aspectos clave. El primero es que el control de los personajes cuesta de dominar por su gran cantidad de opciones, lo que penaliza mucho hasta que tengas unas cuantas horas de experiencia. El  segundo y m√°s importante, por el comportamiento err√°tico del personaje en ciertas situaciones, as√≠ como cierto desfase al intentar realizar algunos movimientos, que hacen que la precisi√≥n en el control no sea brillante. Esto, en un juego de la dificultad que √©ste atesora, es un problema serio.
La dificultad, como ya he comentado, es muy alta. Nivel top. Solo apta para jugadores con experiencia en este tipo de juegos y con reflejos felinos. Seguramente uno de los juegos m√°s complicados del cat√°logo de Steam. Esto, sumado a que la precisi√≥n en el control no es brillante, hace que adem√°s de complicado sea una y otra vez desesperante.
La durabilidad est√° asegurada. Si consigues superar los 64 niveles de que consta el juego, recibir√°s 16 llaves que, en un lugar secreto del mapa, te permitir√°n abrir otras tantas puertas para acceder al √°rea final (con 8 niveles m√°s). Y si hasta ahora te parec√≠a complicado, amigo, prep√°rate para llorar. Llegar√°s pensando que ya eres un as del control, y te encontrar√°s con mapas casi imposibles que te har√°n morir una y otra vez. De inicio, seguramente no puedas evitar pensar que jam√°s podr√°s superarlos. Sin embargo, si eres tenaz no es una tarea imposible, aunque cr√©eme que sufrir√°s.
Si consigues superar con doble S (un perfect) cada uno de los 64 niveles + el nivel "Giga Difficult" del √°rea final, habr√°s conseguido el √∫nico y meritorio logro del juego.
Por todo ello, por ser un juego casi √∫nico por lo retador pero a la vez desesperante en muchas ocasiones, y por ser variado y con un gran n√∫mero de niveles pero a la vez menos preciso en el control que otros juegos del g√©nero, lo recomiendo a jugadores con pericia pero no lo veo como un imprescindible.
A tener en cuenta tambi√©n, como algo positivo, el editor de mapas, y los niveles custom creados por la comunidad.

NOTA: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198035186086', 'num_games_owned': 553, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1663519529}
review:
It pains me to leave a negative review of this game.  I wish I could select a 'neutral' option instead of negative b/c there is SO much to like about the elements in this game.

- The soundtrack is incredible.  I'm happy I purchased it just to experience & discover it.
- Has a vibrant but minimalist style which I dig. It's a touch too 'cold' and empty, but it still resonated with me.
- The vibe & experience is laid back and not particularly stressful, which I appreciate.

My issues are with the gameplay and level design.  I've played a lot of platformers going back to the NES days and it's one of my favorite genres.  With great platformers, there is always a moment that happens where you lock in with the controls.  Where you feel a 'click' and you and the controller become linked.

There is a flow while playing.  And, unfortunately, this game didn't have that for me.  It never 'clicked'.  I felt like I was constantly battling the controls and mechanics.  The character is too 'sticky' when it comes to walls and ceilings and generally too 'floaty'.

The level/course design left a lot to be desired for me and only one out of the maybe two dozen rooms I cleared ever felt satisfying.

And that for me is a big thing: as a platformer this never felt satisfying when I cleared.  Nor was I relieved.  It never elicited a feeling from me, which is the problem.

This is NOT a bad game.  It is a most likely a very good game.  It has all of the elements to be so.

It was just simply less than the sum of its parts, sadly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007890522', 'num_games_owned': 2715, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1661344731}
review:
[h1]Achievements review
‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ - Very Hard[/h1]

There is only 1 achievement in the game: complete all levels with a double S-rank. At each level, there is some ‚Äúdirt‚Äù and the first grade is given for cleaning it. S-rank is given only if everything is cleaned. The second grade is for ‚Äústyle‚Äù - you need to go through hole level as quickly as possible and not die. You must do it at the same time. This grading cannot be completed in different tries - after replaying the level, both ranks are rewritten, even if you had a previous score better, even if the score was already SS.

It seems as not impossible, BUT

[h1]Game review
‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ - Beautiful, but unplayable[/h1]

No matter how beautiful the game is, it has critical problems with controls and character movement.
- The game has an input delay, from the keyboard and the gamepad.
- Also, the game can't correctly read input, what you want to do for now: run up or just slide down the wall, etc.
- The main movement in the game is ‚ÄúDash-Jump‚Äù, which isn't read correctly by the game. To perform it, you need to press 2 buttons simultaneously, but the pressing window is so small that the game recognizes either one action or another, and only 50% is successful.
- All is not easy and with normal jumps too. The jump in the game is badly controlled and this is really critical

author: {'steamid': '76561198287848773', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1658380423}
review:
I have tried on 4 separate occasions to enjoy and understand this game, but i just cannot get a grip or understand why it is made the way it is.

Dustforce is a platformer which focuses on using multiple buttons to perform moves rather than the complexities of the games movement or physics, i can see what its trying to do, but for me it just does not work at all, it ended up feeling overly clunky, overwhelming and just very very beginner unfriendly, from the times i tried to play, i had 3 major killing issues which ultimately for me, has made me come the conclusion i will never be able to play or truly appreciate this game.

Reason 1: the physics are incredibly stiff, personally i prefer platformers with a lil slack to them, dustforce does not allow for this, i found myself very frequently getting mixed up with buttons and what move would even be remotely ideal for each scenario, and the jumps you have do not carry you far unless you know how to chain it with other moves, it never came naturally to me and so as a result i just felt humiliated for trying to approach the game how classic platformers play out, which is highly discouraging.

Reason 2: the button claustrophobia, far too many moves, far too many buttons to keep track of, and just generally felt absolutely abhorrent on my hands to play, never has a game left my fingers feeling genuinely irritated by just playing a game but this definitely hit that level for me.

Reason 3: confusing mechanics, the ceiling walking, the slopes dashing, the jump refreshing and although i never got to it, the actual jumping off of spikes??? all of it completely goes against what i expected from watching and seeing the game.

Normally i talk about graphics and sound in my reviews, but being entirely honest i don't see the point when the gameplay already puts the game well beyond any chance of redemption in my eyes but for the sake of consistency: graphics are smooth and fine, music is terribly boring and i shut it off almost instantly.

Overall this game is a huge coin toss, you'll either love it or absolutely hate it, and for the games and platformers i've grown to love and appreciate, this one tries to break that meta, but does so in every wrong way imaginable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015183469', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1657835558}
review:
I generally enjoy skill and precision based games as long as they are fun, balanced and easy to follow. This game does none.

You are first dropped into the tutorial where the game teaches you 40 different mechanics in 10 minutes instead of letting the player discover them naturally throughout progression. And don't get me wrong, I liked the gameplay. I think it's pretty neat and innovative, even 10 years later. But then there's the controls, which are AWFUL on a keyboard and you can remap them sure, thanks for that. But even then, after trying different combinations, it's still unplayable imo. Ah, don't worry, I'll just use my controller then. Nope, no controller support. Awesome.

I liked the levels that I've played and I've seen them get way more challenging down the line on YouTube, but the game design and balancing is awful. There's no progression in difficulty. You randomly choose a level from the Nexus and then whether it's gonna be easy or impossible is a roulette. The nexus is just bad user experience.

I can understand this game being older than most indies but people need to chill a bit when they say it's the best platformer ever. This game might be good after you have put many hours into it and died a thousand times but it is not a "good" game per se. It has A LOT of flaws that you can spot very early on.

For me, a 6/10 just doesn't do it. Especially when I have to put more than 20 hours into it. Not now, not ever.
Super Meat Boy understood the assignment much better than this game.

review: The loop of breaking down, practising, and mastering a once insurmountable challenge to produce a perfect run kept me hooked throughout many of the game‚Äôs most demanding courses. The fluid and speedrun-focused gameplay is complemented by a soothing soundtrack and a momentum-centric physics model ‚Äî one that has a learning curve but whose deliberate and punishing nature is perfect for the game‚Äôs core loop. Working all the way up through Giga Difficult was an undertaking that I enjoyed every step of the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561199236622621', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1656653434}
review:
Dustforce is an amazing precision-platformer game similar to Super Meat Boy and Celeste. The game features platforming that lets the player smoothly transition between platforms, and requires that the player learn a level's mechanics within the hub world before allowing them to actually enter that level. It's genius.

That said, this game is chock full of so many frustrating bits that will get to you if you don't have a huge amount of patience. It got to me and frankly, I can't be bothered to consider myself a master of a level after raging at it for over 30 minutes. If you are the kind of player who hates being rated by the game based on completing a long level without checkpoints, then Dustforce is not for you because this game requires you to perfectly clear levels with no checkpoints in order to actually be able to play all levels. This isn't a problem for the easier and shorter levels (no locks / bronze locks), but the harder longer levels (silver locks / gold locks) are difficult enough doing them with checkpoints. I steeled myself many times to try to beat all of the base-game levels at SS, but I just couldn't do it every time. 

Even if you give up like I did, this game is absolutely worth the money and the time to pick up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030876854', 'num_games_owned': 1882, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 4497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3559, 'last_played': 1693570288}
review:
This is the most complex platformer i've played, by far. In a normal platformer you can jump walljump maybe dash. In Dustforce you can jump, dash, light attack, heavy attack, wallrun, walljump, slide, airjump, airdash, dashjump, attack both up and down, ceilingrun, walldash, midair downdash and spike jump. And all that on 4 characters that have different jump heights, airjumps and attacks.

When learning a level you have to learn when to use which jump or dash to get to the finish. There are also enemies that are not just fancy spikes that move. In fact touching them is fine but some have attacks.

You are graded on how much you cleaned each level and how often you failed. Speed really isn't that important here. You can miss a bit of dust but go back for it and if you don't lose your combo you'll still get a perfect.

The fluidity of this game is so fun, both to play and watch. Flying through a stage looks super stylish.

Finally the music. It is amazing, spectacular, chilling, breathtaking, inspiring, relaxing and just plain fun to listen to. The game will never gloat on your death. Dying takes just a second and the music doesn't restart. You are not gonna get mad at this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981867244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1655466617}
review:
--10 YEARS LATER--

Still a great platformer. I never got super far in it but trying to get good times on the levels imbedded them on my brain. A very memorable game, great soundtrack. A quintessential part of the Steam Indy collection. Too bad the devs disappeared from existence, because I'm sure they'd be turning out more classics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2558, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1653917901}
review:
"Dustforce DX" ist ein schneller 2D-Pr√§zisions-Plattformer.

Wir sind eine hochagile Reinigungskraft und m√ºssen Dungeons saubermachen. √úberall liegt Laub rum, das weggefegt werden will. Sogar Tiere, die herumlaufen oder -fliegen, sind komplett mit Laub bedeckt und wir entdecken erst, was sich unter dem Laubkn√§uel befindet, wenn wir mit unseren Besen einsetzen. 

Die Thematik wirkt merkw√ºrdig, ist aber im Endeffekt hervorragend, denn ein solcher Pr√§zisions-Plattformer braucht eigentlich kein Thema. Es geht in dem Genre prim√§r um die Mechanik und um die Herausforderung, das Thema ist immer irgendwie aufgesetzt. Dann auf eine ungew√∂hnliche Thematik zu gehen, die keine tiefere inhaltliche Begr√ºndung hat, aber mit einem deutlichen Augenzwinkern locker und ironisch daherkommt, ist nicht nur folgerichtig, sondern auch erfrischend. Wir k√∂nnen sogar zwischen vier verschiedenen Reinungungskr√§ften w√§hlen.

Das Wichtigste bei dem Genre ist aber die Mechanik. Und die ist richtig gut gelungen. Die Steuerung wirkt zwar zun√§chst etwas umst√§ndlich, hat man es aber einmal gelernt, erm√∂glicht die Mechanik ein sehr fl√ºssiges Spielen. Die Reaktionszeit der Mechanik ist erstaunlich kurz, so da√ü man mit √úbung wirklich sehr pr√§zise agieren kann, Combos aneinanderh√§ngen kann und so einen Level in Bestzeit s√§ubern kann. 

Denn darum geht es in den Leveln: m√∂glichst pr√§zise und schnell zu sein und das nat√ºrlich ohne zu sterben. Es gibt Level, die nur 20 Sekunden dauern, wenn wir sie denn perfekt absolvieren. Das bedarf allerdings viel √úbung und sehr schnell ausgef√ºhrten Tastenkombinationen. 

Mit erspielten Punkten erhalten wir Schl√ºssel, die neue Level freischalten. Sp√§te Level k√∂nnen absurd schwer werden, zum Beispiel fast nur aus Spikes bestehen, so da√ü ein kleiner Timing-Fehler in einer Kombination t√∂dlich sein kann. Aber darum geht es auch in dem Genre. Man scheitert immer wieder und lernt dabei aber auch wie Abschnitte am besten zu meistern sind. Und hat man einen Level mal geschafft und auch alles Laub weggefegt, dann geht es immer noch darum, schneller zu sein als im letzten Versuch und die eigene Zeit zu verbessern. 

Und die Level sind richtig gut gebaut. Stets fordernd, aber mit viel Schwei√ü schaffbar.

Und das macht richtig viel Spa√ü, sogar mir, der kein Crack in dem Genre ist. Das liegt an der hervorragenden Mechanik, aber auch an der treffenden Comic-√Ñsthetik und auch an dem richtig guten Soundtrack. Bei "Dustforce DX" ist alles qualitativ ausgereift und gekonnt. Alles funktioniert so wie es soll und schaut so aus wie es gedacht war.

F√ºr den, der mit dem Genre der Pr√§zisions-Plattformer etwas anfangen kann, Spiele wie "Super Mear Boy" spannend findet oder sich f√ºr das Konzept des Speedruns interessiert, ist "Dustforce DX" ein notwendigen Pflichtkauf. 

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
8/10 Atmosph√§re
-/10 Story
8/10 Grafik
8/10 Sound
9/10 Spielmechanik
7/10 Balancing
8/10 Spielspass 

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
"Wieder versuchen. Wieder scheitern. Besser scheitern" (Samuel Beckett)

[h1][b]8/10 Gesamtwertung

An open platformer that allows you to set your own pace, this unique take on the genre is a lot of fun. The lack of widespread controller support is frustrating as hell, but other than that, the game is solid, and a must-play for diehard platformer fans, particularly any looking for a serious challenge. The level design mode is awesome, as is the fact that you can share your levels with an active community.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041747731', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3228, 'last_played': 1657448196}
review:
If you like difficult platformers, I highly recommend this game! Tight controls, great visuals, relaxing soundtrack, Dustforce has it all. Except for a story, there is no story at all. Just platforming. 
Just be aware that this game is quite difficult, with no way to reduce the difficulty and only a limited amount of easy levels. The game essentially forces you to perfect long sequences (often 1 Minute or longer), which may be frustrating, but is also immensely satisfying once you get it. I usually don't replay platformers much, but Dustforce is the only game where I go back to replay older levels, just because it's so fun to see the sequence executed perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198797612804', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1708065787}
review:
I first played a demo for this game on the PlayStation Vita, where it was an indie title that stood out. Became infatuated quickly and bought it for the PS3. Then, I bought it here -- so my playtime isn't 100% accurate.

Dustforce is a game with amazing visuals and an equally amazing soundtrack. As much as I love it, it genuinely is not for everyone -- while I'm something of a perfectionist myself, the idea of needing to perfect every level to 100% the game may be unappealing to some. But I definitely recommend it nonetheless. Fastfall provides a host of chill songs, and it's a good game to go to if you want to kill time -- or even chill out, should you replay its easier levels.

Even if you're not a perfectionist, it's a speedrunner's paradise. While some regard its movement as clunky, or its controls unintuitive (again, I first played on consoles and I strongly recommend a controller), with proper skill and practice one can blaze through levels at insane speeds -- which, while not rewarding you with anything in-game (the score ranking systems are based on maintaining a combo and collection/defeating enemies), will cement you bragging rights on the local (Friends list) and global leaderboards.

Most importantly, it's an indie game that needs some love. With a bigger scene of runners, Dustforce could have been so much more, and the devs have basically been radio silence for a few years. Buying this game, and maybe a copy for a friend, could be the support they need.

author: {'steamid': '76561198186530370', 'num_games_owned': 2630, 'num_reviews': 570, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1644685151}
review:
The game has a very serene feel with a soothing soundtrack and oddly captivating theme. But under the hood is a monster competitive score chasing game. It's a weird mixture that somehow blends very well. In it's best moments you flow through the levels dusting everything off in one glorious motion. 

But something is wrong with the controls. It started to creep up slowly but became very apparent in the later levels. They are absurdly floaty. At first it seems to fit the flowing nature of the game, but when you are asked to chain together long jump sequences and land on small platforms in the later levels frustration skyrockets. It feels more like you have to memorize the levels rather than improving your general skillset because fine tuned air controls doesn't work very well. 

I really enjoyed the game initially, you can do some really cool things. Sadly the controls ruined the later levels for me.

review:
Dustforce probably has the most fun 2d physics and movement of any platformer.


That being said, I really can't recommend it unless you're willing to challenge yourself and learn the game's intricacies. If you complete the first few levels and you still don't feel like playing it, do yourself a favor and at least listen to the soundtrack. The art design and vibes alone are really amazing.

I'm not gonna lie and say that this game is for everyone, but if you're into these kind of games, you should be playing this right now lmao

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198001890631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1456056382}
review: At least in a Zachtronics game if your solution is inefficient you still feel like you solved something, but I find there's very little satisfaction to get to the end of a level in this and find I am a 10th-percentile broom operator. To put it another way, "beating the level" is relatively easy (usually, things definitely get a bit tricky in the later levels), but the sky is the limit in terms of optimization for time and score. I'm still giving the game a positive review because I think it's a super cool idea and I love the presentation, but it's the kind of game that is hard for me to enjoy casually after watching speedruns. At least playing it yourself provides context for how incredible the leaderboard-topping runs are, but if you're not the kind of person to replay levels trying to shave seconds off your time then you may want to avoid this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354281303', 'num_games_owned': 453, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2949, 'last_played': 1622182477}
review:
[h1]Dustforce - ¬°El arte de limpiar como un Ninja![/h1]
Dustforce toma como premisa un concepto que nadie esperar√≠a en un videojuego y logra con ella una formula y ejecuci√≥n de lo m√°s limpia, resultando en un plataformero f√°cil de jugar a simple viste, pero extremadamente complicado de dominar. Todo envuelto en una banda sonora muy relajante e inspiradora para cada escenario, haciendo que muchas veces contin√∫es hasta lograr el √©xito en cada nivel y gracias a su jugabilidad adictiva cuando logras dominar los controles, entendiendo conceptos como el peso, el momentum, la movilidad y dem√°s cualidades de tu personaje.

Dustforce es un juego de plataformas de car√°cter Indie centrado en la limpieza de m√∫ltiples escenarios de la manera m√°s precisa y en el menor tiempo posible, para lograr un desempe√±o perfecto en el nivel y una buen puntuaci√≥n en las tablas de clasificaci√≥n. No presenta ninguna historia o trasfondo remarcable, m√°s all√° de que algunos personajes no-jugables repartidos en varias localizaciones te brindar√°n algunos di√°logos extra, pero sin terminar de entender tu origen o prop√≥sito en el juego. Simplemente es una propuesta que va directo al grano, buscando entretener por varias horas al jugador gracias a sus mec√°nicas y un apartado t√©cnico minimalista, pero sumamente cuidado en todas y cada una de sus animaciones.

Los gr√°ficos de Dustforce son simplistas y coloridos en muchos momentos, mientras que en otros (y gracias a la combinaci√≥n de todos sus elementos) pueden tomar una est√©tica y lujo de detalle como la comunidad ha sabido plasmar en numerosas ocasiones en los niveles comunitarios, haciendo que en el apartado art√≠stico desprenda en cada momento un estilo con mucha personalidad y profundidad. [b]¬øPor qu√© digo profundidad?[/b] Simple, todo lo anterior es potenciado, gracias a que el juego sigue muchos de los [b]principios de animaci√≥n[/b] para cada una de nuestras acciones (e incluso enemigos), desde el simple salto podemos reconocer algunos principios como: estirar/encoger y anticipaci√≥n; hasta para los ataques y habilidades especiales como: exageraci√≥n, sincronizaci√≥n (timing), entre muchos m√°s que componen los 12 principios. Logrando que en un todo, visualmente sea atractivo desde los conocedores del dibujo, arte y animaci√≥n, hasta para los jugadores que desconocen estos conceptos; pero que indirectamente har√°n que su experiencia se sienta mucho m√°s fluida, acertada y atractiva.
La m√∫sica, como ya mencion√© anteriormente, forma parte esencial del t√≠tulo y es la que termina de complementar a toda la obra; ya que sin esta, no desprender√≠a el mismo carisma con el que conocemos actualmente el juego y si la direcci√≥n de sus melod√≠as hubiesen tomado otro rumbo en otro g√©nero como el rock o incluso un chiptune m√°s movido o fren√©tico, no tendr√≠a la misma identidad que posee y resultando en un todo, bastante contraproducente a la larga. La m√∫sica fue un acierto tan inmenso que muchos de nosotros (incluyendo su servidor), conocimos primero su banda sonora y por asares del destino, la curiosidad nos termin√≥ trayendo a esta infravalorada, pero magnifica joya Indie.

[u]En conclusi√≥n:[/u] Dustoforce es un juego de plataformas que nos entrega otra propuesta que en papel puede sonar una aut√©ntica discrepancia, pero que con la correcta ejecuci√≥n que sus desarrolladores lograron ([url=https://hitboxteam.com/]Hitbox Team[/url]), terminaron haciendo una aut√©ntica joya de los videojuegos Indie. Demostrando en esta ocasi√≥n que no se necesita una gran premisa o una historia profunda, para cautivar el coraz√≥n de otro jugador con cientos de horas de entretenimiento y ensayo y error. Claramente no es un juego para todo el mundo ya que su nivel de dificultad escala muy r√°pidamente, con muchos momentos de frustraci√≥n y pensado para los perfeccionistas, completistas y amantes de los juegos de plataformas. Si disfrutaste mucho de juegos como [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/40800/Super_Meat_Boy]Super Meat Boy[/url] y [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/504230/Celeste]Celeste[/url], te invito a que le des una oportunidad a Dustforce, te aseguro que no te decepcionar√°. ¬°Muchas gracias por leer!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051619521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1633288165}
review:
Let me start by saying that I've only played through the tutorial and the first couple missions afterwards. That said, I found myself less and less interested as the tutorial went on. Some moves aren't explained very well, and take trial and error to even realize that you weren't even doing it right (see advanced moves section of tutorial). I fell into a pit a few dozen times trying to do the dash-jump, only to have to fail the same dash-jumping required by the next steps. 

The controls are awkward at best. Any movement is exaggerated making minor adjustments near impossible "on the fly". I can only imagine the precision necessary for later stages to be pixel perfect. While this may or may not be intentional, it definitely detracts from the experience, from a casual players prospective. The graphics/sound work well for the style of the game, and create a pleasant atmosphere. 

All things considered, unless you're a fan of megaman style precision platformers, I wouldn't put this too highly on any list.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066565950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2910, 'last_played': 1607751709}
review:
At the time that I'm writing this review, Dustforce DX is my favorite 2D platforming game I've ever played. If you enjoy platforming games even just a little bit, you will absolutely enjoy playing Dustforce.

The game is beautiful, aesthetically. The cartoonish graphics are very friendly on the eyes, and the layers and color schemes always make the level geometry crystal clear. The characters are all so likeable and memorable, and they're all so charming to look at. Each of the five worlds has a unique aesthetic. Looking at the screen will immediately tell you whether you're in the forest, the mansion, the city, the laboratory, or the challenge world.

The music of the game is awesome. The soundtrack gets lots of airtime in my own music library even when I'm not gaming. The music can be relaxing, mystical, ethereal, and confrontational at times. It always seems to fit the level you're playing, and it never feels like it's too much. One of the features of the game that I absolutely love is that the music doesn't stop or re-start when you fall in a level. The music simply gets a little quieter while a gentle "failure" sound plays, and then you re-spawn at the last checkpoint. The fact that the music doesn't stop playing through any of this keeps me motivated to keep playing the level, even when I fail. It's a subtle detail that makes a big difference.

There isn't much of a story to the game, but there is a concept that's easy for anyone to get into: You play as a team of janitors with ninja-like acrobatic capabilities who are cleaning up a messy world. In the forest, you clean dead leaves. In the mansion, you clean dust. In the city, you clean rotten food and trash. In the laboratory, you clean slime. The challenge world takes on an arcade-like aesthetic, putting all the world-building in the background to allow you to focus more on the platforming. There are other little details that make me feel like the cleaning is making an impact in the game's world. For example, when you defeat one of the enemies in the forest, you find that it was actually just a small animal (like a squirrel, for example) covered in leaves. You're freeing the squirrels! In the city, these giant trash monsters are actually construction workers covered in trash. It's a cool concept, and getting through a level with 100% completion feels very satisfying for that reason alone.

When it comes to the objective of the game, there are two of them on each level, both of which are very easy to understand: completion and finesse. Completing a level with perfect completion means cleaning up every speck of dust (or leaves, slime, whatever) in the level. Completing a level with perfect finesse means that you never fall, and that you never go on for too long without cleaning something (or, never breaking your "combo"). You receive a separate score (from E-A, with "S" being a perfect score) for each of these two categories. Getting higher scores on each of the levels grants you "keys," which can be used to unlock more levels at your discretion. Each level is graded on a difficulty scale, from bronze to gold, so you know what you're getting yourself into with each one. I love this setup because you can basically complete the levels in any order you like, but the key and lock system prevents you from accidentally entering a level that's too difficult for you right off the bat. You can do things at your own pace. There's no pressure, and you can always try one of the other levels you're working on if you're stuck on one for too long.

There are four different characters you can play as, and they're all unique. The blue "dustman" is an all-around type of character. I think the most unique character is the purple one ("dustkid"), who has the smallest attack and the shortest jump height, but can run the fastest and also has an extra jump. The developers were super thoughtful here, because you can reasonably complete every level in the game regardless of which character you play as. So, you can choose to play through the whole game as one character, or just whichever one you're most comfortable with on a level-by-level basis.

The level design is incredible. Each level is a challenging, acrobatic funhouse that will get you pumped up and challenge you in interesting ways. The first few levels on the forest get you familiar with the controls and allow you to freely enjoy the fast pace of the game. "Ghost Parapets" is a sparse platforming challenge with huge jumps. "The Abyss" is a challenging descent into a monster-filled pit. "Night Temple" is a booby-trapped adventure at the peak of the forest. "Hideout" is an incredibly difficult foray into a ninja-precision obstacle course. Each level is memorable and well-thought out. The levels are all hand-designed with character movement in-mind. There is always a fluid way to move through the level with a perfect score, if you have enough skill for it.

This brings me to my favorite aspect of the game, which is simply the way it feels. The game feels so incredibly fluid and impactful. Every time you jump or land, dust flies up, giving the characters weight and a sense of impact. When you land a big jump, the camera shakes, intensifying this weightiness. The gravity, the jump height, the attacks, and the dashing all feel like they were tweaked in minute detail with absolute love and care. One of my favorite mechanics in the game is that landing a successful attack on an enemy will grant you an extra jump or mid-air dash. In some levels, this can lead to tense moments where you go several seconds without landing on the ground, being kept in the air only by your precise attacks. The mechanics of the game are very easy to learn (there's a great tutorial), but very difficult to master.

The challenge of this game is as difficult as you want it to be. You can simply see how many levels you're able to complete (I would consider myself pretty good at Dustforce, and I haven't yet completed all of them. There are just a few in the challenge world I haven't been strong enough to complete yet). If you get bored of simply completing levels, you can try beating each level with a perfect score (doing so will grant you the game's only achievement, which I would love to have one day). If you're good enough for that, there are more challenges to be met by completing each level with a perfect score *and* doing it very quickly. Each level has a leaderboard, with the lowest times and highest scores at the top of the list. You can try to get as high up on the leaderboard as you want. You can try beating each level with each of the four different characters. Finally, if you get bored with all the in-game content, there's more waiting for you with the level editor, where you can make your own levels or push yourself by completing other player's custom-made levels. The game is very easy to get into, but it seems like there is no end to how much you can challenge yourself with it, if you want to.

I always find myself coming back to this game. It's so fun to play, even when you feel like you've gotten everything you can get out of it. Team Hitbox obviously put so much love and care into every little detail of it, and it shows. This is an absolutely wonderful little game, and I can't recommend it enough for gamers who enjoy platforming games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194060379', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1196, 'last_played': 1656697839}
review:
At first you'll think the controls feel like crap, then you'll realize that they're some of the most precise and enjoyable controls out there. There's plenty to say about the physics and momentum mechanics, but part of the fun is learning those on your own. Also, don't stress about finishing a whole area at once, finish what you can in one area, move on, come back later. I only force myself to complete golden doors early because I enjoy the challenge.

ADVICE: Please, PLEASE change your refresh rate to 60 hz before playing. Inputs get dropped on higher refresh rates. This is probably why some people dislike the controls so much. Use something like 12noon Display Changer to switch refresh rates on the fly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003069685', 'num_games_owned': 818, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3383, 'last_played': 1622680037}
review:
Dustforce is a game about navigating complex environments by using your varied moveset to gain and maintain momentum. There's not another 2D platformer out there with a skill ceiling this high. This is a game for people what want to improve as they play. Levels aren't there to just be beaten, they're there to be beaten, improved upon until S rank, and then improved on for better times. The fun of Dustforce comes from mastering the movement, and learning how to use that movement to make the most of each level. I'm not the type of person that usually enjoys beating times, and chasing leaderboards; this the exception. It's extremely addicting to shave fractions of a second off your time, or trying to work in a new strat you discovered in a previous run. And the game, plus the community have provided a plethora of tools to help you get better.

Dustmod, dustkid.com, and the Dustforce Discord are all amazing community resources. The quality of information/tools on dustkid.com alone blows my mind. 

All-in-all I highly recommend Dustforce. It's a top 10 platformer; maybe top 5. My main reason for writing this review was because I noticed that after nearly ten years Dustforce still hasn't hit overwhelmingly positive on Steam and I thought I'd help it get there.

I've really gushed here, so let me just finish by saying this game will not be for everyone. This isn't a game you can pick up for the first time and immediately start having a ton of fun; or at least most won't. With a high skill ceiling comes a comparatively higher skill floor. There is a pretty steep learning curve, but it's well worth it in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070717675', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 14371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 11, 'playtime_at_review': 1249, 'last_played': 1710537008}
review:
picked up this game a year ago, and hated it. absolutely could not understand the controls. everything to me felt clunky and awkward. uninstalled it, and left it alone in my library. 

fast forward to 3 days ago. thought i'd give it another shot, and everything fucking clicked. I understood the movement system.

THIS. GAME. FEELS. AMAZING.

as of now, i've put in 20 hours in 3 fucking days. i literally just wake up and play this game. I am about 5 levels off of getting the only achievement for this game. this is one of my favourite platformers. 

shoutout to the amazing discord community.
also download dustmod
**EDIT - i am now apart of the 0.4%. fuck giga walls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198361341799', 'num_games_owned': 36, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1620167905}
review: I bought this game because I had heard good things about it, and I really wanted to have fun with it. The problem is, I just didn't. I gave the game an honest try, but I wasn't able to enjoy it. The controls are frustrating and sometimes feel downright clunky, making the simple act of moving around the level a chore. Even as someone who enjoys difficult games, I prefer when the difficulty is in the challenges the player faces, not in something as basic as moving around. This doesn't mean the game is all bad though. It has a smooth artstyle, great music, and even a level editor. However, those elements mean nothing if the core gameplay isn't solid, which it isn't... at least for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999122269', 'num_games_owned': 525, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1618416366}
review:
It well crafted game, with beaufitful visuals, characters, and level design. However, it is hard, really hard. For me even finishing all tutorials was hard. I played on a keyboard, so maybe that is a problem. I don't know if this supports a controller.

The game is a native 64-bit Linux OpenGL app, using haxe / SDL toolkit. It also has 32-bit version for older computers. 64-bit one is a default on my computer. There is no resolution settings, or monitor selection, it just launches in fullscreen on primary display. Read README.linux how to run it on different monitor. Sad it is not in options.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059361840', 'num_games_owned': 1181, 'num_reviews': 1030, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1617833884}
review:
I really enjoyed playing Dustforce.

It is a beautiful platformer with a unique art style, simple controls and a great soundtrack. Nevertheless, it is really challenging.

There are many different locations and levels ‚Äì The best thing being, that you can immediately visit all locations. Some doors will be closed and can only be opened by keys, that you need to collect, but many will already be playable. Each location has its own style and topic. All you need to do is clear the level by cleaning the floor and kicking the shit out of any flying dirt/leaves/slime, etc.

Also, there are 4 characters from which you can choose. They all play the same way and don‚Äôt have specific characteristics, apart from changing colour and broom.

In addition, there is a local multiplayer and some minigames as king of the hill, survival and custom levels. 

The price is fair for becoming the coolest janitor on earth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036549322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3405, 'last_played': 1619542320}
review: A solid game either to play casually or to commit to and master. I won't dare say I've done the latter (though I've acquired an SS on all official maps, including the Difficults), but the game's extremely supportive of mastery and optimisation, as is the community. People have done some amazing stuff on every single level and it's a sight to behold. It's so cheap for its quality and content, please play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994727461', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 299024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 48, 'playtime_at_review': 238585, 'last_played': 1709840897}
review:
- This game looks cool
- This game sounds cool
- This game has a very cool skill ceiling
- This game's community is cool
- This game's replay system + ingame leaderboards are cool

Some things about the game can be a little hard to grasp and the tutorial levels really don't do the mechanics justice, at which point you'll probably be hanging out largely for the music...

However, once you watch a couple of world record replays, and you start to get to grips with the game it's an endlessly rewarding goldmine of skills + mechanics to master. If you're streaming the game or hanging out in the community discord many of us will happily help you on your way to true mastery.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145602506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7224, 'last_played': 1707648998}
review:
im not huge fan of 2d platformers, but this game has unique style (visual, animations), gameplay(you clean dirt, leaves as janitor) and soundtrack is such a masterpiece. It took me a while until I started passing gold levels with perfection, there is a big gap between easy/medium levels and hard ones, not to mention difficulty levels (look for last level Yotta or even harder Infini difficulty). anyway, I would rate it 9/10, i really enjoyed playing this and i'll probably play this in future from time to time.
Also, eventho this game is small old indie game, that has almost no new players, it has one of the best communities i've ever seen so far. fan made dustmod as a ingame plugin with a ton of stuffs, also dustkid as site is amazing for stats in every aspect of the game, everyday there are new custom levels on atlas site.

review:
This is a master-class platformer. This is the hard to master kind of game where the base mechanics are so deep, they don't need to introduce more during the game, just slowly ramp up the difficulty.

But it's nothing else than a platformer. Play through a level and improve your score to progress. If you want more features in you game, you'll be disapointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198404724932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2048, 'last_played': 1703276135}
review:
Controls are very frustrating. The game will register an up or down while pressing left/right or vice versa and then you'll go in the wrong direction which will ruin a good run. Being able to master advanced levels really depends on being able to master glitchy controls like spike jumps and whatnot.

Gameplay is also fairly boring and doesn't leave much room for creativity the way a Super Mario-like platformer would. Ultimately, the game just reduces to a measure of whether you can press a button on the right frame or not. This isn't particularly compelling and gets old very quickly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035100973', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 765, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1612721685}
review:
I love these types of games, but I just don't get this one at all.

I love They Bleed Pixels, Action Henk, Trials, The Kings Bird, Celeste, Super Meat Boy, Electronic Super Joy, Cuphead, etc. (obviously some of these games are much less like dustforce than others)

But something about the controls and mechanics in this just feel incredibly clunky and non intuitive. When you watch it done "correctly" the game looks super smooth and awesome. But when you aren't yet at the point that you are speedrunning like a god, the game just feels bad to play and not very fun compared to the previously mentioned titles.

And this isn't just the perspective of a "casual gamer". I've 100% (or nearly) completed all of those previously mentioned titles. All platinum medals on trials, 106% meatboy, all rainbow medals action henk, etc. 

All of those games offered a fun gameplay experience all the way from beginner to eventual mastery with endgame achievements and speedrunning. This game feels like it is insanely tailored towards towards only being enjoyable for people willing to dedicate 20+ hours to mastering the mechanics. And personally I would just much rather spend 20+ hours playing something that is fun throughout.

This isn't to say the game is completely unenjoyable during the learning process, but I promise you will have a much better time during the learning process of almost any other popular platformer. So unless you are prepared to invest a lot of time, I would spend your money elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094858125', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1629340045}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042546095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1648768243}
review:
The music is good, but the controls feel very clunky and frustrating. Games like Celeste give you a visual indicator when you can dash or jump again, but this game doesn't for some reason.

I tried to go through the advanced tutorial and just constantly died in this one section where you had to dash and double jump. I got it after a while by pure chance. After that, I had to press dash multiple times, which I set to shift. The game promptly crashed after pressing shift five times.

So yeah...not a game for me, but you might enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070726040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3662, 'last_played': 1709331265}

author: {'steamid': '76561198118004744', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1670767272}
review:
The pinnacle of platforming. There's just nothing better in the genre. Never will. Good.

Comparing this game to Celeste for example is like comparing a very good potato (a big un') to a bad potato. There's no comparing.
Celeste is a dull, primitive, rhythm based only game. 
Dustforce is momentum driven, precision something, stylish and frankly just different than a lot of the so-called titans of platforming. 

And who would want a game about climbing a mountain (that's been overdone 1000x and is probably a metaphor anyway) over a zen-like leaf dispatching unit in action?
I leaf that decision to you, my friend.
