author: {'steamid': '76561198340847703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1600604616}
review:
Genre:
-Precision Platformer

Fit for me:
-Perfect fit, my fav genre!

Pros:
-Excellent use of physics.  It's up there w/ N++ for best use of physics in a precision platformer.  Taking advantage of going downhill, jumping at the correct time, and using your dash correctly all play a huge role in your movement and speed.
-Incredibly high skill ceiling.  This is similar to Celeste in that the best players are able to do things that seem impossible.  It feels like they have been given extra upgrades that beginning players don't have access to.  
-Skill based game w/ little to no luck.  You start off w/ everything you need right from the start; there are no upgrades, it's your skill that will improve, not your players stats.
-Very peaceful, calming music, w/ the occasional upbeat tempo that fits the theme and aesthetic really well.
-Leaderboard that is available after every level, allows you to see how you compare to others.  You can also watch replays directly after an attempt, giving players extra help.  This is kind of the assist mode for this game.
-Tons of content if you are looking to complete the one and only achievement, which is get SS rank on everything.  There are a ton of levels, and a lot of them are extremely challenging.  

Cons:
-Very steep learning curve makes it a tough game for beginners.  The tutorial is very limited, which may scare off players early.
-In order to get keys, which allow you to play more level, you need to achieve SS rank on each level, essentially proving that you have mastered the level.  You will probably have to repeat levels many times over, which some players may not like.  If you are looking to beat a level w/ any score and then move on, this option is not available to you in most cases.
-The Hub world can be a bit confusing at first for beginners.  It's not your traditional world map, and you will probably miss quite a few levels until you really make a true effort to explore the whole Hub world.

Thoughts:
-This is another extremely good platformer.  I like aesthetic, the level variety, and consistent challenge.  It feels great when you are able to SS a level that at one point seemed impossible just to finish.  Being able to find a new level in the Hub by performing a tough platforming sequence is really rewarding.  I also like the cute, simple story and the colorful but not too bright aesthetic.  This is just a really well rounded game.

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 3 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  This may be 8 years old, but you wouldn't know it by playing it.  This is a really creative, challenging, physics based game w/ a really detailed and fun aesthetic.  I get N++ vibes while playing this, which is another one of my favorite platformers.  If you haven't had a chance to play this, snag it b/c it's worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080155659', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1646904717}
review:
Excellent minimalist 2D platformer.
Using momentum to pull off sick maneuvers is just so satisfying, but it's a slow burn to fully grasp the controls/physics.
It gets pretty challenging if you want to beat all the levels, let alone SS them, but:
Video/site guides are available, and the Discord is small but alive and very helpful for when you don't know what to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960931103', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1599697279}
review:
[b]Pros[/b]
+60FPS
+Fantastic soundtrack
+Great visual style
+Solid level design
+Controls solid overall
+Powerful level editor
+Lots of community levels
+Tons of replay value

[b]Cons[/b]
+Was too tough for me (just a personal negative, I know many people enjoy these games)

Really great precision platformer that is the epitome of ‚Äúeasy to learn but hard to master.‚Äù Dustforce will demand a lot from you. In order to progress and unlock keys you not only have to keep your combo going but you must eliminate all enemies and clean up as much as you can. Your rank at the end of the level is really how you progress. Higher the rank, more keys unlock to access all the levels. 

The graphic style is very nice. Simple, clean, cute and varies in each area. The soundtrack is a real star. Great tracks that are chill and easy to listen to.

The controls are solid overall. I did feel like it was a little snappy or unpredictable but at the core it‚Äôs responsive. 

I played for a little while and really enjoyed it. I knew going in that I‚Äôll get stuck at some point and be unable or unwilling to be perfect on all the levels to access all the levels.  

One quick shoutout is how fast you can get into the game from your desktop. Click play and in seconds you are hanging out at the Nexus entrance ready to go. I love that. 


[b]Conclusion[/b]
A precision platformers dream. Great gameplay all around. Just be careful and understand the learning curve and difficulty. 

[b]8/10[/b] Very good

author: {'steamid': '76561198321162970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1313, 'last_played': 1592611449}
review:
Dustforce is a divine platformer, a hallmark of its genre. This truly is one of the best 2D platformers out there, as I see it.
	The controls and physics are sublime. They‚Äôre tricky to master, and there‚Äôs plenty of nuance, but the game naturally teaches you those mechanics as you encounter progressively harder challenges. Jumps are interestingly floaty at the start, but you‚Äôll fall like a rock soon after, and you‚Äôll often have to consider how hard you drop in the stages, as you may crash right through a fragile platform. Luckily, your extra jump(s) should aid your descent. Dustforce is also a bit more slippery than most platformers this tough and precise, but once you get a feel for its movement and flow, the game is a joy to control.
I love how the hub world is laid out as its own set of platforming challenges. The hub tasks you with nailing tricky maneuvers to get to levels requiring those very same maneuvers within. Additionally, the more open nature of the hub, as compared to the decidedly linear progression of stages, makes reaching level portals in the hub their own little puzzles for the player to solve. Now, midway through my playthrough, I did find myself wandering a bit aimlessly in the hub, as I tried to find an unopened door matching my current selection of keys. But regardless, this is an excellent example of a hub which complements its core gameplay.
	Stages progressively become incredibly demanding, but oh the rush when you finally pull of that perfect run. This rang true for me throughout the core set of levels. Clearing the stage at all was its own thrill at times, but getting that elusive SS rank proved similarly addictive. Revisiting levels to obtain a better rank also demonstrated the progress in learning nuances and mechanics, as stages that seemed previously difficult to even clear were a breeze. This is a testament to the effectiveness of the game‚Äôs ability to impart its intricacies. Dustforce just has that addictive quality, that drive to try ‚Äúone more time‚Äù, to clear ‚Äújust one more level‚Äù. It should be a testament that I spent over THREE HOURS to get the SS on Hideout, and still love the game as much as I do.
	The stages comprise a beautiful mix of interactions, from bold, sweeping leaps to tight, delicate jumps. However, I did run into an area and level that were close to impossible with my character of choice, Dustkid. I‚Äôm not sure if other levels may be nearly unbeatable with specific characters, but this was a disappointing design quirk, as the game almost forced me to learn a new character I wasn‚Äôt as well versed with. Each character has their own distinct qualities in how they play, so I was frustrated that the game forced me to shift from my favored playstyle. One other critique I‚Äôll offer is that the spike hitboxes seemed a tad too large. I would feel a bit cheated at times when navigating tight, spike-ridden spaces.
	I love the simple but striking art style. There are also plenty of lovely little animation flourishes, such as the scattering of leaves, or the impacts and bounces of the characters. Dust is used as a natural guide for the player‚Äôs path and interactions with the stage. The game could perhaps stand to pop a bit more in its color palette, as the aesthetic is somewhat muted. With more saturated colors, the environments could serve as a nice contrast with the dusty areas of the stage, though perhaps the desaturated look is meant to emphasize the dirty environments you‚Äôre out to clean. Regardless, it‚Äôs a lovely looking game, and I didn‚Äôt find myself losing track of my character even as the camera would zoom out considerably in some stages. The music is rather nice, a selection of low-key tunes that may initially seem out of place for such an intense platformer, but which kept me level-headed even as I repeatedly fell to my death, crashed into spikes, or lost my combo.
	[SPOILERS HERE] Now, upon completing the punishing task of getting those SS ranks on every single core level, you‚Äôre rewarded with‚Ä¶a new suite of even more brutal levels‚Ä¶I‚Äôll be honest, this set of stages became deflating after the ordeal to simply unlock them. The Difficult levels are so ludicrously hard that the notion of getting SS on all of them seems dizziyingly insurmountable. Additionally, some of these levels were once again not so friendly to Dustkid‚Äôs unique jumps. Ironically, while the final stages adopt more uniform color palettes, this makes it harder to distinguish the dust trails on walls, frustrating when these courses are already frenetic. I even lost track of myself on occasion in certain stages. I definitely felt my motivation to keep playing drop upon reaching these levels. I feel they go far beyond a challenge that I‚Äôm able to truly enjoy. [SPOILERS OVER]
But I loved the core set of stages enough to still hold Dustforce in high regard. That core experience was one of the finest I‚Äôve ever played, a platforming bliss both graceful and thrilling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072098538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 123, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1710606607}
review:
This game is fast-paced at the highest level but not as much as some other games. Since you're moving quickly but it's still slower-paced than other platformers like it, the chill aesthetic and soundtrack are great fits. It also means that the flow state in the game is *unreal* and incredibly rewarding. Also, chubbyemu uses this soundtrack in his videos. 
I engage with this game super casually and still enjoy it immensely, despite being an intentionally competitive speedrunning game.

Yes you can use a controller but it feels like it was designed for a keyboard (what year is it?). It barely takes effort to for programmers to map the keys to a standard XBOX one style pad. author: {'steamid': '76561198076346279', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2321, 'last_played': 1648160711}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969637011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3812, 'last_played': 1670671174}
review:
My review
easy the best platformer on steam.
The game feels good to just be in, with nice music and easy to look at visuals and animations, the hand drawn effects are especially cool. The main world of the game is a simple HUB world with doors to each level, after completing the levels you get graded with 2 rankings 100 percent cleanliness (no dust left) and how fast you clean up the dust in, the goal is to get (S) rank for both cleanliness and finesse some levels have keys to collect by getting S S ranking, with harder levels giving you a gold key, to get to the last level you need all the gold keys. there's also leaderboards for how fast a level was completed.
The theming of the game is a little weird and a bit of a mish mash, but it doesn't effect the experience because all the worlds have that consistent desaturated cell shaded style, the style and theme is definitely secondary and very little narrative, Dustforce cleans the dirt that corrupts the creatures and humans of the world seems to be the sole narrative. but like Mario games that really doesn't matter because the mechanics and level design is where all the love and attention went for this game. at first completing levels in a sub optimal way can feel and bit disheartening, like you just cant get the momentum. you soon learn that every level is designed to be done with an optimal path and it feels really good when you get in that flow so it might turn a lot of people of this game that couldn't be bothered with something so difficult.
as the game goes on each later level will introduce subtle mechanics that you learn through playing and not a pop up that tells you what to do, although the new tutorials levels basically tell you all you need to know. the game designer was a huge fan of melee and you can see some of elements that inspired this games character movement. 
highly recommend especially if you are a fan of well thought out platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965964690', 'num_games_owned': 1010, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 6017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1659305862}
review:
Dustforce is a precision platformer that has all the ingredients to give you a fulfilling and challenging experience.

We all know this type of game lives or dies by its controls, and the controls are perfect.  To add onto that, the maneuvers your character can do are unique in this game.  You can double jump, wall jump, or run up walls; these aren't the unique part.  Where this starts to differentiate itself is with the ceiling riding mechanic.  You have the ability to slide across ceilings, which on its own may not seem like much.  This method though opens the door for the game to set up areas so that you run up a wall into a ceiling, sliding across that ceiling, and from there proceed to other incredible maneuvers.  It's a mechanic that is simple on its surface, but with proper level design it is utilized to maximize style and fun.

The soundtrack is pretty much perfect.  The game is challenging, but the soundtrack is so chill and catchy that it eases the frustration from trying a level over and over and over again.  Still on the same level for an hour?  Well the tunes will remain catchy the entire session.

Really Dustforce is the perfect precision platformer.  The genre is full of excellent experiences like Super Meat Boy and Celeste, and this game manages to beat them at their own game.  If you're interested in the genre in even the slightest way, this is a game you must try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025478065', 'num_games_owned': 737, 'num_reviews': 354, 'playtime_forever': 2189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1589892223}
review:
Avec [url=store.steampowered.com/app/230270/N_NPLUSPLUS/]N++[/url] c'est la deuxi√®me fois qu'un jeu de plateforme me d√©√ßoit beaucoup.
Il n'est clairement pas fait pour moi. J'ai tendance √† pr√©f√©rer les jeux simples √† prendre en main mais difficiles √† ma√Ætriser, alors qu'ici c'est l'inverse.

On y incarne un balayeur qui doit nettoyer des d√©bris de plateforme en plateforme. Il y a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/65300/discussions/0/666828126747240379/]beaucoup de subtilit√©s[/url] √† ma√Ætriser, beaucoup trop m√™me.
Le jeu nous encourage grandement √† tout nettoyer et √† ne pas briser le combo si on veut obtenir un bon score et une place au classement.

Le probl√®me est que je n'ai vraiment pas trouv√© √ßa amusant. Alors que dans Super Meat Boy le but est assez simple puisqu'il suffit d'atteindre la fin du niveau en vie, ici il y a trop de complexit√©. Devoir maintenir le combo et syst√©matiquement tout nettoyer est tr√®s p√©nible et ruine le plaisir, mais d'un autre c√¥t√© finir simplement un niveau n'est pas int√©ressant non plus.
Le personnage est tr√®s sp√©cial √† contr√¥ler avec une inertie particuli√®re que je n'ai pas appr√©ci√© et je n'ai pas ressenti les sensations grisantes que j'√©prouve dans d'autres jeux de plateforme nerveux.

Et pourtant, je suis content que Dustforce existe, parce que c'est un jeu de niche qui a son public. J'aime beaucoup aussi le fait qu'on puisse voir le replay d'autres joueurs au classement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014232578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4333, 'last_played': 1415202165}
review:
Dustforce e' un piccolo gioiello. L'ho giocato parecchio tempo fa,ottenendo la perfezione in tutti i livelli (piccolo particolare: quando lo comprai,non avevo un joypad a disposizione....ebbene si,con molta pazienza ottenni il massimo in ogni livello).
Sono anni che cerco un gioco simile,con queste caratteristiche,ma invano.
Dustforce e' consigliato agli amanti delle "perfect run". Inutile parlare delle meccaniche di gioco,ci sono decine di video esplicativi,sappiate solo che inanellare una combo continua dall'inizio alla fine del livello (impresa che non sara' affatto semplice e che richiedera' studio del livello,tempismo,pazienza e nervi saldi) per ottenere la tanto agognata S vi procurera' una soddisfazione incredibile.Il level design e' DIVINO e la colonna sonora,a meta' tra il nostalgico e il malinconico, e' semplicemente favolosa. I controlli sono un altro piatto forte del gioco,semplicemente perfetti,il che e' FONDAMENTALE in un gioco di questo tipo.  Piu' giochi come quest e meno livelli procedurali pls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075061111', 'num_games_owned': 1156, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1586094904}
review:
Game #112										5.4.2020.

[h1] This game can... *ahem*... SWEEP YOU off your feet! GAHAHAHAHA!!! [/h1]

Ever wanted to play a game as a janitor? Honestly, Viscera Cleanup detail 
https://store.steampowered.com/app/246900/Viscera_Cleanup_Detail/
 is a pretty good game so I don‚Äôt think I personally would mind. How about a super agile Janitor that would even make spider-man look jealous?

[h1]Janitors in action [/h1]

Dustforce is a game about super janitors. It‚Äôs a simple platformer where you take control of one of four janitors and you zip around a level while cleaning as much as you can in as little time as possible. Sounds fun, right? Well, yeah, it sound fun.
Anyway, Dustoforce is a pure platformer. While your primary job is to clean as many things as possible, I often forgot about that because it‚Äôs mostly racing to the end of each level while cleaning what you can along the way. 

You start the game off from the main hub-world. Here you can learn the ropes and select what you wish to do, you just have to get to them first; by this I mean, that the hub world itself is more-or-less a level‚Ä¶ where you select levels. You aren‚Äôt bound to follow a linear level progression, instead you choose a level that you want and try to complete it as best as you can. After finishing a level you get graded based on how much you cleaned and how fast you did it. Your score gets converted into key points and once you hit a certain mark, you get a key which unlocks a gated, slightly-harder key. You can play this game solo, but you also have the option to play multiplayer (which I haven‚Äôt tested) and even to create or play custom levels.

[h1] How do you clean... I mean... play the game?[/h1]

So how do you actually play this game? Well, it looks and plays much like Sonic game
https://store.steampowered.com/app/584400/Sonic_Mania/
, honestly. You go through various 2D levels trying to get to the end and clean the surfaces of platforms and walls you pass by. You also have two types of attacks that help you deal with "enemies" which can also give you another jump or a speed boost. While you are supposed to clean as much as you can on each level, all you really want to do is gain some speed and to keep that speed going for as long as possible. You do this by utilizing the level and the platforms. You can run, dash, jump, double jump, slide, slide-boost and even wall-run upside down. There really is nothing stopping these janitors from cleaning. I can never get enough of a Janitor sliding down a hill only to hit a boost at the end and continue running at full speed.

[h1] Nothing freshens up the place like a good mopping/dusting [/h1] 

The graphics, while minimalistic, are really pleasant as is the music. The music is easily my favorite part of this game.

[h1] Cleaning just ins't for me [/h1]

With that said, I cannot recommend this game. It just isn‚Äôt fun to play. Just like I say in all my reviews of this nature, if anything I have written above sounds interesting to you, you are probably going to like this game. I for one, didn‚Äôt find much point to playing this game anymore. While the opening cinematic suggests an epic battle between janitors and some dust-spewing villains, the game doesn‚Äôt really have an actual story. The levels are fun to speed through but they lack that personality and rhythm that games like Super Meat Boy
https://store.steampowered.com/app/40800/Super_Meat_Boy/
 have.

[h1] How do you control this broom? [/h1]

The controls, while very functional, are really counter-intuitive. I suggest you play this game with a controller but even then, keeping the momentum going is going to be a mess (Pun intended). I could never keep the speed momentum for more than a few seconds because I had to change directions so quickly. This is especially noticeable when you are supposed to run upside-down on ceilings.There is also the double jump which only works if you don‚Äôt drop off a cliff. By that I mean, you have to make sure not to run off a platform before initiating a double-jump because otherwise you will only be able to do a normal one. I‚Äôm sure there is a reason for this, but I could never get used to it.

[h1] Not a bad game, just not for me [/h1]

Dustforce is an ok platformer. It‚Äôs pretty to look at and it has great music and if you willing to invest the time and effort into it, it‚Äôs not a bad platformer. It‚Äôs just not very fun, for me at least. If the game had more creative levels and maybe a story with easier controls, I‚Äôd probably be more favorable towards it. As it is, I really can‚Äôt recommend it.

Next game: Eador, Masters of the Broken World
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/232050/

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I‚Äôm trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG [/h3]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041245652', 'num_games_owned': 855, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 9200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4610, 'last_played': 1635711246}
review:
TL:DR, My absolute favorite platformer ever, please buy this game, its fantastic.

Below is my history with the game and how I came to know it as my personal favorite platformer of all time and a contender for being my favorite game ever.

At first, I didn't really like Dustforce. I found a lot of the gameplay to be a little too difficult, even in the early levels of the game. It felt like the game didn't want me to play, like it wanted to keep me out. But me being who I am, was stubborn, and wanted at least the 100% completion on Steam. So I grinded and grinded and grinded. Through all of the levels that technically meant almost nothing to the only achievement in the game. The S+ Achievement, which is given to you on completion of a SS run of Giga Difficult, one of the levels in the game that is so far in, that it keeps anyone who doesn't have the true mentality to push, to improve, to keep playing, from ever reaching it. 

Even before reaching the Difficults, I struggled hard. With levels like Hideout, Night Temple, Observatory, or Core Temple, I would spend hours upon hours trying my absolute hardest to beat what I thought was already an impossible task, an incredibly difficult level, an overwhelmingly hard and oppressive SS rank. For to access the Difficults, you must get a SS rank on every level prior, setting a true bar of entry to them. 

After countless hours of grind to SS all the levels, I finally did do it. I reached the Difficults. What awaited me was 8 of the toughest levels the game could throw at me. Now, you only need to SS Giga for the achievement, and at first that was all I wanted. But as I kept going, I started to want more and more. It took around 3-4 hours of straight strat finding and grind to get SS on Giga. And boy, it was not easy. By the time I had reached Giga, I already had nearly 34 hours in the game. By that point I had already (or so I thought) mastered the mechanics of the game and its characters. What I didnt know, was that I was only scratching the surface as I didn't truly have them down or understood. 

After I finished Giga, I had enough playtime and enough practice to have the balls to try and do all the rest of the Difficults, or so I thought. I was able to SS most of them, Kilo, Giga of course, Tera, Peta, and Exa. But one single level, not only broke me, taught me that I didn't understand the game like I thought I did, and made me drop it entirely, saying I would never ever come back because of how much I hated the game. That level was Mega Difficult.

Mega Difficult is simple really, being technically the second Difficult level of the set, it shouldn't have been as bad as it was, but oh boy. The level centers a lot around ceiling running and midair attacks while dealing with Hit-rise, which is a somewhat complicated idea to newcomers and something I wont explain here. I thought that my experience's with other levels that I would have the capabilities to complete Mega SS, but I was so wrong. Almost every section I was terrible, and could never do perfectly the first time, or even the 50th.

After nearly 7-8 hours of grinding Mega Difficult, I gave up, and I dropped the game, stating that I would never come back because I hated the game. But, as the months went on, I found myself wondering whether or not I should go back to the game. One 100% gave me the courage to dive back in for a second try and really work on the game, that hundo was Celeste. I had gotten all the Golden Berries in Celeste up until the new Chapter 9 released. And after that, I felt like I could finally tackle the difficulty that Dustforce had.

And after coming back, I made it my mission to stay calm, have fun, and just work on truly understanding what I was doing wrong. I watched replays of better players, played some custom levels, worked on my IL times in other levels, and improved my skill with the game. By the time I felt comfortable going back and grinding Mega Difficult again, I had felt like a new man. A better, improved, and more analytical man. In in only an hour or two, I had gotten the SS on Mega Difficult.

After SSing Mega, only two levels remained. Zetta and the notorious Yotta. My end goal became to SS Yotta. And it took nearly 18 hours of simultaneous grind and practice to finally conquer the beast that it was. But while I was grinding Mega, Zetta, and Yotta. I realized something. My struggle with Dustforce was because I was too focused on getting everything done as fast as I could, whether that be 100% or All SSes. Eventually, working on just playing the game to improve and enjoying my time with it made me not only a better player, but appreciate the design of every single part of Dustforce.

I realized that the artwork and the animations moved so fluidly with such grace yet so simplistic with such a charm. I realized that the music was beautiful and kept me calm and motivated all while sounding amazing too. I found true satisfaction within the gameplay that I used to despise. The gameplay is wonderfully crafted, having almost perfect mechanics that make other platformers only wish they could be as good as Dustforce. And of course, a game with difficulty like no other, that truly taught me to persevere and keep going to accomplish my goals.

And thus, Dustforce, a game that I bought with almost no preconceptions and for only $10, became one of the absolute best I have ever played. Setting itself as a standard for any indie game I will ever play, a standard for how good a platformer can ever be, and as a standard, of how I can go from hating a game with every fiber of my being, to knowing it as one of the best there ever was. Thank you Dustforce, for bringing me pure joy, pure excitement, pure sadness, and pure rage. For all the emotions you have brought me, and all the time you took away from me, you have me fall in love with you.
Thank You. I wouldn't have it any other way.

review:
Dustforce is a competitive racing/rhythm horror game that is extremely easy and designed for casuals. On top of this it has an underlying murder mystery centered around who killed the 5th janitor. The game received praise do to its "Cool" visuals but its clunky controls hold it back severely. Kappa
---------------

German Review

Dustforce ist das ideal Spiel zum relaxen. Zumindest bis man etwas ambitionierter wird und die schwereren Levels angehen m√∂chte. Dann wird einiges an Konzentration erfordert. Wenn man die Steuerung aber mal verinnerlicht hat muss man nicht mehr viel nachdenken und der entspannede Soundtrack tr√§gt viel zu einem guten Spielerlebnis bei. Selbst nach √ºber 100h werden die Tracks nicht langweilig.

Vom Gameplay her ist das hier ein Pr√§zissions-Platformer, der viel Wert auf Momentum legt. Wenn man mal in einem Level nicht weiter kommt, kann man sich bequem im Spiel die Replays von anderen Spielern (und auch Freunden) anschauen um zu sehen wie sie das gel√∂st haben.

Wirklich Negatives gibt es bei dem Spiel nicht. Das Spiel ist ziemlich perfekt und wird von der Community dank eingebautem Leveleditor auch regelm√§ssig mit neuen exzellenten Custommaps erweitert.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993400405', 'num_games_owned': 3354, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 1223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1678768297}
review:
My frustration platformer of choice is N++. Compared to Dustforce, I think the physics are way more fun and the hazards are more complex in N++. I definitely find Dustforce's overworld and level unlocking structure hella frustrating, and the fact that the only scores that are worth fucking ANYTHING are perfect scores makes me want to tear my hair out. It's a lot like trying to master a Hedgehog engine Sonic game, where you're mashing out a really tough sequence of moves that are the same every single time. 

At least aesthetically Dustforce excels without relying on minimalism or pixels, and there's something to be said for that. The cool, frosty soundtrack and the fresh imagery of sweeping up dead leaves off apartment rooftops at dusk... honestly, it feels good man. Quiet city vibes. Not a lot of games do it right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060769335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1567570452}
review: Dustforce is a seriously impressive platformer that I wish I knew about sooner. This games mechanics and gameplay is phenomenal. The game has mechanics that are easy to pick and a bit challenging to master keeping things fun while also challenging as you progress. Everything feels smooth and responsive making the overall platforming experience wonderful. The graphics are nice and clean and has a nice relaxing soundtrack to boot. Not to mention the game has community levels in it as well taking the potential content to new heights. If you want a challenging platformer with fun mechanics then give it a try!

review:
it is such a fun and simple speed running game. but looking at the replays from the leaderboards has a tremendous and complex skill, which i adored of their outstanding plays. as of this review, there are some levels that are very insane to achieve an SS rank; and it always put me in a smile when i put hours to accomplish this goal. but beyond SS rank is to climb up the leaderboards, which makes it a greater and a near impossible challenge.

my only critique:
even though there is local multiplayer, i really wish it to be online just to see this game develop and branch out to fighting communities. it's such a waste to see the gamemode and the villian sprites not being used very often.

also, the music bops

update:
it seems there is a mod called "dustmod", which allows you to have multiplayer (pvp and co-op) and even more content than the original has to offer!

stream the game on twitch, you'll meet some amazing people

author: {'steamid': '76561198027873712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 208, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1619053340}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986527965', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 412, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1472769139}
review:
Dustforce looks neat but unless you're interested in speedrunning and perfecting sequences through levels, it doesn't have much else to offer.

The controls are absolutely horrendous and are the main reason why I stopped playing.  I expect a game to do what I tell it and not to completely make up on its own whether it wants to do it or not.  You will spend your time in this game fighting the controls.  They are the most difficult enemy in the game and more difficult than any level I played through.

The hub world is ridiculous.  It forces you to platform around to get to levels.  This means getting to levels can be almost as annoying as actually playing the levels if getting to the level requires advanced techniques to reach since the controls will decide at random whether you did that technique.

If Dustforce had functional controls, it might have been ok.  It's one thing for some unnecessary mechanic not to function properly since you don't need to use it.  If the main controls for a game don't work properly, then it's a poorly made game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042551517', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2257, 'last_played': 1661824241}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025276907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 222960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 265, 'playtime_at_review': 128979, 'last_played': 1710831942}
review:
Dustforce boasts one of the deepest and intricate mechanics than any other 2D platformer. Even 2,000 hours in, I am learning new ways of how the game works and how I can implement that into levels. The controls take some getting used to, but that's because Dustforce is simply different from every other 2D platformer. The momentum and weightiness of your character is something no other game has.

The game is split up into 4 hubworlds, and an extra difficult hubworld. When (or [i]if,[/i] for many players, since the last level alone will likely take 30+ hours to get a perfect score on) you're done with that, you can jump into the thousands of custom levels that users have made with the highly detailed level editor built in-game. You control everything, including the background design, the choice of music, the enemies, and even the camera. Finally, when you're done, you can upload your level, with its own unique leaderboard, where you can watch every player run through your level with the in-game replay system.

Last but not least the I adore the aesthetics of this game. The soundtrack is chill and serene with little interruptions to make it a blast to listen to. And I love the art style. Going through levels quickly gives your character a sense of flow with all its stylish flourishes on attack and dash animations.

Dustforce is a game all about platforming. While there is no actual story, the mechanics, once you seek your teeth into it a little, feel exponentially more gratifying to master. The leaderboards and in-game replays for each individual level and custom level editor serve as content well beyond the first clear of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040865333', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 56713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48709, 'last_played': 1705166740}
review:
This game looks cool....
Memes aside, this game has amazing music created by the talented Lifeformed, the best platforming controls I'v had the pleasure to use, the best game community I've encountered (I'd recommend streaming this game on Twitch for the optimal experience).
If you like platformers, this game is a must-have. If you want a chill entry point to speedrunning a game then this game will do wonders.
In addition to the base game there are hundreds of custom level of very high quality some even higher quality than the ones made by the dev team (the dustforce community can help you find the very good ones if you have problems navigating the dustforce atlas).
Do yourself a favor and do some ninja janitor duties.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040106431', 'num_games_owned': 912, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1561243589}
review:
It tries to be unique in terms of mechanics and veers away slightly from typical platformers. Your aim is to clean dust/leaves/sludge by jumping onto platforms and walls. I found this premise quite tedious and to make matters worse, the game seems to have the worst controls I've experienced in a platformer (played with an xbone controller) for quite some time. Just as an example, you character will just walk across many gaps instead of dropping down off the edge as intended. The movement also has an unnatural momentum to it which just does not work for a game like this that requires precise controls.

The music is quite good. The art style is nothing to write home.

Overall, this game left me frustrated and unimpressed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017093348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1559941404}
review:
I was looking for fun multiplayer games... I found this experience where you have to map every key of the 4 XBox One Controllers and it has the most frustrating tutorial introduction to date (more than 30 years playing games). If fisting was made videogame it will be the tutorial level of this one. 

I'm not going to bother to play the game aside the multiplayer mode. The game designer of this game has shown a total lack of respect for the player. If he has made such a twisted tutorial I don't want to imagine what is inside the main campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011595325', 'num_games_owned': 2468, 'num_reviews': 928, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1558878290}
review:
Dustforce DX foi um jogo muito elogiado no passado, s√≥ tive a oportunidade de jogar recentemente, depois de jogar por algumas horas e completar alguns levels posso dizer que embora n√£o seja um jogo ruim, n√£o merece tanto elogio.
Pra come√ßar os controles no teclado s√£o um grande problema, o dash n√£o funciona como deveria a maioria das vezes, mesmo voc√™ apontando para frente, as vezes ele vai pra tr√°s, o pulo tamb√©m parece n√£o funcionar sempre da mesma maneira. A arte do jogo √© bonita, mas o jogo rapidamente se torna repetitivo, tudo que voc√™ faz √© limpar a sujeira e liberar animais presos em sujeira. Antes de comprar assista alguns gameplays.
----------------------------------
Dustforce DX was a highly praised game in the past, I only had the opportunity to play recently, after playing for a few hours and completing some levels I can say that although it is not a bad game, it does not deserve so much praise.
To start the controls on the keyboard are a big problem, the dash does not work as it should most of the time, even you pointing forward, sometimes it goes backwards, the jump also does not seem to always work in the same way. The art of the game is beautiful, but the game quickly becomes repetitive, all you do is clear the dirt and release animals trapped in dirt. Before buying watch some gameplays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033032358', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 11864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4670, 'last_played': 1662236872}
review:
A masterpiece of game design. If I believed in perfect games, this would be it, but it's a solid 99/100 in my book. Super tight mechanics with an incredibly high skill ceiling, though a bit different to get used to. The sound effects are satisfying, the music and visuals are beautiful (a soundtrack that can calm you during even the most difficult of levels), and the replayability is off the charts. The standard levels alone offer hours and hours of content if you intend to get the highest rank on them all, but then there's custom levels. Thousands of them. There is something for everyone, for all skill levels. 

7 Years after release and it still holds up very well. There is nothing I see that's really wrong with the game, in any aspect. This is my favorite game of all time and I am glad I went back to play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040747221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1448, 'last_played': 1571433571}
review:
It's a little late, but Dustforce is an amazing game for a very specific type of player. It has some of the smoothest gameplay and most satisfying challenges I've seen in a platformer, and once you've learned it, just moving around is fun. If you liked Celeste, it might be worth a try as another mobility based game, but there are some significant differences.

Namely, the game focuses very heavily on getting "perfect runs" of the levels - not dying or missing any of the "dust" you collect along the way. This is great way to add difficulty for this game - individual sections can be relatively easy, but a successful run requires mastery as you chain your dashes and jumps through the level. 

For most levels, this means the skill they test is how competent you are at moving around, or knowing what jump to use at what point, rather than precision. It also encourages you to go faster through the level, making it feel very fluid. 

This has several downsides though. It can be frustrating at times, as you'll be playing through the same part many times as you get better. Personally I still enjoyed this as the movement is fun in itself. Another problem with this is if you attempt to do imperfect runs - this can make the game boring, as there isn't much challenge. You'll spend most of your time just walking over to whatever patch you missed. 

If you don't mind going for perfect runs and like platformers, I would recommend Dustforce.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125357588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1673058258}
review: Dustforce may never get the recognition it deserves, but the world is a better place for its existence. In an industry bloated with violence and destruction and tension sometimes it's nice to have a game that's just...nice. You don't kill, you clean. I've owned Dustforce for years now, and have yet to beat it. Though that's in-part because I don't like the idea of there being no more Dustforce to explore. My only real gripe with it are the hazards/combat, which disrupt the tone I love so much. I just wish there was more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198191106777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7490, 'last_played': 1701108270}
review:
Alright, so i got the perfect score on all levels, except the last one....and i gotta say Dustforce is one of the, if not the best 2D platformer  i have ever played! The controls feels very awkward at first, but as you progress you quickly learn how insanely good they actually are...the game is really fun and rewarding, you can either go for perfect score, or just go through the levels as quickly as possible, a build in leaderboard helps for replay value, as you might wanna improve some of your times!

The Overworld is very well done...basically there is 4 different kinds of levels:
Normal levels - Can be accesed very easily
Bronze Levels - Can be accesed by completing enough levels to earn a bronze key...they are usually not a whole lot harder than the normal levels, but they are harder to access in the overworld
Silver levels - Can be accesed by completing enough Bronze levels to earn a Silver Key...they are usually at pretty tough to reach spots in the overworld, making sure you know what you are doing, before you accidentaly access one, difficulty really gets higher with those!
Gold Levels - Those levels are the hardest in the game, they are very well hidden in the overworld, usually hidden behind other platform courses, you need to be able to overcome first before you can enter them, they are really hard!

After you beated all of the levels with an SS score, you gain access to the "Difficult" levels, which is another set of levels, that is even harder than the Gold levels!

All in all, this is one of my most played and favorite games currently, its really fun and addicting, you can play it for multiple hours, or just a few minutes, whatever you feel like! id highly suggest giving it  a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970903359', 'num_games_owned': 1485, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1554040467}
review: Seemed like a nice game, great anims and bouncy tunes but the difficulty of the 3rd dash triple jumping tutorial along with the unintuitive keyboard controls turned me right off before I started. I'm sure if you're into this thing and are prepared to persevere and build up your skills, then there's a interesting little game here, but there are too many games to experience and life is too short. Meatboy nerds might love it, but I felt like I was playing a speed typing simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006742545', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1561769117}
review: Precision platforming at its finest. Takes forever to git gud, but there's still lots of fun to be had even if you're not gud. Its gameplay is very challenging and addicting at the same time. Its music is perfect for this kind of game. The game never tries to make you feel bad for losing, and you will lose A LOT! The game mechanics have infinite possibilities that only the veterans can figure out. But don't worry, you don't have to know the game like the back of your hand in order to have a good time. The controls are easy to learn and you can remap them if needed. I've tried multiple controllers and a keyboard, and I think the keyboard is the way to go. Using a d-pad gets very uncomfortable after a while. It's the reason I switched from the PS Vita version of Dustforce to the PC version. My left thumb was getting fooked up. I think I've mostly said enough. Dustforce is super fun and addicting. It'll push you to the limit. It'll make you say a month's worth of curse words in just one afternoon. Great game. Try it out. It's worth the asking price. Now I'm going to go install this gem onto my crappy laptop. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198052007123', 'num_games_owned': 6823, 'num_reviews': 1307, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1552688384}
review:
I'm gonna to remember Dustforce because of two things:
- the game is showing us that cleaning can be fun
- there is only one achievement which actually is meaningful, it truly shows that you achieved something
Also, the game is nice, the style is great, music sounds fantastic. Maybe after so many years, while Steam is being filled with tons of indie games, people don't remember it much anymore, but I can for sure say one thing: this is a truly fun indie gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049050571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 917, 'last_played': 1667139895}
review:
This game is amazing in every way.
Unfortunately, the devs are inexcusably lazy idiots and neglected THE ENTIRETY OF CONTROLLER SUPPORT.

- The game may randomly choose to ignore the existence of your controller
- YOU CANNOT BIND THE MENU BUTTON
- The game may choose to randomly bind the menu button to any face button, rendering it unplayable

The technical state of the game as a whole is an absolute mess. Alt tabbing will break and often crash the game. As amazing as the game itself may be, it fails to meet the technical standards of your basic text editor, so I cannot recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018775820', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1550058860}
review:
Visually very nice and pretty detailed. The moves are elaborated too with not too many keys. BUT the controls are way too slow to respond. When I want to do a double jump or walk on the ceiling, it should happen right when I touch the button, not randomly on the animation frame or whatever hidden condition. Also, 4 buttons seem still a bit too many buttons for such kind of game. For instance Super Meat Boy has only 2 buttons (jump and run), and the run button can be keep pressed. That's simple like a rock but very efficient and the techniques are still advanced.
I'm not saying that this game should be an SMB clone, far from that, but such kind of game requires topnotch reactions from the game, nothing less. And that's why it's pretty much unplayable once it gets advanced ( multiple ceiling and wall runs with spikes everywhere).

author: {'steamid': '76561198082191796', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1544669653}

author: {'steamid': '76561198323740994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1567252747}

author: {'steamid': '76561198092050894', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 17077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5801, 'last_played': 1704297221}
review:
Dustforce is the best platformer I've ever played. It has it all: 
- Easy to learn, hard to master difficulty
- Fantastic music 
- Great level / art design

The only thing the game is really missing is story, but I'd argue that it doesn't really need it. In Dustforce, the gameplay speaks for itself. Not to mention, the community surrounding this game is insane. Not only are there some highly talented players, there are also people who took time to create amazing tools for this game that allow for a better gameplay experience. Seriously, check out Dustmod. Dustkid (the site) is also great, expanding upon the ingame leaderboard allowing for visual framedata, easy sharing of runs, and more.

If you're on the fence about this game, I will warn you that it's challenging at times. But it is immensely satisfying to see yourself improve (whether you're taking it hardcore or casual). $10 is not enough for this game (and it's worth the full price and then some), but 100% pick it up when it's on sale if you're not sure if you'll like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044205078', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1546474253}
review:
Uno de los mejores juegos de plataformas en Steam, con la misma vena de juegos como Super Meat Boy. La gran diferencia aqu√≠, adem√°s del estilo art√≠stico singular y el concepto √∫nico, es que el movimiento de los personajes est√° fuertemente basado en la f√≠sica y el manejo del momentum, por lo que el solo hecho de movernos implica dominar una serie de t√©cnicas para impulsarnos a trav√©s de los n√≠veles que requieren de cierta pr√°ctica. En un principio sentiremos los controles un poco tiesos, pesados y descontrolados, pero a medida que aprendamos las mec√°nicas del juego suceder√° todo lo contrario y el movimiento se sentir√° extremadamente fluido, ligero y preciso, lo que demuestra la profundidad del gameplay y lo hace extremadamente satisfactorio.
 Los niveles comienzan siendo bastante simples, pero el juego nos obliga a aprender sus mec√°nicas premi√°ndonos con llaves de cobre, plata y oro cuando obtenemos la calificaci√≥n m√°s alta en cada nivel, permiti√©ndonos acceder a los niveles m√°s dif√≠ciles. Cada vez que pasamos un nivel, nuestro puntaje queda autom√°ticamente grabado, junto con una replay de nuestra partida, en las leaderboards mundiales, d√°ndole al juego un toque competitivo y adictivo. A todo ello se suma un modo multijugador bastante divertido y la capacidad para descargar y jugar niveles creados por la comunidad, que hacen que la rejugabilidad sea pr√°cticamente infinita.
Sin mucho m√°s qu√© decir, recomiendo 100% Dustforce, especialemte a los fan√°ticos de las plataformas, con la √∫nica advertencia de que es un juego mucho m√°s complejo y dif√≠cil, tanto mec√°nicamente como en el dise√±o de sus niveles, que quiz√°s cualquier otro del g√©nero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100486610', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1683230398}
review:
There's a lot to like about Dustforce. It's got an incredible art style, the core gameplay is fun, and the soundtrack is wonderful. Some levels unfold like puzzle boxes as you figure out the optimal route through the stage, and others are mad dashes through a reflex based stage, testing your reaction time and mechanical mastery. However, I have precisely one gripe with this game, and its something that is really saddening because of its omnipresence - the precision and the controls do not line up. 

What I mean by this is that Dustforce, as implied above, is a reflex driven platformer, where precision and control are vital to success. However, the game also asks for some maneuvers like circular d-pad/stick motions when moving around loops - go too fast or don't do a full sweep around the stick, and you lose your momentum and have to try again. It's subtle, a tiny little mistake that's so easy to miss, but makes it exponentially harder, as you find yourself falling off the inside of vertical loops and losing your momentum after a dive.

This could be my insistence on using the D-Pad speaking, as I prefer it over the stick for precision, and it doesn't make the game any less fun or unique - Dustforce is certainly both of those. It simply is marred by a little flaw that likely got missed in QA since it is very much a problem unique to the fresh player. 

Outside of this one flaw, the game is still fantastic and worth the asking price of $10. It's short, it's sweet, it's fun, and it's made with passion. Check this one out. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198075729056', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4033, 'last_played': 1709167274}
review: Dustforce is a game I cannot recommend enough for fans of platformers. Only one condition applies though. You have to be able to enjoy replaying levels in pursuit of perfection. Dustforce may very well be the best speedrunning 2D platformer on the market right now because of the sheer depth of its mechanics. Improving your runs in Dustforce is not only about execution, but also about technique. Time can be saved at every turn and learning how to do that is incredibly rewarding. Dustforce is a game that wants you to succeed but doesn't taunt you with failure. It won't go easy on you and the length and complexity of the levels ensure there's never a fluke of an SS run, but it'll reward with satisfying mechanics and a healthy amount of well designed levels for you to test your skill on.

I sometimes play the game just because I want to relax and be in the zone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052309645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1416079259}
review:
A game that incite precision and fast reactions. As your movement gets more fluid and things starts to feel natural, you'll want more and more. Thats a different thing for platformers, and is very nice.

Dustforce has a lot to offer for the ones who loves challenges.

The artwork is cool and the sounds are great. I've seen no bugs while playing.

I only wish that there was a multi player campaign.

7/10

review:
Spent a quarter of an hour beating a level thats 99% spikes. Then, I spent another two whole hours getting an SS rank.

I'd say that the game shouldn't be played completionism as the main goal. That'll burn people out. Instead, players should get their movement as fluid as possible and see how far they can go. The depth of movement is what makes the game work. Speedruns will show just how high the skill ceiling can go, and watching one won't detract from gameplay.

Rebind the controls ASAP though. I set my controls to WASD, J for light, N for heavy, Space for jump, and K for dash. Controllers work too. Ignore the lack of styling on the menus. It's a bit crude looking, but it gets the job done. The rest of the game--through animation, styling, level design, and music--is worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971071869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1590898848}
review: I love this game.  I love a lot of difficult games.  I'm not very good at this game.  :D  It's still excellent though.  The music is nice, the controls are precise, the visuals are smooth, and the theme is fun.  If you're into technical platforming, this is a good fit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993174803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1530667195}
review: Most frustrating platformer I've played in a long time, maybe ever. The gameplay looks super smooth and fun, but they hide that behind controls that are horrific, and demand stupidly precise inputs. They also don't bother to explain half of the mechanics to you. Don't be fooled into thinking this will be a very chill, fun game. It's very punishing and I'm returning this crap right now, and then going off to do something about this headache it gave me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070978720', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1536197509}
review:
I was cleaning out my Steam inventory on stream when I just happened upon this game. I had no idea what this game was or why I had installed it. So I started playing.

The game itself is such great fun. Controls are tight, though using the analog stick on the controller didn't feel as natrual as a keyboard.  Controls are quite complex and a learning curve exists, but once you learn them, it's not hard to forget the next time you pick up this game. The game runs excellent with miniscule input delay, necessary in a fast game as this. There's a great community game behind this game that is still active, trying to cut seconds, milliseconds, frames from the leaderboard times. I had the pleasure of streaming for a few speedrunners who are constantly backing this game.

A definte recommend for those looking for a fast paced parkour platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062819014', 'num_games_owned': 970, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1529975512}
review: This game is as close to platforming perfection that has ever existed. The movement is responsive, clean and best of all feels terrific. If you enjoy speedrunning you'll get a good kick out of this. For those of you like me who don't care too much about speed, this game will make you care.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058230979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1591405429}
review:
It reminds me of Sonic a little bit. Except you actually get to interact with your surroundings, because you actually get to see obstacles as you speed to them at 90mph, getting hit doesn't take 5 minutes to recover from, and you don't spend like half of the level holding one directional button down.

It's better, I reccomend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044638723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1419543149}
review: Cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982525705', 'num_games_owned': 1804, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 3128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3111, 'last_played': 1655079325}
review:
One of the best platformers I've played, excellent movement and level design. It's hard to figure out how it's all supposed to work, but once it clicks, the levels become magic. This isn't a game about combat, The enemies barely pass your mind as you flow through the levels with beautiful grace and elegance, barely touching corners and sweeping dust just to keep your momentum going. It's all about flow, and each level will is a puzzle and a maze, with multiple paths for you to choose. 
I've never finished it. This is a game that keeps getting harder, beyond most peoples' skills. But there's no story, it's just a series of increasing challenges, and that makes its not unsatisfying to let go of. You can always pick it up again later and give those levels a try without feeling like you need to remember what the hell was going on, like in many other games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041804772', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2836, 'last_played': 1560556504}
review:
Dustforce is basically a giant skillcheck with great gameplay and soundtrack.
Lures you in with simple levels then makes you do crazy things and tighen all your mechanics until you're a cleaning god deranged to do everything perfectly.
Super hard but the soundtrack and feelgood movements keep me calm so I dont end up raging unless my muscle memory screws me. Fun and rewarding.
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198014743542', 'num_games_owned': 774, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1573, 'last_played': 1683330939}
review: I really did not know what to expect going into this game and when i first played it felt that it was kind of dull. Then I decided to go back and ended up getting addicted. By the time I had finished all of the easier levels and finally got to start playing the real game I was completely hooked. With each challenging level I SS'd it just got more and more satisfying, but also much more challenging. This game does not hold back against you and in doing sp it is absolutely the most challenging and satisfying platformer I have ever played. When you get down to just a couple levels left, you can really feel that drive almost forcing you to beat the rest of them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968173607', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 13455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12552, 'last_played': 1675018282}
review:
6 years or something... still playing it again and again with huge gaps between. I am SO CLOSE to this stupid haunting achievment, something I never thought would be possible for me.
When I got all the standart levels at SS (doing the level without an error) and made it into the top 100 times at the hardest of them for a while, I stopped playing and thought to myself "This is a good place to stop, maybe I ll finaly get some peace and quiet into my head now."

Sadly it didn't work. I played and played and practiced for so long, my head just won't shut up about the stupid achievment. Something I didn't care about in other games before. Only one achievment, one that nearly nobody got. One that I never thought would come in reach for someone like me. It's only one last level. And now I can't stop thinking about it again. That's why I am lurking the store page right now.
So I noticed, I didn't even write a review for this game. Just to avoid playing it again I am writing one now. Ultimatly because I am scared of the amount of work and frustration the last stretch holds for me.
I know I can do it god damn it. I NEED to do it before I die or lose the ability to do so. Getting older myself as well, doesn't make it easier.

Needles to say, I hold this game in high regards. I even wrote the developers an old school email once, to tell them how good their game is imo. They even answered and made me happy that way. Looks like they spent a lot of time with their dedicated community as well on reddit and such.

...It is chasing me down for a good amount of time now. If you want to know something about the gameplay, just read some other reviews. Just one thing. The depth of this game is unmatched in it's genre.







I will get it someday...

author: {'steamid': '76561198026383113', 'num_games_owned': 1217, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1355126400}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997453217', 'num_games_owned': 707, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1692266059}
review: Speed-based platforming boiled down to its absolute perfect formula. Wonderful characters and level design, completely lacks a story and doesn't suffer for it at all. Amazing challenge for any fan of jumping-based reflex challenges.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995424564', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1506, 'last_played': 1596063963}
review:
"Dustforce" est typiquement un hardcore platformer dans la veine de "[b]Super Meat Boy[/b]": on y retrouve un gameplay de jeu de plateformes tr√®s √©pur√© mais tr√®s exigeant, des niveaux en 2D avec une g√©om√©trie nette, un h√©ros ultra mobile qui peut rebondir de mur en mur, des morts fr√©quentes compens√©es par des vies infinies et une absence totale de d√©lai entre deux essais, tous les ingr√©dients du hardcore platformer sont l√† - de plus, "Dustforce" est sorti deux ans seulement apr√®s "Super Meat Boy", et donc en plein dans son sillage.

La premi√®re diff√©rence qui saute aux yeux d√®s que l'on commence √† jouer, cependant, c'est l'ambiance: dans "Super Meat Boy", tout est agressif - on y dirige un petit bout de viande √©corch√© qui laisse des tra√Æn√©es de sang sur tout ce qu'il touche, et qui doit se faufiler √† toute vitesse entre des scies circulaires, des lasers, des missiles, etc. dans des d√©cors hostiles, sales et d√©labr√©s, le tout repr√©sent√© dans une esth√©tique trash et accompagn√© d'une musique tonitruante...

[i]A contrario,[/i] "Dustforce" a une ambiance pos√©e et contemplative et une esth√©tique pastel et po√©tique qui rappellent beaucoup certains dessins anim√©s japonais: dans "Dustforce", on joue des balayeurs qui au lieu d'ensanglanter leurs environnements doivent les nettoyer de leurs feuilles mortes, leur poussi√®re ou leurs d√©chets, ces environnements √©tant sobres et paisibles et la musique du jeu √©tant spectaculairement douce et relaxante (pour ne pas dire "planante").

On pourrait donc croire que "Dustforce" est une version "soft" de "Super Meat Boy", mais en fait c'est le contraire: comme les jeux de puzzles les plus retors, les apparences "zen" de "Dustforce" servent en fait √† compenser un gameplay extr√™mement exigeant et un level design √©prouvant. Si "Super Meat Boy" est un chef-d'≈ìuvre, c'est (et on ne le dit pas assez) en bonne partie gr√¢ce √† sa grande accessibilit√©, mais ce n'est pas du tout l'orientation de "Dustforce", qui est √† l'inverse √©litiste de bout en bout.

Si "Dustforce" est √©litiste, c'est pour deux raisons - d'abord, il y a le syst√®me de notation du jeu: au lieu de simplement devoir atteindre la fin du niveau le plus vite possible pour d√©crocher une bonne note, il faut ici nettoyer dans un premier temps toutes les surfaces sales (ce qui est not√© de 'D' √† 'S') et sans prendre de pauses trop longues (il y a un syst√®me de combo qui se casse au bout de quelques secondes, la longueur du combo √©tant l√† encore not√©e de 'D' √† 'S'), le temps sert simplement √† diff√©rencier les joueurs ayant des doubles 'S' dans les classements en ligne. Le parcours d'un niveau est donc bien plus balis√© et moins libre que dans "Super Meat Boy", et demande beaucoup plus de m√©thode et de pr√©cision (et de la t√©nacit√©, certains niveaux √©tant tr√®s voire trop longs pour un jeu du genre).

Et ensuite, "Dustforce" est √©litiste surtout pour sa maniabilit√©. J'ai lu quelqu'un qui bl√¢mait ses contr√¥les en les comparant √† ceux de "[b]Prince of Persia[/b]" (l'original sur Apple II), ce qui est exag√©r√© mais pertinent: "Dustforce" est en effet bourr√© de d√©lais de prise d'√©lan, de latences vari√©es, d'effets de magn√©tisme (on peut courir temporairement aux murs et m√™me aux plafonds et on "colle" en quelque sorte √† eux) peu intuitifs, rigides et tr√®s difficiles √† ma√Ætriser, qui enrichissent le gameplay et feront ainsi la joie d'un certain type de joueurs, mais qui risquent de beaucoup frustrer les autres.

Personnellement, j'ai gagn√© "Super Meat Boy" avec quasiment des 'A+' partout sans probl√®me excessif, j'ai obtenu des doubles 'S' dans un peu plus de la moiti√© de "Dustforce", et je sais malgr√© tout que je suis un b√©otien complet dans "Dustforce" et qu'un bon tiers de ses niveaux resteront toujours hors de ma port√©e: quand je regarde une vid√©o des meilleurs temps du jeu (on peut le faire facilement depuis les tableaux de classement en ligne), j'ai l'impression de regarder un film d'arts martiaux de Hong Kong et je suis incapable de comprendre ce que fait le joueur, alors que les vid√©os de "Super Meat Boy" sont pour moi toujours relativement faciles √† comprendre et m√™me √† reproduire.

"Dustforce" est ainsi objectivement un bon jeu, qui m'a procur√© beaucoup de plaisir et que j'ai trouv√© tr√®s int√©ressant dans ses m√©caniques, mais il est tout √† fait possible qu'il vous exasp√®re selon le type de joueur que vous √™tes. Vous voil√† pr√©venu...

author: {'steamid': '76561197989742076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 2679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2622, 'last_played': 1523171630}
review:
Having completed all the levels in the campaign and all 109 map pack levels I can honestly say Dustforce DX is the #1 most intricate and challenging platformer I've played since my first experience with a video game in 1993. That's through countless games since then. 

Dustforce is  unique to me for the fact it didn't offer any new mechanics throughout the game. Yet, the gameplay never became boring or tedious. That's quite a feat. 

The only complaint I had at times with Dustforce is the feel / responsiveness of the controls. I want to say they were fluid but at the same time they took a little getting used to. The quick, snappy responsiveness felt in Super Meat Boy, for example, is not *as* present in Dustforce.  Also, button presses sometimes did not register. 

Paying the asking price of $9.99 was a super bargin to me for the amount of content provided. The map pack offered some of the best user created content I've experienced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037551307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 10484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7285, 'last_played': 1683016115}
review:
Dustforce is one of the finest platformers I've every played, with fluid movement and a wonderful soundtrack. The platforming focuses on building and maintaining momentum, which cause some players to call the controls unresponsive, but once you learn your character moves, you'll be zipping through the levels like crazy. After the first 1/4, the game gets incredibly hard, but fast resets and friendly presentation prevent it from becoming as frustrating as it otherwise would be.

Highly Recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198271344741', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 13613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6886, 'last_played': 1683827593}
review: Other reviews alreay told everything you need to know, I can only say, Dustforce is one of my very few 10/10 games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029793090', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1689, 'last_played': 1612327158}
review: I love this game. The controls take a while to get use to, but once you finally get a feel for it, controlling your ninja janitor becomes super fun. Movement is fast, precise and fluid, and is built around maintaining momentum and managing your air jump/dash charges. The soundtrack is incredible, and I have listened to the whole soundtrack by itself dozens of times over the years. There's leaderboards on every level that have brought me back again and again to beat my old records. You have to put some time into this game before it opens up, but if you are a fan of the platforming genre, you can't go wrong here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093957105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1608364095}
review:
After taking a job as a sweeper in a cabinet shop, this game now speaks to me on a spiritual level

- I spend most of my workday sweeping up dust
- I often have to go over the same spot over and over in an effort to clean everything up
- At the end of the day, I end up getting frustrated with nearly every aspect, yet i'm still here

If only air vents and saw blades were replaced by peaceful ambient music
8/10, would live vicariously through a 2d platformer again

author: {'steamid': '76561198042243404', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1489978815}
review:
Easy to understand game that gets more and more difficult to execute in the later levels with precision timing and pin-point accuracy to get the best score so you can advance to the next set of levels.  It was fun at first, but I after realizing I just didn't have the time, nor the patience to continue, I was content at watching speedrunners play it.

Great game if you like speed running, difficult games, and precision platforming.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993946302', 'num_games_owned': 2980, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 2723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2723, 'last_played': 1416780698}
review:
Mi sento di consigliare Dustforce? S√¨, ma soltanto a chi ha idea di cosa sta comprando.
Dustforce non √® un gioco per tutti. Va giocato puntando alla perfezione (pulire tutto e in una sola combo nel minor tempo possibile). Questo significa che bisogner√† ripetere i livelli pi√π e pi√π volte nel tentativo di riuscire a perfezionare la propria performance. Tempismo e manualit√† col joypad (fortemente consigliato, quasi obbligatorio) sono fondamentali. Una volta accettato questo: il gioco ha un level design ottimo, alcuni livelli sono veramente ben pensati. La difficolt√† √® piuttosto alta e i livelli finali sono a dir poco estremi.
