author: {'steamid': '76561197992962555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1518695012}
review: I would only recommend someone to buy this game during sales and only to play some basic-easy levels. The controls are clunky and the gameplay feels somewhat weird, because it requires you to be extremely precise, but the clunky controls are an obstacle to such precision. I am not finding relaxing at all playing harder levels, since i get to die a lot because i didn't time everything perfectly. That's not something that would relax someone that wants to play the whole game (including the hard levels). If you want to stay away, though, from such levels and just play casually, imo it will be a shallow experience that gets boring quickly. I would only suggest this game to lads that play a lot of platformers and have the time and patience to master it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984854820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1013, 'last_played': 1673337636}
review:
An underrated and stylish clean-up platformer.

+ Great art style
+ Chill music
+ Challenging and rewarding gameplay
+ Ability to view the replays of the fastest players

- Not enough people know about this game

This can be very difficult so it may not be for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097597034', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1484019632}
review: Otra gran sorpresa, muy barato para lo que ofrece, si te gustan los plataformas adelante.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999919377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 16099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14871, 'last_played': 1708851094}
review:
By far one of the best platformers I've ever played.  I'm really into super smash brothers melee and it reminds me of the "break the targets" levels in a certain way.

The replay system is amazing.  Watching the top players is mind blowing on every stage, even the "easy" ones.

Soundtrack is 10/10

It's also worth noting that almost every negative review is from someone with less than 5 hours in the game.   You cannot really grasp the depth of this game after that little time.  It is a hard game, but it is deep and rewarding.  The controls are perfect.  Those reviews do not do it justice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997370410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2069, 'last_played': 1706510263}
review:
Absolutely fantastic. The music and artwork are beautiful. The game is so much fun and lends itself to replay, whether casual or hardcore.

This is a very difficult platformer, but unlike any I've ever played. I would compare it to Super Meat Boy, in the sense that you will die a lot, and it restarts the level immediately (so you are not punished for failure in any way). This is more difficult; there are moves I cannot pull off, and there are levels I simply don't understand how to beat.

If you're a completionist, this game may drive you insane. I'll be coming back to this game, probably forever.

P.S. The reviews that say the controls are horrible / clunky / slow etc. do not understand the game. It is very easy to misunderstand that this will not feel like most platformers. This is all about momentum and "perfect runs", not simply beating the level. I've heard the controls compared to a fighting game, I think that's a good analogy. Your moves need to be perfect or you won't get the speed and precision necessary to even visit all of the levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044364065', 'num_games_owned': 1587, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 4185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4185, 'last_played': 1436542295}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009853118', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1514900243}
review:
Dustforce is a challenging game to put it lightly. While it is easy to learn it is difficult to master. If you get this game be prepared for how much time you will need to put in to be good at it.

You play a janitor sweeping up and defeating the occasional enemy. The levels themselves are accessed from a nexus, which acts as a level to get to the levels. So, you will need to platform and know how to do certain moves to get to the harder levels. After beating levels, you are graded on your completeness and your Finesse (how smooth your run was), you then receive progress to unlocking keys to get into newer and harder levels. The better you do on the level, the more progress you get to your key. 

That is where Dustforce sets itself apart, I think, from most other platformers. The goal of each level isn‚Äôt to beat it, its to master it and get the S rank in both Completion and Finesse. So, you can‚Äôt just do the level and move on you have to keep doing it and doing it and doing it until you have it perfect. While I did not spend a lot of time with Dustforce, this game is just not for me, I appreciate its difficulty and I had fun when I was able to breeze through levels and not miss a step, but I don‚Äôt have the time to put into it to master the game, and I‚Äôm just not innately good enough at platformers to do it naturally.

If you like difficult platformers and are the kind of person that loves to perfect their run on any given level, then this game is for you. If you are new to the genre and are looking to use this game as your gateway in, I‚Äôm sure there are more good, but less difficult games to get you started.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012584058', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2935, 'last_played': 1704969096}
review:
2D platformer, with an emphasis on perfect execution at breakneck speed. the great level design allows the near-flawless controls and mechanics to shine, in what i think is the pinnacle of the platforming genre. though many levels can be passed easily, the ingenuity of the game shows by trying to beat the levels with a perfect score. but beware! getting a perfect score in the latter levels is quite hard and grindy, which might not be for everyone. 

+++++ controls, mechanics, level design
++ pick up and play
++ user generated levels (you can make them too!)
++ beautiful artstyle is visualy clear calming
-- later stages are quite punishing
-- lots of grinding

get it! very much worth it even without discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114059231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1590179982}
review:
You don't have to wait any longer to fulfill your dreams of becoming a janitor when you can slip, slide, smack, and sweep your way through different gruesome platforms and levels that are filled with angled obstacles. 

Whether you want to be a janitor that sweeps, blows, or wipes, you get your pick. You can choose the levels, replay the levels, and try beat your old time or the times of other players on the highscores while listening to a calming soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065993070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1553451594}
review: This is quite possibly the most underrated platformer ever. It's one of the best platformers I've played, and is very fun and challenging. I'm kind of stuck right now in the game, but I'm okay with that, as there are many levels to play to be able to unlock all the other levels that I don't have unlocked. I really wish more people knew of this game and played it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045402427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1614837304}
review:
If you enjoyed the N+ series you should definitely grab this game, beautifuly slick platforming with a touch of combat here and there, a super chill sound track that you can easily zone out to and spend hours on one level. SS ranking a level doesn't feel like a chore it feels like a welcomed challenge and the sense of acomplishment you get from doing it is amazing and never gets old. While the level selection is techincally "open ended" the learning curve thoughtfully eases you into getting a grip of the controls, to plowing through levels, to getting you first SS rank, and to trying to flawless every level beyond that.

Just over all a great game, really enjoyable and a definite cop for anyone lookihng for a fast paced classic platformer with a modern touch of personality. 

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198198629873', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1508630221}
review: I really like the mechanics of this game and I think it makes for a great platformer. It's a bit too difficult for me, but it was still fun to play through some of the silver and gold doors. I've watched some speedruns of Dustforce and I'm really glad it got a good speedrunning community because it deserves it :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198169967897', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1514320309}
review:
[h1]Rating[/h1]
8/10 (A-tier)
It's a very good platformer. I'm just not the biggest fan of the artstyle and the controls.

[h1]Details[/h1]
[h3]Pros:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Challenging gameplay
[*]Leaderboards and replays
[*]Lots of levels
[*]Community levels
[*]Fun gameplay
[*]Amazing music
[*]Nice art design and animations
[/list]

[h3]Cons:[/h3]
[list]
[*]High difficulty
[*]Overworld is a bit too maze-like making it hard to find certain levels sometimes
[*]I'm not a fan of the controls but that's probably because I've been using keyboard
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198174167502', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 27116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11362, 'last_played': 1688725802}
review:
Bonjour √† toutes et √† tous,

Ce jeu est probablement le meilleur jeu de plateforme existant. M√™me les r√©f√©rences du genre tels VVVVVV, Super Meat Boy ou encore N++ n'ont pas l'incroyable richesse de Dustforce ni sa physique enchanteresse, infiniment plus plaisante que celle de n'importe quel autre jeu du genre.

Le principe du jeu, ou plut√¥t les principes sont simples : vous pouvez au choix viser les meilleurs scores en nettoyant un maximum de salet√©s (feuilles, poussi√®res, d√©tritus, slime en fonction des environnements parcourus), le tout sans mourir et en encha√Ænant rapidement ; ou alors atteindre la fin du niveau le plus rapidement possible. Votre performance se verra attribuer un rang entre D (le moins bon) et S (le meilleur) pour la " compl√©tion " du niveau (si vous avez bien tout nettoy√©) et un second pour la " finesse " (√©value votre capacit√© √† encha√Æner les nettoyages). √Ä noter que la premi√®re approche est r√©compens√©e d'un rang SS si effectuez parfaitement un niveau tandis que la seconde approche, n√©gligeant le nettoyage, sera assez peu r√©compens√©e ; mais rien ne vous emp√™che de viser les meilleurs temps tout en faisant un niveau en SS, au contraire !

Vous disposez de toute une palette d'actions pour vous mouvoir en plus des d√©placements classiques au stick/ZQSD, selon que vous jouiez au clavier ou √† la manette car les deux sont possibles. 
Tout d'abord le plus important : le dash. Contrairement √† certains jeux comme Super Meat Boy qui permettent de courir en permanence avec la pression d'un bouton, ici le dash n'est qu'un petit boost en avant qui vous octroit la vitesse maximum de marche instantan√©ment. Il permet √©galement de conserver les vitesses tr√®s √©lev√©es, que vous pouvez atteindre en chutant ou en glissant le long des pentes, si vous r√©ussissez √† avoir le bon rythme pour dasher en boucle.
√âvidemment vous pouvez sauter, et dasher, dans le jeu √† n'importe quel moment depuis le sol ou un mur ; dans les airs seulement s'il vous reste une " air charge ". C'est un nom particulier qui a son utilit√© puisque une fois en l'air on peut utiliser un saut ou un dash (ou exclusif si l'on omet la technique avanc√©e du dashjump qui consiste √† sauter et dasher durant la m√™me frame), c'est pour cela qu'on parle d'air charge afin d'indiquer la possiblit√© de faire l'une ou l'autre de ces actions.
Vous disposez √©galement d'attaques l√©g√®res qui vous permettent de nettoyer les salet√©s ou de vaincre les ennemis, et aussi d'attaques lourdes, √©quivalentes √† trois attaques l√©g√®res en terme de d√©g√¢ts, avec plus de port√©e mais plus lentes que ces derni√®res. An√©antir un ennemi avec une attaque lourde fera appara√Ætre des projections si un mur se trouve suffisamment proche dans la direction de l'attaque, ce qui peut vous p√©naliser car prendra plus de temps √† renettoyer ou au contraire vous avantager pour remplir votre " jauge de super ". En effet, en nettoyant votre jauge augmente petit √† petit et une fois pleine, une pression simultan√©e des touches assign√©es aux attaque l√©g√®res et lourdes vous fera nettoyer (√† condition que la surface √† nettoyer de soit pas derri√®re un mur par rapport √† votre personnage) et annihiler tous les ennemis en une fraction de seconde dans une rayon donn√© autour de vous. D√©truire un ennemi avec une attaque ou utiliser la super vous fera regagner votre air charge ce qui permet de longues phases impressionantes sans toucher le sol dans les derniers niveaux.
Input la direction du haut permet d'√©voluer le long des murs ou des plafonds tandis que la direction du bas permet de glisser le long des pentes ou, combin√©e avec un dash, de " fastfall " (faire une chute acc√©ler√©e pour retomber plus rapidement au sol).

Quatre personnages diff√©rents peuvent √™tre incarn√©s : Dustman, Dustgirl, Dustkid et Dustworth ; chacun ayant des caract√©ristiques diff√©rentes pour la hauteur des sauts, la longueur de dash, le vitesse de chute, la port√©e ou encore la vitesse des attaques. Vous pourrez donc changer de personnage avant chaque d√©but de niveau en fonction des sp√©cificit√©s de celui-ci ou de vos pr√©f√©rences personnelles.

Le jeu ne dispose pas d'√©cran de s√©lection des niveaux sous forme de menu puisque toutes les entr√©es de niveau sont accessibles dans un monde appel√© Nexus. Le Nexus est divis√© en 4 environnements : forestier, ch√¢teau/manoir, urbain et laboratoire. Chaque d√©placement entre les niveaux est une opportunit√© de perfectionner sa technique. Ceux-ci sont d√©compos√©s en 4 cat√©gories de difficult√© croissante : les niveau accessibles de base, les niveaux bronze, les niveaux argent et les niveaux or. 
Chaque entr√©e de niveau n√©cessite une clef correspondante ; clefs d√©bloquables en finissant des niveaux de difficult√© inf√©rieur. Par exemple une clef argent s'obtient en finissant plusieurs niveaux bronze. Plus vos rangs sont bons plus vous d√©bloquerez de nouvelles clefs rapidement. Les niveaux or quant √† eux vous donnent des clefs rouges...

Le jeu poss√®de une courbe de difficult√© adaptative puisque vous ne pouvez d√©bloquer les niveaux de difficult√© sup√©rieur qu'en r√©ussissant les niveaux plus simples. Il est th√©oriquement possible d'atteindre l'entr√©e d'un niveau or d√®s le d√©but du jeu (quoiqu'extr√™mement difficile pour quelqu'un n'ayant pas encore d√©bloqu√© des niveaux argent) sans pouvoir le faire puisque vous n'aurez pas la clef n√©cessaire pour l'ouvrir. 
Au tout d√©but les m√©caniques sont relativement difficiles √† assimiler, bien que les tutoriels soient exemplaires, il faut donc se familiariser un peu avec le jeu, l'affaire d'une heure ou deux en faisant le tour du Nexus et des entr√©es de niveau accessibles pour la technique d'un joueur d√©butant. Une fois chose faite on se retrouve face √† une courbe de progression plut√¥t logarithmique : les niveaux jusqu'au bronze de font assez ais√©ment puis les argents commencent √† demander plus d'investissement et enfin les niveaux or vous prendrons autant de temps que tous les autres r√©unis.
Pour ma part en une petite trentaine d'heure de jeu j'ai quasiment fini tous les niveaux en SS, sauf les derniers niveaux or bien ardus, et avec un classement plut√¥t correct, entre 300 et 2000 en fonction des niveaux. Cependant la diff√©rence avec les joueurs qui font syst√©matiquement top 100 est abyssale et vu la profondeur du jeu √ßa n'est pas √©tonnant de voir plusieurs joueurs atteindre le millier d'heure pour obtenir ce niveau de ma√Ætrise.

Si le contenu propos√© de base par le jeu ne vous suffit pas, de tr√®s nombreuses maps custom sont jouables. Un mode multijoueur est √©galement disponible.

Que dire de plus, si ce n'est que la direction artistique du jeu est fantastique, agr√©able √† l'oeil tout en restant tr√®s lisible. L'OST n'est pas en reste puisque Lifeformed a livr√© une musique magnifique et apaisante qui se marie √† merveille avec l'aspect graphique du jeu. Le sound design en lui-m√™me est, pour changer, d'excellente facture, et rythme les niveaux telle une cerise sur le g√¢teau visuel et sonore qui nous est servi.

La communaut√© speedrun est √©videmment tr√®s active sur le jeu, plusieurs ann√©es apr√®s sa sortie les records sont encore battus r√©guli√®rement car les joueurs sont loins d'avoir ma√Ætris√© √† la perfection le jeu, beaucoup trop riche et complexe pour que cela ne soit que l'affaire de quelques ann√©es ; et les speedrun, quelle que soit la cat√©gorie, sont toujours incroyablement fascinants √† regarder mais aussi tr√®s inspirants pour les joueurs. 
La metagame du jeu s'est fa√ßonn√©e au fur et √† mesure et c'est ainsi qu'on se retrouve avec un personnage sp√©cifique dominant compl√®tement le classement d'un niveau puisque tout a pu √™tre optimis√© du mieux possible avec lui ; et √† l'inverse d'autres hauts de classement sont bariol√©s avec la pr√©sence de tous les personnages, montrant que la cr√©ativit√© et les styles de jeu de chacun peuvent s'exprimer sans que l'on s'en trouve limit√©.

Dustforce DX est un chef d'oeuvre : sa physique, son level design et ses m√©caniques en font le pinacle du plateformer.

review: 70+ hours in and I still haven't beaten the base game yet (Still yet to beat half of the difficults). The game is hard, yet it's one of the easiest things to chill out  to. It's not tense at all. It's pretty much the most complex, pure platformers out there but packaged in an amazingly relaxing package. Even though the game requires a lot of patience and muscle memory, I find the game to be a fantastic stress reliever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995669781', 'num_games_owned': 2395, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1505591798}
review:
How to have fun with Dustforce if you like your games difficult, but not frustratingly difficult (or just don't have the patience and/or time to learn how to deal with the precise timing the game's momentum mechanics require):

> SS all the No Key levels.
> SS all the Bronze Key levels.
> Beat all the Silver Key levels (SS them if you feel like it, I guess).
> Play Imagination and Wonderland from the Community Maps on your way out to reward yourself.

Congratulations! You've beaten the game the sillythings way!






Nah, but for real. You're probably not going to be able to beat the game unless you're very good at this kind of stuff or willing to invest a lot of time. This is usually something that would keep me from recommending a game (see my review of DeadCore) but the time I did decide to spend with Dustforce was exceedingly pleasant, the music is fantastic, and the level tiers allow you a sense of accomplishment and closure even if you quit early. Yes, I do wish the game conveyed even more clearly how to execute the more difficult moves (and didn't just expect me to patiently learn through trial and error and watching other players), but ultimately I do feel it's less my fault than the games' for me not being able to carry on. Thus, a recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149350338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1669058050}
review:
An amazing precision platformer, with really awesome levels where you really have to think your way through to get the best ranking. 

I'd recommend playing with a gamepad, however. The keyboard controls are a tiny bit weird and I got confused a lot of the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053392122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1529, 'last_played': 1505631719}
review:
I'm appalled I didn't hear about this game until recently, this game is absolutely underappreciated and deserves more attention in my opinion. It's by far the best 2D platformer I've played since Super Meat Boy, it's challenging but the replay system let's you learn from other players, you will stare in awe as the top scorer clears a level faster than Sonic ejaculates, and you will want to imitate him, you will try again and again, getting a little bit better each time. Eventually you will be able to finish the game with a perfect score and a decent time, even though your place in the scoreboard is still relatively bad, you earned that goddamn place, dammit! And you are proud!
The game also has a fantastic soundtrack and characters with very charming designs and animations, always wanted to be an anime ninja janitor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134542868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1507323102}
review:
This game is great in my mind, but only because it's part of a certain niche of games that I like to explore. To SS all the levels, the player has to thoroughly understand how the levels work, and execute them perfectly. For some,  it is annoying and stress-inducing. For others, it's enjoyable and satisfying.  If you're looking for a game that has a lot of variety in enemies and mechanics, this is not it. It uses masterful design to make levels engaging, rather than variety.
      If you've played or enjoyed Speedrunners, it's aesthetically similar and often feels the same way with its momentum-based movement. The music is similar to something like N++ - it's zoned out, and it may help you focus.
      All in all, it's exactly what it sounds like. Play it if you're interested. If you're not interested, don't play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993522971', 'num_games_owned': 904, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1382300258}
review: I love how Dustforce has so much density in its challenge distribution that you can push yourself as far as you'd like to go, play a boatload of stuff at that level, and retire satisfied. The soundtrack is also, to me, the single data point at which it became apparent that indie games were going to define game music going forward.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034838036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1572, 'last_played': 1670802109}
review:

Gameplay and soundtrack: 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198061410322', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1482292256}
review:
A well presented game that rewards mastery of the controls.

Dustforce is a speedrunning game, in essence. Major focus on completing the levels as fast as possible, and the mechanics are inclined to reflect that. Movement is fluid and quick; after a little while of learning the controls you'll find yourself breezing through the beautiful enviroments and dispatching areas of dust. And that is where this game is unique, in that you have to not only go fast but to clean the room of dust/leaves/slime as best you can. Going fast by itself will not get you the best grading (although usually the dust is used to indicate to you the best possible path you can take, think of it like coins but more specific.)

This game features smoothly animated hand-drawn graphics and shows an incredible amount of attention to detail, without obtrustructing the gameplay. Leaves fall gracefully when you dust them away, old attics have a neglected ambience to them, it all fits together wonderfully.

The soundtrack is worth mentioning on its own merit. Many peaceful, relaxing or energetic tunes for this surprisingly high-octane game make playing it a pleasure. I can't properly put it into words but I think this game is worth buying for the music alone.

The game also features multiplayer and a plethora of custom levels with a wide community. I haven't really tried it out myself though.

In conclusion, a lovely game that I honestly should spend more time playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045937335', 'num_games_owned': 716, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1484314800}

author: {'steamid': '76561197965372159', 'num_games_owned': 870, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1502158365}
review:
Here is the thing. This game is not for everyone. It doesn't reward you with stupid stuff like other games. The reward is satisfaction of getting a good ranking. 

The music is some of the best in any game ever. The controls are great albeit hard to get used to. This is a beautiful game and you will have a beautiful time playing it if you give it a chance and let it grow on you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057471073', 'num_games_owned': 700, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1500766339}
review:
I simply didn't find this game fun. 

On the casual level, all you do is complete levels that aren't very engaging. For the "pro" community, the challenge consist of being able to control your character and memorizing the most efficient way to finish a level. These two facts combined with a really weird "homeworld" for selecting levels, just didn't make the gun fun. I was spending my time trying to find levels, getting mad at complicated levels when trying to get a decent score, and overall just bored if I was simply trying to finish a level.

I could see some people that are really into platformers enjoying this game, but it doesn't do it for me personally.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056264361', 'num_games_owned': 606, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1705634035}
review: This is a truly captivating and ultra-difficult momentum based platformer, in addition the soundtrack and artstyle are beautiful. Somehow I can sit and play the same level over and over in the attempt for an S rank without frustration, but rather, a sense of peaceful relaxation that morphs into adrenaline fueled exhilaration as I near the end of a particularily difficult course with the S rank intact. Few other games offer difficult challenges that are as satisfying to overcome, and as relaxing to work toward despite their difficulty. There really is something here for everyone, whether you are a more casual gamer or lean more toward the competitive side, the game is fulfilling to simply experience regardless of your course ranks but if you decide to chase the coveted S ranks you will discover that this game puts Super Meat Boy to shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198393603555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1617584745}
review:
Es una maravilla jugable,cuando juegas bien sientes una sensacion que jamas habia sentido antes que es el fluir por los niveles como una bolsa de basura en venezuela,el juego es facil de tomar y dificil de dominar porque este juego tiene lo que muchos juegos de mario tiene que es ademas de las habilidades normales como el dash y salto tienes tecnicas que puedes utilizar como:un dash luego de un salto para ganar velocidad o un dash antes del salto para llegar mas lejos con el salto utilizar los ataques para ganar mas tiempo en el aire.

para mi la duracion de un juego no importa si el juego es divertido pero para la gente que si le importa la duracion depende de tu habilidad porque no todo el mundo se puede pasar el juego al 100% o siquiera pasarse los niveles con cualquier calificacion.

en resumen esta bien si quieres un juego que te reta en cada fase y te obliga a dominar sus mecanicas pues adelante

author: {'steamid': '76561198076496018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6105, 'last_played': 1498973283}
review:
Great platformer. The level design is the best I've seen from an indie game - each level has themes that are developed without ever being too repetitive, and yet it all fits into the game's core gameplay without any need for one-off mechanical gimmicks. Restarting is fast and stages never have any sections that are too easy or make you wait too much. 
The levels are somewhat long and yet more lenient compared to other games in the "hard platforming" subgenre, which results in lots of proper, well-paced tension while playing, whether in trying to recover form a failure or from finishing the last section of a level. Far too many of said platformers get stuck in lolhard-land, where fun comes down to retrying pixel-perfect jumps in a 10-second level hundreds of times.
My only serious criticism is perhaps about visuals getting in the way of gameplay. For one, the fluid animations can get in the way of understanding the actual coordinates of your character, which is especially frustrating when dealing with dust blocks. Also, there is no way to immediately see if you have jump charge or not. That is something I'd say would be a much better use of the glowy aura than the special attack, which can be seen at the bottom of the screen or outright memorised for certain sections of a level.
A minor complaint is with how poorly the game explains some of its controls. That's somehat aggravating given how you're required to know unintuitive techniques you're never told about to access certain levels. For instance, the fact that you can slide off a U-shaped ceiling and back into a wall without jumping if you have enough speed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049054008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1511427981}
review:
Dustforce is a challenging precision platformer with a great aesthetic.
I love the concept of the game, however some things that frustrate me are:

-lack of contrast between background and platform colors 
-controls that don't necessarily give you the precision you need
-minor gripes, such as poor progression, lack of achievements, and inability to switch between characters in a  convenient manner

Despite the flaws, I still recommend it to anyone who likes difficult platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038834385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3192, 'last_played': 1601882429}
review:
This is one of my favorite games. The controls and movement feel so good. In the beginning when you haven't learned the mechanics it feels sort of clunky, but as you improve the game develops a really nice flow. This makes mastering levels really satifying. In most platformers I just want to make it through each level and move on. This was the first game where I found myself revisiting levels just because I wanted to do a better job.

Another great part of this game is the way they handle the learning curve. There are plenty of levels that a beginner can approach, and each of these helps teach you the tricks and strategies you'll need to tackle the more difficult parts. They never spoon-feed you any technique, but instead let you develop it yourself as you work your way through. It almost feels like your character is leveling up and learning new abilities throughout the game, but it's actually just you getting better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085155433', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 4729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3305, 'last_played': 1697301767}
review:
You know smash bros melee? Take the absurdly complicated but deep movement from that game and make it into a platformer, where your goal is to sweep up garbage. Like melee, it feels awkward at first. It feels like the game is eating your inputs all of the time, since there's no buffering or any kind of hand-holding if you mistime button presses. But the movement is immensly satisfying to master. Finally getting that SS on a stage, or improving your time by a fraction of a second after dozens of retries feels amazing.

I have to mention the soundtrack as well. Lifeformed is a goddamn genius. It's entrancing, calming, nostalgic and a bunch of other adjectives to sell you on the idea of listening to it. I bought the game in 2017 and I still put the soundtrack on to relax.

If what I've described sounds fun, you're going to love it. Otherwise, you're probably going to drop the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994527406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1616646304}
review:
A game that I would be hard-pressed to top if needing to name a game that exemplifies the creed "easy to learn, difficult to master". That being said, this game is awesome, period. The design is tight, both in terms of aesthetic and mechanics. When you look at the top runs in a given level, you will find your jaw dropping over and over. It feels like the inputs are done so precisely that only a machine or someone who knows the game beat-for-beat would be able to execute with such precision. And truly, precision is likely the name of the game.
You'll come for the challenge and stay, again, for the challenge of trying to perfect your runs. I doubt that anyone coming in fresh to the game will be able to top and particular chart (or even top 10 for that matter) without many dozens, possibly hundreds, of hours invested into it.
To this day I'm not sure what control scheme is better suited to this game: a controller (where all relevant buttons are a glide away) or with a keyboard (where all the actions are laid out in a row). A friend of mine, who is far better at this game than I am, swears by the keyboard, and it does sometimes feel like the superior control scheme.

An honorable mention should go out to Lifeformed for a fantastic, near flawless OST. I love it. It is likely in my top 5, in fact. If nothing else, play this game for the music and ambiance alone (or better yet, go buy and support the artist).

Numeric score of 10/10 (10/10 does not mean flawless or perfect, but a truly excellent game that I would recommend to someone, if I had to give them only one game to play on Steam).

A solid game through and through, with the DX update only improving on an already excellent foundation. It may not be for everyone, but if you can do the tutorial and say "yeah...I get this", then your time and effort will be rewarded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025365699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1957, 'last_played': 1543807344}
review:
I highly, highly, highly recommend this game if you enjoy difficult platformers. The game pulls its inspiration from brutal platformers such as the Jumper series and Super Meat Boy. What sets Dustforce apart, however, is the emphasis on performing fluid and stylish runs. Like the aforementioned games, the levels are relatively short and when you die you simply respawn. Primary hazards include spikes and death traps. What's unique about Dustforce though is that each level contains 'dust' cleverly distributed throughout. You can simply get to the end of a level if you wanted, but you'll score better and feel more accomplished by clearing all the dust. This requires a near perfect series of maneuvers and speed unparalleled in any other platformer. Perhaps the most clever implentation within this game is the ability to watch other players' replays. As devising a feasible route for quickly clearing dust can itself be a puzzle, it is fantastic being able to see how the best of the best go about each level.

I just realized I'm kind of rambling and a lot of that probably doesn't make sense. Just get this game if you want a really good platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067359292', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1493507571}
review:
I can appreciate this game for what it is, it is an actual great game of its genre, unfortunately is not a genre I myself like  too much.

If you ever enjoyed games similar to Sonic ( a platform speed runner), where the objective is finishing the level as fast and with as many points as possible, comparing scoreboards with people world wide, this is definetly the game for you.

Its creative, fast, and you can even see exactly how the guy at the top of each stage managed to do his record run and learn from it. Its insane the skill and practice you have to have to run perfectly and at top speed on each stage to even qualify for the top scores.

It requires a lot of practice, skill and timing to master each stage and even start competing with the top scores. Unfortunately, platform runners like this are certainly not my cup of tea, I guess I could have tried playing the game in a more casual way without trying to get S scores, but it felt wrong to play it that way.

Defiently recommended for people looking for the next great Sonic-like game.

review: ‰∏çÈîôÁöÑÂ∞èÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºåÊúâÂú®Á∫øÊéíË°åÊ¶úÔºåÊú¨Âú∞Âèå‰∫∫„ÄÇ

author: {'steamid': '76561198179523627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 3533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2026, 'last_played': 1647726665}
review:
The Best platformer currently on Linux. Probably the best 2d platformer ever.

Cons:
-Difficulty Curve
definately not for newcomers of the platforming genre, or for impatient people. As this game is throughly made around it's mechanics. You will fail, you'll die, you'll be enraged when you can't beat a tough section. Infact I first made a joke review saying how you'll love the tutorial, because I could not get to the 3rd tutorial, Yes not beat, get to. This is also how dustforce teaches new players. By tempting a challange and use the player's curiousity to solve the issue.
-Story
The closest thing to a story is the opening sequence (Which can be disabled), and probably the multiplayer, but this is not a major issue. As the game was clearly not designed for story.

Pros:
-Graphics
Dustforce uses a vibrant and simplistic artstyle. It's soothing to look at, completely complementary to the gameplay. Your 5 enviroments are distinctive, the  tranquil forest, the grimy city roof tops, the minimalistic virtual levels, the haunting manor levels, and the futuristic lab levels. However they are not so distinct that you get tired of seeing them. A forest level might have a noon set stroll while another is at peaceful midnight. 
-Effects
The effects blend the artstyle and gameplay into a satisfying adventure. When you get that tail glow, not only does it look awesome, but helps keep track of your super attack. The trash particles when you sweep them up, feels rewarding, but also gives you visual feedback that you hit that part and you don't need to look back. Which helps the main concept of this game.
-Music
Like the Graphics, the music is reciprocal to the tough gamplay. Relaxing, and energetic the music calms the player. The devs knew it's not supposed to be snowing on your parade, so they took their cider time, and made their world a safe place to sleep. If you can't handle the frustrating 9-Bit expedition this game provides. Then buy this soundtrack.
-Gameplay
This is Why dustforce is the contender for best 2D platformer of all time. The platforming is fast paced, and gratifying. Nailing those jumps you once couldn't do as a newbie, is a sensation I rarely get from other platformers, but here it's every level. Hitting enemies and hearing that sweet SWACK sound is delightfully empowering. Even the hub world provides a amusing playground. The controls and fluid movement take some time to get use to, but you'll take to it like walking.
-Level Design
No other game knows itself better than dustforce. Their are several parts where you think, this can't be possible. But try, you'll get it eventually. Infact plottwists for this game is finding the new ways you can run in your virtual earth. The story of this game is it's gameplay. 
-Level Editor
You'd be suprised at the complexity of this thing, it offers basic building blocks and enemy placement, to light configurations and dynamic camera angles. The community maps are a treat, and diverse thanks to this robust editor.  
-Multiplayer
A fun distraction, very limiting because you have such a small arsonal, but a good time with friends.
-SpeedRuning
Normally I would not list this as a positive or negative, but man, Dustforce lives by it's speed running community. I'll never be as good as Luffy, Thor, or Freshmanic. But I love trying to beat the guy at 784th place on the leader boards, especially when I succeed.

Conclusion:
Play this game. I don't care if you get the steam version, playstation, or even if you pirate it. This game is a must play for fans of platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058159844', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 1697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1682, 'last_played': 1590127245}
review:
[i]Dustforce[/i] is a precision platformer whose controls are complete shit right up until the moment you start to get it. This is a pretty well-defined moment, and one in which you realise the potential your sluggish, heavy-footed janitor has to become a ninja with a broom. This is the point where I started to have fun. The game is still about hitting precise jumps at the exact right moment, but understanding of the game's mechanics surrounding momentum is what makes it genuinely fun. The difficulty curve can be pretty brutal, which was only alleviated a little bit by the [url=http://hitboxteam.com/dustforce-dx-update-released]overhaul patch[/url] released by Hitbox Team in 2014 (branded [i]Dustforce DX[/i]), which stopped the hub world from flowing like a brick wall by filtering players directly from the easiest tier of levels onto the next tier without leading them past the levels which introduce the mechanics integral for success.

The aforementioned hub world is divided into four areas - a fairly standard forest, a huge, empty mansion, a bustling city and a complex of underground laboratories. As of [i]Dustforce DX[/i], the hub world loops all the way around, filtering you back into the forest after you've completed the easiest tier of levels in the laboratories. Once back in the forest, you'll find that the new skills you've picked up actually help you access other levels within the previous regions, unveiling a more precise progression system than the game initially lets on. The [i]DX[/i] hub world is fantastic - not only does it provide potential for a more linear path through the game's many difficulty tiers, but it also creates a prerequisite level of ability for reaching certain maps. For instance, you're not going to be able to access the top floors of the mansion without some advanced climbing techniques. However, once you do reach these floors, the levels within will actually require that you use the same techniques to progress through them. It's a subtly clever way to protect players from accidentally stumbling into an pixel-perfect reflex orgy that they're not prepared to complete. It's a similar method to the one [i]Dark Souls[/i] uses - very little of the games learning curve comes in the form of text boxes or direct tutorials; you're expected to pick these things up as you go. It adds a lot of depth to the game's already gorgeous aesthetic of a janitor cleaning his environment in total solidarity.

Speaking of which - [i]Dustforce[/i] is gorgeous. From the smooth animations on the characters to the way dust and leaves kick up into the air and then dissipate when you sweep them up to the calm little chiptunes that play while you're cleaning, every cosmetic aspect of [i]Dustforce[/i] is to the end goal of contributing to the complete sense of calm that it invokes. It's a huge asset to the game's success that there isn't a plot - anything more complex than 'just clean everything up' would detract from the atmosphere and overcomplicate the two draws [i]Dustforce[/i] really has - simple controls used in complicated ways for maximum effectiveness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039118595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 10465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8736, 'last_played': 1647818019}
review:
This game is such a joy to play. The mechanics, though extremely hard to pick up, are amazingly crisp. This game is all about flow, and the feeling the game gives when I get into that flow is pure bliss.

This game most definitely is hard, but once you pick up the mechanics and learn how to move, the game just feels so good to play. I keep coming back to it to replay both the main levels and the amazing community made levels that are still being made 5 years later.

Definitely my favorite game on Steam, and a real contender for favorite game of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068101706', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1649037928}
review: Dustforce is a very unique and engaging game not like many around. The mechanics make for a speedrunner's dream, but they don't alienate the casual crowd with strict time enforcements. I find myself applying moves within other games, which I believe is a testament to the impression playing it has left on me. The environment is stunning and the soundtrack is by far distinguished enough to make the world stand apart as unique. I bought this game on sale, but it's a gem even at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067586068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3934, 'last_played': 1492959435}
review:
Grab your overalls and go for the dust !

Did you ever imagined a crossbreed between VVVVVV and Super Meat Boy ? This more or less wraps up that game.
Dustforce is a challenging platformer where every layer of dirt needs to be swept in order to access harder levels.

To do this, enter the Nexus, choose any of the four ninjanitors available and keep cleaning by walking over, jumping on or bashing filth. Controls are pleasant, and playthroughs sometimes heady for a cleaner work "simulation".

Remember, though, it's not easy task : if you're not specifically good, you'll have to arm yourself with patience, and a fairly great amount of it at that, to perfect the levels and assimilate subtle mechanics that honestly aren't obvious, and sometimes really frustrating.

But who knows, maybe you'll have a great time doing it, especially if you also enjoy those colorful 2D sceneries and Terence Lee's great music.

Anyway, Dustforce is to me an underrated platformer that should be tested at least once.

If you don't agree or are fed up with, then close your game, breathe, put your computer on standby, and take a real broom this time : perhaps it's time for you to take a cleaning break, with all those specks of dust around your room...

author: {'steamid': '76561198293013187', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1484539737}
review:
PROS:
- Smooth controls
- Comfy soundtrack
- Very challenging gameplay
- Beautiful graphics and theme
- Cleaning has never been so damn awesome!

CONS:
- Too difficult for platformer newbies
- You still won't clean your room after this

Dustforce is an indie platformer that blends various game mechanics together into a smooth and unique gameplay experience. While speed is a focus, the game also requires a certain amount of finesse that never feels too awkward. However, the challenge level rises very quickly and newbies may find themselves discouraged very early on.

Overall, I'd recommend this game more for platformer enthusiasts and hardcore players. Those who enjoyed the Sonic series and similar speed-focused games should definitely pick up this rare gem for a very memorable platformer experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022346251', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1459250211}
review:
- Fast paced, "competitive" platformer with the goal to play each stage over and over again to master the level design and race through the stage as fast as possible.
- Extensive and intuitively integrated leaderboard- and replay system to foster competition and self improvement.
- A pleasently unique and discreet art style.
- Stages play more fluid and compelling with each new atttempt through increasing skill and familiarity with the stage layout.
- As someone who rarely plays games in this type of genre, I thoroughly enjoyed the title for a good ten hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034935991', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1483292737}
review:
What a cool little game. It's a runner-platformer where you have to reach the end of the stage cleaning all sorts of dirt/slime/dust in the way. 

The animation is VERY well done and the level design is great to put all of your ninja/dusting skills into use. The soundtrack is noteworthy as well. I just didn't notice any difference between the 4 cleaners (if there's any at all) and there's not too many levels, though there's a level editor if you feel like giving it a shot. 

I recommend playing it with a controller, but you will have to manually map it in the options menu. If you don't want to, you can enjoy it with the keyboard as well, the controls are very responsive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085647654', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 64211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 18, 'playtime_at_review': 2145, 'last_played': 1709912486}
review:
Ce jeu est juste parfait. Des graphisme splendide , des mouvements rapides et badass , une prise en main facile et quand m√™me un c√¥t√© hardcore sans etre rageant !

Franchement Sire, je dis ch√¢teau! (comprendrons qui pourrons )

author: {'steamid': '76561198042442620', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 2736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2728, 'last_played': 1482440040}
review: I love this game to death, but it's frankly kind of hard to recommend to a lot of people. It's definitely for those who want to MASTER a game. It's a speed runner's dream. It gets hard as hell eventually, but I've found that with enough practice I've done what I thought was impossible. The soundtrack is pure distilled chilled love. The feeling of control in this game is pretty weird. I want to say they're fluid, but it has a handful of quirks, I've played enough of the game that I don't notice any more. If you want a platforming challenge, get Dustforce. It feels great when you get the flow of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038649693', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5808, 'last_played': 1692840852}
review: I'm a little biased because I just got the achievement, but this really is one of the best platformers EVER made, and such a good game either to relax into or to enjoy in-depth. Wonderful level design, deep mechanics, and an active community mean you're almost never going to run out of things to do with this game, whether you want to shoot for a good time or just play whatever levels you want.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993693261', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1935, 'last_played': 1419188583}
review:
Deeply underrated precision platformer. 

Highly difficult even within its genre. It probably has the most intricate control scheme of any precision platformer. You've got multiple different types of attacks, wall running, air dashes, etc. Just a lot going on.

Awesome vibes and a killer soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064198257', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3546, 'last_played': 1630631545}
review: Dustforce is a masterpiece. The controls, although somewhat difficult to pick up, are the most fluid and technical of any platformer I've ever played. The skill ceiling is through the roof, and even after hours and hours of gameplay it's difficult to complete, and subsequently perfect the harder levels the game has to offer. If you enjoyed super meat boy, or ssbm, this game is definitely for you. Mechanics are rock solid, soundtrack is Beautiful/10, stage and sprite design is 9/10 just because Abyss and Backup Shift are ugly. My best advice if you want to play this game is to just spend some time with it. It may take a few hours before you really get a good feel for the controls, and it will take many hours before you have any semblance of mastery. But nonetheless communjty is great and dustforce is one of my favorite games of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028056226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1697157653}
review:
It's really cool to see a platformer that uses action elements not to simply make the game have a fighting aspect, but to add a layer of complexity to platforming.  Every move that you can perform can be used in defense against enemies, but enemies are generally positioned in a way that allow the player to fight them while maintaining momentum through the levels.

Difficulty for this game ramps up pretty quick, but the satisfaction of mastering an area or level in this game is super high.  The game is also quick to reset the player after messing up, so the penalty isn't very frustrating.

To top it off, the game has an amazing soundtrack.  It complements the style of play very well.  I feel like the soothiness of the music has often made the time spent to master an area or level enjoyable.  I mean, this game gets pretty hard...it could be one of those "flip the table in frustration" games, but the environments and soundtrack are so relaxing that it's easy to convince yourself to keep trying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058087481', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3043, 'last_played': 1585590562}
review:
[b]Dustforce is a gem in the rough. A relatively unseen, unknown game that blows away many AAA titles released today, just out of sheer love and attention by the developers.[/b]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Finely tuned. That's the most accurate description that comes to mind when I think of what it feels like to play Dustforce. In the same way that you can pick up Smash Bros for the very first time, or be a veteran who knows every combo, and still have an absolute blast, this game delievers an identical experiece on depth of fun. There is a brief tutorial in the beginning of the game to familiarize players with the most basic mechanics, but then they do a wonder of teaching through experience. The levels ramp in difficulty, from "so easy my blind grandma could do it" to "you're going to have to practice this one for 8 hours if you want to finish it". That sounds like a barrier, in a world where we feel the need to play every game until completion, but it's quite freeing in practice. You finally get to play what's [i]fun[/i]. If you like the easiest, relaxing levels, there's something here for you. If you like mind-numblingly difficult ones, they've got you covered. And when you're done with all of those? Swing over to their website for thousands of user-created cakewalks and nightmares. 

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
You can see for yourself, this game is beautiful. Lovingly crafted, the look perfectly complimenting the gameplay. Every animation, every character, every enemy, is an absolute joy to watch. As you speed around the levels sweeping up dust, leaves, and other grime, you'll feel a sense of ease and relaxation. It's odd to say for a game that can be so challenging and difficult, but how could you not when even the color pallete is perfectly chosen.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
A masterpiece. You can hear it in the trailer, but it doesn't do it quite the same justice as playing the game with it running in the background. If you would like to give the entire thing a listen, you can do so [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8_B8ekeZTCM]here[/url].

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
[b]If you take the time and put in the effort to become good at this game, it's like magic. Like water flowing through your hands, or painting gorgeous works of art. One movement glides into another, no infurating bugs to ruin your progress, no janky mechanics to kill your zen-like trance. Dustforce let's you feel like you've mastered it, in a way that very few do.[/b]

Just buy the game, sit down for a good session, and hopefully you'll see what I saw in this title when I first played it many years ago.




[b]Old Review[/b]
This game is truly a masterpiece regarding mechanics and soundtrack. The depth and skill level required for some of the bonus levels is mind-boggling, and it's the most satisfying feeling to climb up the leaderboards and compete against your friends. I highly recommend this to anyone who likes smooth, mechanics-based platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993274629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2905, 'last_played': 1532630339}
review:
Dustforce is a wonderful little platformer. 
It's extremely hard, at least when you get to the later levels, but the earlier ones are perfectly designed and super fun, and pushing against your records for time is enjoyable by itself, without necessarily beating all the levels. 

I think the best part about the game is how tightly designed it is, in terms of the controls and the interface, and the leaderboard system. This could have very easily been an underwhelming game if it was just a series of levels with nothing to encourage you to beat your score or watch other people's runs. 
If the idea of a time trial 2d platformer sounds appealing to you, you should really get this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028673669', 'num_games_owned': 7009, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1480000142}
review:
This is the amazing game, one of my 1st steam purchases ever, and I still love it till today:

+Soundwork: OST is the biggest plus of this game, amazing music, and other sound effects are very smooth. Great soundwork.
+Visuals: Great pixelated graphics, with cool style, so even pixelated the game looks pretty smooth. Great effects - dust, leafs etc, infected animals looks cool before and after. A pleasure to see.
+Gameplay: Has its pros and cons - one the one hand - this game is amazing platformer with —År–∞pton of levels + community map packs - on the other hand - after sometimes game gets really difficult, making its nearly impossible to fully complete, so you can enjoy a lot of easy/medium levels but not beat the game, or you can enjoy all levels but sweat your a55 off - would enjoy if you are hardcore platformer fan.
Oh, you also have 4 characters to pick with different stats!
+Controls - pretty smooth reliable controls, most likely this game is better with a controller.
+Steam cards
-The one and only steam achievement is nearly impossible to get - like 0.3% of people got it.

After all, this game is amazing, stylish and fun to play platformer that also good if you like HARD games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084291562', 'num_games_owned': 275, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1533354257}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000783445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 10589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10436, 'last_played': 1649386147}
review:
Amazing platformer, personally I found it pretty difficult to get the hang of the game at first, but I stuck with it and I'm glad I did, this is my favorite 2D platformer that I've ever played!

Once you get a hang of the controls, the levels all have a great flow to them. On top of that the game has an amazing soundtrack and the levels look very nice!

The game has in-game leaderboards with replays, so if you ever wonder how the fastest players achieved their times, you can watch their runs from within the game.

There's also a level editor if you want to make your own levels and there's a site where you can browse and download user-made levels, so you'll always have something to play.

I definitely recommend this game! (And the soundtrack as well!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038683014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 25165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23427, 'last_played': 1693752448}
review:
If you like a challenge, this is a game for you. The levels start off easy to get you used to the controls but they ramp up in difficulty quickly. But the best part is that it's all fair. No random disappearing blocks, falling spikes or anything of the sort. If you mess up, it's all on you. You'll find yourself grinding a hard level for hours to get SS rank without it really feeling like a grind and it'll all be worth it when you get it.

There's also a level editor with a huge amount of user created levels on the Atlas in case you want more challenges and neat ideas you wouldn't see in the stock levels.

One of my favourite features though is the leaderboard/replay system. Every run automatically gets recorded and uploaded to the boards so you can view anyone's run at any time (as long as you have an internet connection of course). No need to wonder how the world record got such a crazy time, you can just view it yourself! It really pushes you to improve yourself and compete with your friends.

You can easily put in a lot of hours so it's an absolute bargain for the price, especially since it regularly goes on a deep sale.

review:

It's a keyboard-friendly and really difficult platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061162977', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 2153, 'last_played': 1710291202}
review:
This is a great precision platform game.

Soundtrack: Soundtrack in this title is pretty unique. It is hard to find such well composed and level matched songs in the game industry.

Art: The art concept is odd at the first look, but if you pay attention you will see harmony and hard work behind it. Its an odd art concept for an odd game. But odd is not bad. And it is not too odd.

Gameplay: As a precision platformer this game has so many features that made this style playable to most of us. And yes,  the gameplay is smooth and awesome.

This is the major features of the game. Thank you for your time! If you need a score, there it is: 10/10.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198029929832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1498, 'last_played': 1633468522}
review:
Dustforce is one of the best games I've played in the 2D platformer category.
The controls are very tight and well made, having the possibility to do everything from the beginning - your skills progression solely depend on your increasing understanding and ability to control your janitor. If you're into a whole lot of challenge, this game can provide it. (and if you're easily frustrated by absurd difficulty, which exists in the later part of this game - consider avoiding the game).
The graphics are beautiful, atmospheric and give each level-set a defined feel and flow.
The soundtrack is a bit too relaxed sometimes for my taste, but overall really great.

I am close to - but have not finished the game yet and played mostly the provided levels, but I know there are plenty of rich community levels, besides the base content.

So far it has been a great challenge a lot of fun - I highly recommend this game. (and consequently also look forward to Hitbox Team's Spire).

author: {'steamid': '76561198009924365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 15484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15194, 'last_played': 1511970606}
review:
Dustforce is a calming game. The game isn't labelled difficult for nothing, but the game is probably a very different tone than most you'd find under the category. Between the calming visuals and the serene soundtrack, I never really got that frustrated like I would in other difficult platformers: instead I got determined.

That's part of the magic of Dustforce. It's one of those games that really lets you take the game at your own pace, do levels how you see fit. There's no plot or story which allows you to explore whichever unlocked door you want to first.

It's a very easy game to get into, with challenge ramping and testing you throughout. The entire game is essentially a tutorial. Unlike similar describable games though, there is an endgame there.

Enter the community. You can watch the top run that anyone has done in the game via the replay system. You can see how any of your friends tackled the level. You can see the guy who shaved a few frames off your time and see what he did differently. Anyone you meet who plays this game extensively is also incredibly friendly and just welcoming new faces to the game. It's got to have one of the best video game communities I've ever been bare to witness. 

So pick it up, try it out, see if it's your cup of tea. You might be surprised how fun cleaning can be, and how far you can take it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133628702', 'num_games_owned': 2145, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1475339598}
review:
Great speed-run platformer that you can play casually or competitively. The levels start out pretty easy enough but then they get to god-like levels of difficulty. One thing I don't like about the game is that there is only achievement and it requires you to master every level in order to get it. Also, the controls are kinda strange at first, I almost gave up on this game until I found a key-map that I liked. It's a pretty great platformer overall though that requires some real level of skill to master!

4/5

Map your keys as follows;
WASD --> Movement

L --> Dash
P --> Jump
; --> Light Attack
' --> Hard Attack

author: {'steamid': '76561197983545926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 348, 'playtime_forever': 840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 840, 'last_played': 1474150640}
review:
I've really tried to like this game over the past 5 or so years I've owned it. I love the concept, but I really can't say I enjoy the 'feel' of the game. It has some weird momentum-based physics that give it a sort of 'floaty' feel to it. A lot of people will call this a precision-based platformer. I would call it pretentious. The devs did well to implement a series of tutorials, as they thought the game was too hard for many. However, there are still a ton of hidden mechanics that aren't explicitly taught to the player, so it's often confusing once you've completed a certain number of levels on where to head next. Until you know what's possible in the context of the game, it's really off-putting. I shouldn't have to go to forums and YouTube to determine that there are many completely obtuse things hidden in the game's mechanics in order to proceed. 

Additionally, there are numerous bugs this game has, such as the game deciding it will automatically use up your double jump if you are too close to an edge. Mr Peck on YouTube has these documented, if you want some evidence of them. Tons of optimization problems, such as crashing if you alt+tab out of the window and simply setting up a controller is a nightmare if you want to switch between keyboard and gamepad; buttons across both is frustrating. They should have just used a 'set all buttons' command and let the player sequentially determine the mappings.

If I were looking for a game in this genre, it'd be Wings of Vi over this - feels way better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132333943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1473451983}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025540438', 'num_games_owned': 7100, 'num_reviews': 558, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1473364359}
review:
A challenging platformer that's comparable to a more tactical Meat Boy: rather than the goal just being to get to the end as fast as possible without dying, you're also tasked with cleaning up as much dust/leaves/trash/etc on the ground as possible (by running over it as you traverse the level), and in as large of a combo as possible by sweeping it all up in quick succession, while also dealing with the occasional small group of enemies. 

While the controls feel a bit different than what you'd normally expect out of this sort of game, they're actually very well made once you've had some time to get used to them. The gameplay is rock-solid, the soundtrack and art are comfy, and the higher-difficulty levels provide a great challenge.

My main gripe with the game, and consider this an important disclaimer if you're anything less than really, -really- good at platformers, is the system for unlocking new levels. 
Levels have 5 difficulties, which for purposes of space we'll call A, B, C, D, and E. By default, you have all of the A levels unlocked. Completing an A level and getting an S rank for both dust cleared and max combo (called SS rank) earns you a key to unlock a single B level. Likewise, earning SS rank on a B level unlocks you a C level, SS-C unlocks a D, and earning SS on all of the D levels opens up a bonus hub world containing the E levels.
It's important to note that to earn S-rank for each category, you must score absolutely perfectly. That is, clear -all- the dust from the level, and have a combo that stretches all the way from the first patch of dust to the last. 
If you earn less than an SS rank, be it SA, AS, BB, CD, or whatever, you only earn a portion of a key. So in example, earning BC rank on two A levels would get you a single B key and some progress towards the next one, as opposed to the two you'd have earned if you had scored SS ranks.
This brings up the pretty immediate problem that, if you don't have the skill and/or patience to keep retrying to earn SS on every level, you'll never unlock the more challenging (and at least for me, the more fun) parts of the game, especially considering that dying, or even just getting hit, automatically disqualifies you from earning S for combo unless you start the entire level over again.
While this isn't a huge issue for A and B levels for anyone of at least moderate skill, C levels already ramp up the challenge significantly, and D levels are pretty much Meat Boy tier in how many times you're going to die trying to beat them (don't even get me started on the E levels), so this system ends up locking out a lot of players from a significant portion of the game merely because they weren't -absolutely perfect- at it.

This aside, I do recommend the game to anyone who likes truly challenging platformers, as there's a light at the end of the tunnel that saved this review from being a Negative one: Should you find yourself in the same situation I did, having a lot of fun with just the challenge of beating the levels, but no fun at all at the prospect of going back and spending hours trying to perfect them, something you may simply not have the skill to do, the game has a community-made mod called Dustmod that, among a whole lot of other functions, lets you switch your save file to NG+ with the click of a button, unlocking all of the levels and letting you play the entire game without having to worry about rank.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025468901', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 531, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1414140716}

review:
[h1][b]Step aside Super Meat Boy, there's a new king of precision platformers.[/b][/h1]

After 50 hours I have completed Dustforce and got the SS+ achievement and I can honestly say this is my favorite 2D platformer of all-time. 

Get to point A to point B and make sure to clean up all of the dust along the way.
Do it quickly and without getting hit to maintain your combo.

[h1][b]Controls: Amazing
Art: Amazing
Music: Amazing
Story: None
Gameplay: Amazing
Difficulty: Very Hard[/b][/h1]

It's challenging and rewarding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062942976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2835, 'last_played': 1677206198}
review:
Dustforce is a great precision platformer with a very high skill ceiling. If you enjoy speedrunning and technical movement, or just want a fun little 2D platformer with relaxing audiovisuals, I would definitely recommend this game.

The goal of the game is to get a perfect score in each level, which involves clearing all of the dust without missing a spot and while maintaining your combo. Now, it is very difficult to do this in every level, especially in the endgame levels. Dustforce is more about seeing how far you can push your abilities. Each level has an online leaderboard where you can compare your time against others, and see how low you can push your time. In the beginning, some jumps and obstacles seem impossible, like they require you to unlock a new item or technique or something, but Dustforce is purely skill-based. As you master the movement, you slowly figure out how to overcome these challenges with your default abilities, and find new ways to do levels faster and faster.

The game has instant replays for every run on the leaderboards, a level editor, a great soundtrack, and a large number of base levels. I think this is a very enjoyable game, but you have to remember to have some patience with it. It may take some time to master the movement, and some of the harder levels may take hours of attempts to beat properly.

(Edited my review to rewrite it better)

review:
Dustforce is one of those games that I genuinely feel only people who are aces with timing and execution love. I'm not one of those people, and while I really like Dustforce, I caution that it can be very challenging to those who don't quickly grasp game mechanics and the various ways in which they could be used.

If you find yourself to be a fairly high-skill gamer (in terms of movement tech), then this is a game for you. If you like simpler platformers like Mario, Sonic, and the like, this may be a game worth passing by for now.
