author: {'steamid': '76561198040576203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1485165461}
review:
[h1][b]"I can't beat it, therefore it's a bad game." Just... No.[/b][/h1] This isn't Surgeon Simulator, or Probably Archery, or QWOP.

Dustforce is underrated and unfairly downrated. Whether you're good/not good at it, the game is great. "Tight and responsive controls" commonly boil down to "easy and requiring little brain power" and lead to less technical capability for a player to utilize. It's one loathesome reason why people say gamers barely use their brains. Blaming the non-status quo movement and momentum physics to justify giving a negative review is a poor, lazy, subjective decision that doesn't do Dustforce justice, especially when many others can actually do it. Refer to Super Metroid for a minute. It's an iconic example of completely breaking the norm for platformers. It fused with action, exploration adventure, and has controls and physics that shatter your experiences if you've only jumped like a Mario or a Mega Man.

Like a fighting game, Dustforce's controls will require some learning and does not give you "Yeah, I get it" filler moments. The skill ceiling is much higher. The tricks are much more complex. Good fighting game players know more than to just spam 2 moves. Good platformer players can do more than just run + (double/wall) jump. Also see TotalBiscuit's video review on his YouTube channel for a good, objective take at the game. It's for an old version but the things covered in the video still hold up. One more important thing to note is that this game was [i]not[/i] made in Game Maker. Only the [i]prototype[/i] was. The finished product uses its own workings built from scratch. Don't be like those fools who don't read/research and bash the game on an incorrect fact.

[i]Dustforce is a difficult game. That doesn't take all the fun away... There will be those incorrect people who think that being bad at a game alone means the game sucks. "This game sucks" is not the correct way to say "I suck at this game", or "In reality, I'm too lazy to learn".[/i] The controls, which [i]can[/i] be rebound, [i]do[/i] have a learning curve that the player is supposed to grow into and be accustomed with. This should not be a problem if you have played fighting games with a competitive/more technical mindset. If not, don't worry. Every player of this game was bad at some point. Just play through the 3 tutorial levels without worrying about getting S/S rank in the beginning. Granted, they're all harder than the first normal levels you will get so don't worry how badly you do, but they're there to show you how the game works of course. Trying to be immediately perfect at something new is an unrealistic and unhealthy mentality. Break things down into smaller pieces at a time. Their varied environments are good to experiment & practice in. You don't have to be the top 10%, or even top 30%, of the leaderboards to really enjoy what Dustforce has to offer.

A while back, this game caught some flak with being compared to another fun, difficult game: Super Meat Boy. I have seen a couple speedruns for both games, including developer commentary during 1 of each run, I've seen "Indie Game: The Movie" with its developer coverage of SMB, and have had my hands on both SMB and DF. SMB is great for all its reasons, but it can't be compared to Dustforce since they're fundamentally different games. SMB draws much more on artistic theme. DF draws much more on technical gameplay. It's loud and clear that both games have different target audiences. If it isn't to you, then you gotta look and listen harder. These 2 are [b]not[/b] better or worse when placed next to each other. Just [b]different[/b]. Apples and oranges, ladies and gentlemen.

SMB is more precision platformer than DF is. DF is more momentum platformer than precision. Here are a few points to think about this situation.

SMB is a bit like:
- Super Mario Bros. (Movement, as in there are fewer "tools" that the player will have and the environment accounts for most of your choices.)
- Classic Mega Man (platforming)
- A touch of Super Smash Bros style crossovers

DF is a bit like:
- Super Smash Bros. series (Movement, as in there are more "tools" for the player to use. Environment alone accounts for less than that of SMB. More on that in a bit.)
- Zero's character style from Mega Man X series and classic 2D Sonic (platforming)
- A touch of Super Smash Bros combat. It's simply "hold a direction or not" before hitting an attack button, but the timings must be right or you'll whiff and button mash like a newbie. The momentum style and Super Smash Bros aspect is even confirmed by one the developers. More info on that in the final paragraph.

Dustforce has more weight on utilizing the system of the character at a deeper level akin to fighting games instead of just mainly interacting with the environments themselves. Players must be thinking about what they can do with their options and what the environment calls for at the same time. Much more of the game is in the player's hands instead of the environment forcing decisions in a 1-sided fashion. DF has more meat on character controls than your typical platformer: dashes, air-dashes, air-down-dashes, normal attack, normal attack + directional mid-air, heavy attack, heavy attack + directional mid-air, wall jump, wall running, ceiling running, slope sliding, momentum preservation after hitting enemies while mid-air, fillable gauge for super AoE attack, etc. All of these interact with the physics of the game to produce even more things. All of these are learned as you go and become natural. At least they should be. More attention on what your character is ACTUALLY doing (not what you THINK s/he should be doing) is a must in this game. Level selection also isn't just a grid with things to select. To play a level, you must clear the platforming section to the door in the hub world. This introduces the techniques required to complete such levels. Difficult levels will need the player to be skilled enough to reach them, let alone complete them.

This game has been featured in Games Done Quick speedrun charity events. The Summer Games Done Quick 2015 run (Any% route) also has one of the developers talking with the runner and commentators. I highly recommend seeing that on YouTube if you're still skeptical on buying this game. The dev comments are great and the pro play will undoubtedly be amazing. There are also "All levels S/S ranking" runs to watch. Remember, you don't have to be as good as them to enjoy the game.

Some dev comments from that run to note & more:
- They thank the community greatly in helping detect cheated runs to delete off the leaderboards.
- It's not so much a precision platformer as much as it is a momentum platformer. Get a feel for how far your momentum can carry you and keep going. If you can't make a jump, did you deliberately decelerate in mid-air or after landing on a platform? (You might wanna call up Sonic for some tips. And fire Mario or Mega Man if they happen to be your tutors who said that they'll teach you everything you need to know about platforming. You got scammed.)
- The game is inspired in part by N+, and Super Smash Bros. series.
- Coding for the movement and momentum consists of about 5,000 lines to be able to do what it can do. Some minor inconsistencies exist most likely due to rounding errors, but you wouldn't notice unless you were told about them or spent lots of time experimenting. None of these will bar you from completing the game at any skill level (obviously many have already done so) as all physics interactions discovered were tested.
- Difficult levels requiring skill to reach and enter in the hub world is a system to help players recognize their strengths and weaknesses versus a traditional level selection screen where players would just get walled and discouraged by surprise difficulty spikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022209629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1035, 'last_played': 1688804501}
review:
I wouldn't call myself a Jump'n Run fan, but every now and then a strong title appears and sucks me in with its addictive flow state.
Dustforce is one of those games, that are repetitive in the best possible way. Where many games are a sequence of similar levels, each played a single time, Dustforce is a set of unique challenges, which have to be tried again and again to be mastered.

Let's talk about the game's overall structure first. The player is thrown into a hub world, filled with several doors, which lead to the individual levels. While in theory the player can reach every door from the start, most of them are locked with bronze, silver or golden padlocks. Those levels already accessible, need to be played to unlock bronze doors, which again are required for silver keys and so forth. In order to open all locks of a kind, every level below that kind has to be finished with a top ranking (more on that later) ‚Äî but lower rankings accumulate and can unlock at least some of the higher levels as well.
This is a great way to keep the player within the flow curve. Hard levels ‚Äî and boy, they get hard ‚Äî can't be accessed until the player has proven his/her salt. And by using a ranking system the game makes sure, that the player actually played well and didn't just luckily stumble over the finish line. On the other hand, players are still able to unlock a few new levels, as long as they at least perform okay.

There is a second design decision preventing players from taking challenges above their skill level. I mentioned earlier, that levels are accessed through a hub world. Within that hub world, the level doors aren't just lined up, like they are in Rayman Legends for example. Instead the hub world is a level itself, where the doors have to be reached.
Doors to simple levels can be reached by walking, with a few occasional jumps in between. Doors of more difficult levels require skill and a solid understanding of different movement mechanics. And to top it all: it's not like you need any arbitrary trick, but exactly those skills needed within the level you are trying to reach. By this, the game makes sure you know what to do in every level.

Let's talk about level structure next. Most levels are linear, with a clear route and a bad guy to beat up at the end. There is dust on the floor (or on the ceiling or wherever) that the avatar brushes away automatically when running over it. The interface has a combo counter, indicating how much dust has been collected. If no dust is swept for five seconds or the player gets hit or dies, the combo is interrupted and the counter reset.
After finishing a level, the player is evaluated for the amount of dust cleaned (completion) and the number of combo interruptions (finesse). To get a double S (and unlock a key) all dust has to be collected without a single interruption.
Evaluating both completion and finesse is a clever way to ensure good play. Abusing blinking time or brute forcing every single obstacle won't bring you the necessary finesse to advance. Using shortcuts to pass by hard sections won't work either, because dust in skipped sections is guaranteed to be missed. You can use these techniques to finish a level of course ‚Äî and some levels can be done ridiculously fast using shortcuts, ‚Äî but harder levels are reserved for good players.

All this dynamic balancing is necessary to keep players engaged while they still learn how the game is played. Dustforce has a lot of movement techniques, from sliding down slopes over fast-falling to running at the ceiling. Every movement requires precise input. In contrast to the heavily automated system of an Assassins Creed, your avatar in Dustforce will do nothing that you don't tell him/her explicitly.
Unfortunately not all of Dustforce's options are taught properly. The game starts with a set of three solid tutorials, explaining most important aspects ‚Äî how to reset your double-jump for example. Abstruse, while nevertheless useful, techniques like spike-jumping on the other hand, are left unmentioned.
It took me a few hours (and a good youtube tutorial) to "get" the controls and gain a solid level of mastery. Those few hours weren't boring at all though and the top-class Jump'n Run I got in return was a satisfying trade.

There isn't so much, that I want to say about Dustforce's aesthetics, but I can't let them be unmentioned.
The game's sprites have few details and let their well-chosen color pallets speak instead. I also like how the four playable characters differ in design. Each of them cleans with another tool, from broom to vacuum cleaner, and color, animations and hats all differ too. I'm particularly fond of Dustworth's design, who looks like Luigi got old fast after exorcising his mansion.
There are few sound effects ‚Äî and no voices at all ‚Äî but that almost feels intentional to underline the game's great chiptune soundtrack. Almost all songs are strong enough to stand their own, but they accompany each levels theme pretty well too.

Mechanics, structure, balancing and aesthetics all interlock and support each other just right. When I started Dustforce, I was expecting a satisfying high complexity platformer, but the game is so fine tuned and works so well that I'm surprised that it isn't more popular. I highly recommend it for every Jump'n Run fan out there.

Read more of my reviews at:
theguygaming.com

author: {'steamid': '76561198079537972', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1540520150}
review:
I would really only recommend this game to speed-runners and completionists. It's fun to play even though I'm not the type for skill based games like these, but my only issue is that getting to some of the levels is difficult and require that you use a difficult technique to reach them and it took me a while and I had to watch some videos.
     As for the actual levels themselves, you don't really die or anything just reset when you fall or touch spikes, but when an enemy hits you, it only knocks you back a little and breaks your combo. Your combo determines your 'finess' score. If you choose to play the game at a slower pace and don't care about score, then it's pretty boring, seeing as no actual 'deaths' means no risk to messing up a jump or getting hit by an enemy. There is multiplayer but it's only local, but there is also a level editor which gives the game a lot of replay value.

TLDR: Speed-runners, completionists - :approved:
           Casuals - :denied:   
           Everything else - it's up to personal preference really

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1952, 'num_reviews': 2041, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1466718701}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Dustforce DX is a fast paced platformer where all you need to do is sweep sweep and sweep

The gameplay is simple and fluent but hard to master. The game is not easy to play especially in the later levels and can cause quite a frustrationn to some players. The music and visuals are really nice and pretty and fit in well with the aesthetic the game is going for

It is highly recommended that Dustforce DX is played with a controller rather than a keyboard because the game is fast paced and it is more tailored for a controller

Dustforce DX is a great indie game to play, it's face paced, challenging but not too difficult to play. Dustforce DX is an interesting title to pick up and play

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198013924266', 'num_games_owned': 622, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1626, 'last_played': 1708105985}
review:
Oh. My. God. 

How the hell have I missed playing this game up until now?! 

I can't actually find descriptive enough words to convey the utter brilliance of this game. The soundtrack is the best I've heard since the old time Legend of Zeldas and Final Fantasies. The fluidity and stylishness and light-heardedness of the movement and gameplay is a sight to behold. Personally, I feel like I get transported to another world when I play Dustforce.

This game is a masterstroke, and holy shit is it satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059682069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1467, 'last_played': 1494727490}
review: A hardcore, rewarding speedrunner's platform game.  Imagine Super Mario Bros with brooms, wallrunning and such a high skill ceiling that you can run the same level several hundred times over many hours and still only land in the top thousand records.  Watch other players' replays in-game to see how the pros route the level (great feature!), master your favorite character (each of them play differently, and the differences are even more notable in high level play), complete the simpler levels to unlock progressively more insane stages (and possibly the most challenging secret stage zone I've ever seen), and feel the power of your own improvement.  Visit Dustkid.com to get involved in the running community and save all your replays - a sure way to track your own rank and improvement.  This game becomes more fun with every minute you put into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067111424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 88291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78580, 'last_played': 1703051029}
review:
Dustforce DX is not an easy to pick up game. I'm one of the best active players in the game atm, and as you can see that my hours reflect the dedication needed to be among the of the best.

However, as a casual game, while the mechanics take some getting used to, they start feeling fluid and cohesive. There are 4 action keys along w/ the arrow keys (I use keyboard), which take a ton of time to get into muscle memory. But as the difficulty increases and the game keeps teaching you different mechanics, the satisfaction from beating a difficult level is immense. The soundtrack, composed by one of the devs of the game, is simple and elegant IDM, creating a calmer atmosphere, even in the middle of spikes.

I'd highly recommend this game to fans of technical platforming and those who enjoy a real challenge and have real patience in gaming. If you want to achieve a really good time, or complete that really difficult level, it'll take a while to get there. But I think the dedication and payoff is worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060476101', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1604862564}
review:
Dustforce DX is a game aimed around timetrials.
How quickly can you clean up - but not sounding so tedious.
It's difficult to master but really easy to sit down and chill with.
The controls are smooth and easy to learn seeing as it consists of lots of wave dashing, air dashing and sliding up walls.
Its a casual game for the committed OCD gamer types who want those Platinum/S+ grades.
Music is great too

review: Decent platformer with overly precise controls. Seems to be geared towards the competitve platforming scene, which is a niche audience if there ever was one. If you're that sort of gamer, there's tons of depth here. If you're not, then the music is soothing and the early levels can be incredibly zen-like if you don't take it too seriously...though you will unfortunately be gated to them unless you suddenly become really good.

review:
The game looked like an interesting platformer and I really wanted to try it but it just failed to meet expectations.

There is something about controls that it feels like a chore, like I'm struggling with a basic controls. Even when my character did all those ninja moves it just didn't feel like a consequence of my actions. I played for a short while but it was just not satisfying nor enjoyable experience. Also I don't know if there is any plot later on but from these few levels I played it just looks like a loooooong series of challenge rooms. Nothing to keep me interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023133511', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1505859632}
review:
Dustforce est un excellent plateformer sur une th√©matique atypique : des balayeurses qui doivent litt√©ralement "clean" les niveaux !

Le gameplay est r√©actif et plaisant, avec des tutos simples mais permettant de bien appr√©hender la chose, les graphismes sont jolis et l'OST est *excellente*, dans un style tr√®s calme et apaisant. 
A noter que pour les joueurses √† la manette il faudra reconfigurer les boutons √† la main. Un moindre effort m√™me si c'est dommage que cela ne soit pas fait par d√©faut. 

Adapt√© aux novices de plateformers (dont je fais plut√¥t partie) comme aux acharn√©s, il propose une difficult√© variable, un syst√®me de notation et un classement mondial qui sont des fonctionnalit√©s vraiment appr√©ciables pour augmenter la dur√©e de vie ! 

Je recommande. =)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025482130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1623119500}
review:
Before commencing this review, I would like to note that this is a game that should really be played using a gamepad.  The default controls use the keyboard but the game does not work well when it's played that way.  If you don't own a gamepad you may not necessarily have the best experience with Dustforce.

I'm not normally the type of person who enjoys platformers, especially fast-paced ones like these, but something about Dustforce resonates very strongly with me.  I entered the game wary, as the complicated gameplay and challenging levels that I had seen were intimidating, but in under two days I've put over ten hours into it and I haven't had this much fun in a video game in a long time.

I suppose this is a difficult game to review objectively, but if you're an obsessive perfectionist like myself then this game will likely have you playing for hours at a time without slowing down.  The good music, relaxed atmosphere, and very fluid animations of the game make that much easier to accomplish.  I suggest that even if you aren't a fan of platformers, if you like a game with many testing challenges to overcome, then you should definitely buy this one.  It's worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083478269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1664110563}
review:
Traditional platforming has never felt so graceful. 

If I had to sum up dustforce in one word it would be ‚ÄúUnderstated.‚Äù Everything from the stylized visual aesthetic, to the almost silhouette character sprites, the animations, enemies and even the level design all hold themselves with such dignity. The small flashes of flare that you get, when performing your special ability and the slow motion finishing move at the end of each level all give you a sense of ‚ÄúYeah, I just did that, whatever.‚Äù As you calmly walk off from your amazing display of platforming prowess without even looking back.

Mechanics wise, dustforce is a great example of giving the player a single minded goal, and the tools to get there. I forgot where I read it and i hope they don't mind the unattributed quote but it sums up so perfectly the mentality I draw from the game. ‚ÄúDustforce is not content to let you be content with yourself.‚Äù Again apologies for probably butchering the original quote but it is so true.

Dustforce has a tiered level structure where you unlock keys to higher tiered levels by completing previous ones to a certain proficiency. While simply completing the level from start to finish may be enough at the start to work towards a few keys and level, you will eventually need to break past your preconceived limits. This system of partial completion still progressing the player is great for giving the player control over their own difficulty curve and doesn‚Äôt fall into the pit of so many other challenging platformers where you get stuck on a single level and cannot progress.

Another thing it does great is support the players journey of self improvement without being overbearing. After completing any particular level you are given access to the high scores from the community. But where other games may stop there dustforce then records the exact run of that player so that you can view it whenever you want in its entirety. I cannot tell you the amount of times I was stuck on certain levels but then was able to completely change my approach after seeing a ‚Äúpro‚Äù do it in front of my eyes.

But no game is perfect and Dustforce is no exception. The physics and movement in the game is very momentum based. If you are unable to continue your exact series of boosts and ramp launches you will find your experience rather jerky. When it works it makes speed runs a visually awe inspiring art, but when it doesn't you find yourself spamming jumps off walls at odd angle into spike pits or off cliffs.

I would recommend this game to anyone that loves tried and tested platforming mechanics with a stylish coat of paint and some really nice quality of life features. And to anyone that loves the feeling of becoming one with your controller, eye's glazed, as you become one with the game and skirt even the most precarious platform dungeons with grace and ease.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041108401', 'num_games_owned': 1215, 'num_reviews': 493, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1457729787}
review: Nice Idea, cool animations, feels awesome to tidy up, but it has no story and it has no difficulty to complete any level. The whole game is not about completing a challenging level, no there are no challenging levels when it comes to completing, no its about making highscores and comparing with the people around the world. Almost every level is accessable at the start, you just gather some easy taken keys and unlock all other levels. A level is completed under 1 minute. The real thing begins with doing a level over and over again until you know every jump inside out. This is a challenging task, but repeating the same thing over and over again is more like work than fun for me. Therefore I cannot recommend this game, unfortunately. I hoped for a cool game, because it had much potential imo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011832156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1457290854}
review:
~~My first review~~ 
 Let me first explain my negative review. Ultimately, I wouldn't recommend this game to myself. Rather, I would recommend Dustforce to masochists, personal enemies, and professional platform gamers.

 I really wanted to like Dustforce. The promo videos made it seem like one casually 'ninjas' and floats about beautiful 16 bit levels collecting cobwebs like Sonic collects rings. Not quite. 

The concept itself is interesting. The goal is to travel through obstical courses as fast as possible. Along the way, you must run through patches of dust and hit "enemies" in order to clear the level. This is a 2D speed-running game. 

 The physics and mechanics make absolutely no sense to the uninitiated casual game playing plebian like myself. It can be frustrating, repetative and time consuming simply jumping from platform to platform in the overworld. This is where you wander around finding doors to unlock, which represent individual levels. 

Compare with titles like Super Meat Boy and Cave Story. These games present challenging and interesting game play, while having control schemes and movement that are predictable and intuitive. Dustforce DX creates simple levels, that are made challenging by a character that is difficult to control. Essentially, they took a relatively simple concept and made it difficult to enjoy on account of sloppy, tendinitis aggravating controls that are frustrating to learn and maddening to master.

 Further, the actual levels are fairly uninteresting and easy to get through. The challenge is that in order to properly complete a level, simply getting through it is not enough. You need to get the fastest time possible without missing any dust. This means repeating levels until you have every move perfected. This ends up being more busy work than anything else. You could easily spend a thousand hours trying to perfect each level. Combined with controls that assault your hands, it can be a very unforgiving process of which I quickly grew tired. 

I suppose in the Genre of repetitive games which slap you around and demand perfection it succeeds. However, I guess I'm not a fan of games where developers decided the best way to make a game challenging is to make the character barely controllable. I feel like back in the days of original 8 bit graphic platformers, this would simply be called bad controls and it would be relegated to 2 and 3 star reviews. These days there are gamers who specifically enjoy and excel at games with lousy controls, and I suspect if you're one of those people you will find a lot of fun in spending countless hours punishing yourself on Dustforce.  

Recall the viral flash game where the object is to control a sprinters limbs to push him over the finish line, or rather see how far you can comically stumble and hobble across a track. This is the same concept taken to it's inevitable extreme... 

OK, it's not THAT bad, but you'll be spending a half hour trying to jump onto a ledge just to get to another stage... only to discover that you don't have the key to unlock it. Oh right, keys. 

In order to unlock all the levels, you will need to complete the stages with perfect scores to accumulate keys. Ugh. 

Summary; 
If you are considering using the standard keyboard layout, either get an ice pack for your hands or forget about it. The game is barely playable on a game-pad, which is far superior to the keyboard controls. 

If you're a demi-god with spaghetti fingers and the ability to pick up outrageous controls, and have a lot of time and patience, I guess you will LOVE this game. 

If you're a casual gamer who likes simple controls, and doesn't want to invest the hours it will take to teach your hands to waltz like noodles through endlessly repetitive levels of dust ninja then get Super Meat Boy instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036265621', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1181, 'last_played': 1457645701}
review:
Un piccolo gioiello di platform, davvero ben costruito ed estremamente difficile. Certo non avr√† il level design o le meccaniche innovative di un Rayman o di un Super Mario; ma se state cercando un titolo molto frenetico e che richiede la massima concentrazione per essere portato a termine, Dustforce sar√† pane per i vostri denti. Allo strepitoso stile artistico che contraddistingue la produzione troviamo abbinata una soundtrack veramente sublime e perfettamente incastonata nel tipo di esperienza che il team di sviluppatori ha, credo, voluto proporre. Un titolo veramente imperdibile per gli amanti del genere e caldamente consigliato a chiunque voglia mettere alla prova le proprie abilit√†!

E' un bel gioco, corri a comprarlo... avanti... non rompere i ********!

At first this might look like a game with wonky movements, weird mechanics and physics... and it is, but thats the beauty of this game!

Its unique gameplay forces you onto learning new ways to progress through the "Main Nexus" levels and when you come to the point where getting double SS scores comes just like a walk in the park, the game feels even more satisfying and rewarding.

Can't say much about the multiplayer portion of the game because I never played, but I sure recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039024098', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1604794516}
review:
For this review I'll split up the different aspects of the game into categories and then provide my final thoughts. At this point I've played Dust Force DX for 6 hours, ands have completed all of the default levels, bronze levels, and all of the silver and gold levels of the first area with double S rank.

Story:
You're not buying this game for the story. There is a minor one conveyed through a single opening cinematic.

Music and Art:
Both are done in a very simplistic style. The art isn't something that will blow you away. It adds to the atmosphere of the game, and doesn't make it difficult to tell where the environment ends and where you are. The music is very peaceful. It will keep you playing, keep you interested in the game, and keep you from hating yourself. There is really something very peaceful and soothing about the soundtrack and did a lot to help the game. Great music.

Controls:
The controls take a little bit to get used to, but once you understand them they are very easy to use. They usually make you feel like it's you're fault for failing, which is what you want. I say usally because there have been a few times when it was their flaw and not mine. I would press one direction and the game wouldn't pick up on it, and it would cost me the level. Other than a few isolated incidents they've worked exactly as I've expected them to.

Mechanics:
Every mechanic that you use in the game is given to you the second the game is booted up. It's is your responsibility to master them and force them to do what you want. This is a plus in my book. I love games with few movement options that I can learn and perfect.

Difficulty:
It's a hard game. It is more difficult than any other ultra hard platformer I have ever played. It sometimes becomes infuriatingly tedious and makes me want to stop playing, but there is a significant sense of gratification when you complete a challenge that tells you to keep going. However, I don't think that this is a game anyone can play and achieve a double S rank on every level. I know that there are level that I will never be able to beat simply because my hands aren't fast or precise enough. I'm not sure any amount of practicing will ever allow me to get that good.

Final thoughts:
It's a really good game. It's very difficult and infuriating, but I still enjoy it. Even though I don't think I will be able to beat the final gauntlet of levels I'm still motivated to try. I cannot reccomend it enough to anyone who is a fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090190097', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1543767904}
review:
My first review, so don't expect a good one.

This game is only ment for the people who enjoy parcour/speedrunning, otherwise i WON'T recommend it because it's very hard. I may not have alot of hours on it but believe me i'ts worth your while.

+ It's a beautifull game and the gameplay is very smooth
+ Once you get the hang of it is very addictive
+ It's on sale.

- The game is very hard the first 30 min. I found myself as a good 2D platformer stuck at the tutorial for a good 20 min.
- The first levels are not easy and the game expect you to be good at it after the tutorial.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087097446', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1420248429}
review: Fast paced platformer, I can see how some people would find it fun, but this just isn't my thing. It's very much speedrunning the same levels over and over for faster times.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982697323', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1456101503}
review: I'll be honest. I bought the game purely for the soundtrack. It was on sale so worth it. The game is not bad though. There was enough for me to play an hour without feeling like a try hard. Dont get me wrong, I did beat the "i wanna be the guy" levels in super meat boy, but this game doesnt make me want to go to that level. Anyway, thank you Terence Lee for the awesome soundtrack!

author: {'steamid': '76561198101658990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 28, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1710753889}
review: I'm not very great at this game, but have had many enjoyable plays. There's a rythym that just clicks and when it does, its very rewarding. Kind of an Ollie Ollie vibe, or a skating game, mixed with Meatboy twitch. Lot of praise, if you don't mind your kid schooling you on how easy it is for them. 5 stars, minus a few points for personal initial control setup, other than that, this game is a gem. Relaxing, but once you get the hang, it will push you to want to get better. The soundtrack is probably my favorite on Steam. Great job!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017583814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3186, 'last_played': 1629163937}
review:
This game is awesome.  Hitbox designed this game to be smoother than a baby's bottom.  And as a plus they got Lifeformed to do their BGM (who basically made a fantatic album for this game).
I don't %100 think a controller is best, I'd recommend just sticking to the keyboard.

Oh, and did I say they're making another?

author: {'steamid': '76561198108178099', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1470101261}
review:
This game is the embodiement of "huh. I did ok. But I can do better."

Its kinda like a sandbox platformer. The game provides basic tools, which can be combined and utilized in dozens of ways, which becomes hundreds when combined with the game's physics. Its not a generic platformer, because there's never just one way to finish a level. It allows for a ton of creativity. Also obligatory comment about how good this soundtrack is. (Its great).

author: {'steamid': '76561198041063398', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1455756987}
review:
Date: 2/17/16
Review Number: 18
Game: Dustforce DX
From (Creator Publisher): Hitbox Team
Played On: Steambox (w/ Controller)
Steam Price as of Review: $9.99
Total Time played: 30 Minutes
Review:

Another day, another review from the wheel of insanity.  This time the randomizer brought up Dustforce DX, a platformer from Hitbox Team which apparently is about four people dealing with janitorial work as an art form.  Now, I am always down for unique and interesting takes on new games and all, but for some reason the idea of having your characters doing what they do because they want to keep the floors obsessive clear of leaves just seems a bit off even to me.  It doesn‚Äôt really get too much in the way of gameplay though, and that, surprisingly, is quite interesting, the controls are quite simple once you get into the swing of finding exactly when to dash jump and double jump.  The engine uses a surprisingly robust set of physics rules to control the player's movement, and i could easily see someone trying to spend a lot of time trying to really dig into the specifics of the movement of the characters.  In truth, I think this is the sort of platformer that would appeal to perfectionist platformers, both for the almost OCD nature of its story, to the demanding requirements of the level ranking systems.  For folks who love that sort of thing, this is a definite buy.  For everyone else, it‚Äôs still pretty good, and probably worth keeping on a wishlist for the next sale.

Game‚Äôs Fate: Uninstalled.  Its pretty, but just isn‚Äôt interesting enough for me to enjoy, but I can see where plenty of people would enjoy it.
Buy/No Buy: There's nothing wrong with this game, but it‚Äôs just not interesting enough to me to be worth the full price.  Keep in your wishlist and buy it when it‚Äôs on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040665586', 'num_games_owned': 1003, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1454929028}
review: This game is an afront to phisics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043805204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1454809170}
review:
I did not know what to expect when I started this game. But I can say that I was pleasantly surprised. Within Dustforce DX is some of the most precise, well-constructed 2D platforming that you can experience. Its unique concept and fair set-up allows you to enjoy the game, no matter what your skill level. This is especially true provided the time and score system. 

If I were to provide a negative quirk, it would be the key system and hub which is not entirely user-friendly, and does become a bit of a hassle when transversing from stage-to-stage. Otherwise, it is a fun experience and I would recommend it for anyone who enjoys a challenging 2D platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057903640', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1816, 'last_played': 1478926069}
review:
One of the tightest controls in a game that I've ever played.
Momemtum platformer that's all about being the most precise at cleaning up leaves, dust, trash, and slime.
Amazing sound track aimed to calm the players played at a continuous loop that never stops to remind the players how poorly they had performed.
Fair scoreboard with watchable replays that teaches newcomers how to play and veterans how to improve.
That Double S+ achievement though...
So far away...

author: {'steamid': '76561197970602587', 'num_games_owned': 6364, 'num_reviews': 3660, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1454386341}
review:
https://youtu.be/gKrXAVdyGCQ

In Dustforce you play as a very acrobatic ninja like janitor going from level to level freeing animals from clouds of leaves and clean up everything along the way.

The lack of native controller support is rough but can be rebound which makes the gameplay feel more natural.  The concept and movement animations for this game are great with strong level design.

However much of that is marred by finicky rules for how movement actions are allowed.  The uncertainty of when you have a double jump or not makes the platforming more frustrating than fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052764877', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1457415080}
review: I have not played very much of this game, but I can already tell that completionists/perfectionists who enjoy 2d platforming games will find this a worthy challenge. I wish it had better controller support or multiple key binding options, but this is a minor sticking point. The soundtrack is fantastic and the art style is quite lovely. And if you are worried about replayability or amount of content, do not fret: the level editor and community content extend potential playtime beyond the numerous levels in the main game. I can see myself playing quite a lot of this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998598944', 'num_games_owned': 2056, 'num_reviews': 1144, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1454182270}
review:
No matter how many times I try to get into this game, I still can't get over the fact that the controls are ALMOST good, and the fact that I'm sweeping up leaves.

It' not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032418520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 20218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2243, 'last_played': 1556067846}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041642963', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1646597477}
review: An extremely challenging platformer (if you go for S-rank, which you should), that results in this massive sense of satisfaction and fulfillment. Superb aesthetic and audio, as can be seen in the trailer, and when you finally manage to do an S-rank level, you move with a sort of beautiful flow and skill you would normally only find if you were watching a speedrun, except it's you doing it. Perhaps this is because time is part of the S-rank, practically making getting an S-rank speedrunning and dulling the game for regular speedrunners, but it was a first for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119057120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 264, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1453028004}
review:
I remember running this game as a background process just to have card drops.

This is a decent platformer as is, but it's just not my cup of tea. Music is pleasant, jumping is ok, but it all just feels empty to me.

I can't recommend something that I don't like to play, but take a look at some gameplay videos over the Internet and decide for yourself if it fits your preferences.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072270271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 101970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76975, 'last_played': 1652896680}
review:
I should have written a review long ago.  After all, I've played this game for 1,000+ hours and idle'd in its level editor for a few hundred more.

Dustforce DX is the deepest and most technically demanding 2D platformer ever made.  It has a momentum based engine where all actions have real weight and consequence, attacks have start-up frames, things are jump and dash-cancellable, and there are tricks measured in how many frames they save.  Every level has leaderboards both for score and for raw time, and the community is fiercly competitive and still very active.  More importantly, every run on the leaderboards also has a replay embedded.  Being able to watch your run (or anyone else's) is not just fun, it's a fantastic learning tool.  If that sounds like something you'd enjoy, then keep reading.

Dustforce DX will never hold the player's hand.  Several people ragequit the third TUTORIAL, and a wide number of the advanced mechanics and workings of the game are never explained in-game.  To really master this game and understand everything in it, you need to know other people who play it and/or engage on the subreddit and IRC channel.  Even if you do that and arm yourself with knowledge: this game is HARD.  When you think you've finally gotten good and beaten the game, you have only just begun because you unlocked "The Difficults".  Honestly even getting that far is going to take you a hundred hours at least, because the only way to unlock new levels is to complete easier levels perfectly.  I'll explain...

Dustforce DX has 4 main hub areas of one large world (The Nexus).  Each hub has 4 baby levels, 4 easy levels, 4 medium levels, and 4 exceedingly hard levels.  Each tier of level above the first is locked by a key, and you earn progress toward keys by playing the levels in the tier below.  But the only way to get a full key from 1 single level is to get an SS rank.  One S is completion: for cleaning all the dust and defeating all the enemies.  The other S is Finesse: for never losing your combo from dying, getting hit, or letting it time out.  The game doesn't just reward perfection, it demands it if you even want to see all the stock levels.

Now why did I say stock levels you may ask?  That's because the true magic of this game is its INTENSELY POWERFUL level editor.  Custom Dustforce Maps (it calls them maps instead of levels) are what keep me playing.  This is one of several games where the editor gives you every tool the dev had, letting you make stuff on par with, and often exceeding, the quality of the stock game.  You have 20 layers to work with, tons of cool props, almost complete RGB color control and control over the %blend of the color PER LAYER, a shit ton of props and emitters to place, several things with transparency for awesome effects, and total control over the music and sound effects at every point.  The last sentence is very important since this game has a truly amazing soundtrack.  Free control over the music in the editor doubles as a sound test, even if you don't enjoy making maps.  The nice thing about the leaderboards and replays is that you can watch everyone playing your map once you publish it.  That adds another level of enjoyment to the process, a feature missing from several other games with level editors.

There are almost no restrictions on what you can place anywhere, allowing the free mixing of themes from the 4 hubs if you have the skill to make it work.  The game is easily moddable and the community has several killer spritemods available, one even turns a character into Kirby!  There are several different classes of mods both for art and for performance, and they are all easy enough to find on the subreddit.  Sadly they aren't integrated into Steam like with many other games.  The community also has several third party tools available for more detailed stat-tracking, new kinds of competition, and even a cool TAS community.

In conclusion, Dustforce DX is a great game and one of my all time favorites.  It's not easy to get into: indeed you will struggle if you go it alone and it's still very difficult even with friends beside you.  You'll get what you put into it.  We still learn things about this game every week; the engine is just that deep.  A lot of the quirks in this game are things you just won't find anywhere else.  When I say that there's no 2D platformer with the complexity of Dustforce... I mean it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028769894', 'num_games_owned': 1806, 'num_reviews': 264, 'playtime_forever': 4570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4402, 'last_played': 1493925503}
review:
Dustforce is a really smooth platform game, with a big focus on stylish and fast ways to clear the levels. With an included level editor, and leaderboards available for all levels ever uploaded- it becomes a very competetive experience, especially since you can watch every (!) player's replay in-game. 
You can try to redo their runs and improve upon them- to climb the leaderboards, and feel like the king of the big internet arcade.

The game itself is very challenging, but selfexplanatory and easy to learn. The progress you make as a player is always clearly visible and definitely satisfying. If you want online challenges- there's plenty available; if you want to play just for yourself- there are medals at the end of each level, to reward you with a bit of singleplayer experience.

It's big, fun, and sometimes frustrating to play; but even if you can't get very far- there is always the great artstyle to gaze upon, and chill soundtrack to soothe your nerves (not to mention level editor, where you can make your own kind of experience).

I love this game and I definitely recommend it; but it's hard for me to tell whether I like the game better, or just it's beautiful soundtrack (STRONGLY ADVISED TO PLAY THE TRAILER).

author: {'steamid': '76561198047105025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 16730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1641890343}
review: IMO feels a little similar to Super Meat Boy. They both have tight controls, precise jumping and timing is required, and very nice soundtracks. At first, the controls felt a little awkward but with some investment you'll find that you can do some very complex movements with ease and you'll be rewarded with seeing dust trails cleanly disapear under your feet. I would highly recommend Dustforce if you're into hard 2d platformers  and don't mind a bit of a learning curve.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996910394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1333, 'last_played': 1420152064}
review: This is a game with emphasis on tight controls and complex movements, and it delivers. Tons of levels with a nice level variety from short, dense obstacles to lengthy gauntlets, all with gradually building difficulty. And, with the addition of the DX levels, some stages test your ability to perform tricky and nuanced maneuvers. If you want a platformer with a steady learning curve and a high skill ceiling, this is definitely worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050449764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1457685197}
review:
Ich habe dieses Spiel w√§hrend eines Sales f√ºr ca. 3‚Ç¨ inklusive Soundtrack erstanden.
Das Spiel an sich ist ein Spa√üiges Jump and Run mit ein paar extra kniffen hier und da.
Im Grunde allerdings nicht f√ºr mich, 
ich komme mit den Grunds√§tzlichen Mechaniken wie dem Springen nicht wirklich klar.
Es f√ºhlt sich alles etwas schwammig an, noch dazu hat dieses Spiel zwar Controller Support,
jedoch muss man im Men√º selbst die Kn√∂pfe den Aktionen zuweisen!
Das h√§tte ich mit einem Controller Tool auch extern gekonnt,
zus√§tzlich kann man in diesem Men√º nicht mal Start und Select mit z.b dem Men√º und dem schnellen Neustart belegen.
Mehr kann ich an diesem Punkt noch nicht wirklich sagen und ich werde das Spiel wohl auch nicht weiter Spielen.

Im punkto Soundtrack m√∂chte ich allerdings noch etwas sagen, denn der hat mich an diesem Spiel gereizt!
Im Spiele Ordner selbst gibt es unter content/audio/music alle Lieder in voller L√§nge zu h√∂ren, anbei eine Readme Datei.
In dieser Readme steht Zitat: 
"All the songs in the game are here" "The songs in the album are remastered and uncompressed, and have proper endings (the ones in this folder just end abruptly)." "There are also a few bonus tracks!  Also included are a nice insert tracklist image and liner notes."

Nun habe ich ja das Soundtrack Bundle gekauft und muss sagen... 
Ja da gibt es ein Bild mit der Tracklist und Notizen zu den einzelnen Liedern in einer Readme. 
Ansonsten ist das alles M√ºll was er in dieser Readme geschrieben hat!
Erst mal widersprich er sich selbst in dem er sagt, dass alle Lieder des Spiels hier zu finden sind und beim richtigen Soundtrack angeblich Extras dabei w√§hren.
In dem 'music' Ordner sind n√§mlich wirklich alle dabei und beim Soundtrack gibt es keinerlei Extra!
Noch dazu sind die Dateien im Album soweit ich das h√∂ren kann nur mit einem Hall Effekt o.√§ belegt worden und haben am Ende einen 'fade out' Effekt bekommen wo es bei den Liedern im 'music' Ordner einfach endet.
Wirklich remastered sind sie also nicht, ein richtiges Ende w√ºrde ich das auch nicht nennen und uncompressed?
Auf dem Album sind die Lieder deutlich kleiner vom Format und in .mp3, im music Ordner sind sie im .ogg Format und entsprechend deutlich besser.

Jetzt kann ich das Ganze leider nun wirklich nicht verstehen, die Lieder sind gut, ich mag sie wirklich gerne!
Nur wirkt es hier als h√§tte sich jemand so √ºberhaupt keine M√ºhe gegeben und will daf√ºr wohl auch noch Geld,
da er ja f√ºr das Album wirbt!
Die Lieder scheinen gar kein Ende zu haben, 
da sie immer mit demselben 'fade out' Enden und im 'music' Ordner einfach so abgehackt werden.
Die Readme scheint einen Schlichtweg verarschen und zum Kauf √ºberreden zu wollen.

Fazit:
Das Spiel ist nicht meins, trotzdem w√ºrde ich es weiter empfehlen weil ich denke,
dass es echt Spa√ü machen kann, sobald man sich etwas rein gefuchst hat.
Die Sache mit dem Soundtrack ist einfach nur dreist und unverst√§ndlich, 
ich w√ºrde den Kauf vom Soundtrack nicht empfehlen, da k√∂nnt Ihr euch die Lieder auch aus dem 'music' Ordner holen.
Ansonsten ein interessantes Jump and Run f√ºr jeden der es mag!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044481135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1558737540}
review:
Regretted buying this game for the first two hours because I sucked and it was hard. Unlocking levels is unique and kind of frustrating at first. Super fun and great soundtrack. If you're relatively unexperienced in platformers like I was you will find some of the other levels very challenging to beat!

I bought it on sale for $2.74 but the game is probably worth the full $11 if you're into platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971560590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1451682051}
review:
Picked this up on the Steam sale, but I can't recommend it. The default control scheme is pretty terrible, and enabling xbox controller support doesn't make it any better. There are too many nuances to the controls that you have to master, making some of the jumps pretty annoying.

I loved the art style and the music is neat, however. Too bad terrible controls ruin the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060604297', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 7058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6495, 'last_played': 1596919537}
review: Truly a classic in my own mind. I greatly enjoyed playing some of the hardest levels on repeat for days, trying to nail the mechanics to the best of my ability. If you enjoy perfecting a run of a level in a platforming game, this one is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004145760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 2520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2419, 'last_played': 1451601273}
review: Certainly one of the most challenging games I've ever played. When you spend 2+ hours on one level you really have to think how good this game is. It wasn't super frustrating each time I died either. I just looked forward to getting better at the challenges. I didn't do the difficult levels (after all 16 super keys were collected). Maybe one day I'll have the time for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044278207', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1501841417}
review:
Pros: Absolutely gorgeous sound track, addicting gameplay, many creative levels that require unique and complicated platforming mechanics.

Cons: Absolute worst platformer game controls I have ever played on steam. The animations look cool, but they induce a huge latency that should not be present in a competitive timed platformer. Difficulty in a platformer should come from the complicated mechanics within the level (which this game ALMOST achieves). Difficulty should not come from the ability of the user to overcome shitty controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983732894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1514727051}
review:

review:

This game is a bit unorthodox to control but when you get the hang of momentum, it's great. It's a challenge waiting to be conquered, and the leaderboards lend themselves to helping you get better at the game. The level editing community never ceases to amaze, but even the vanilla levels look great. Highly recommend.

review:
Dustforce es un juego muy t√©cnico, un plataformas exigente. A partir de cierto nivel el avanzar a la primera se vuelve complicado invit√°ndo al jugador a repetir varias veces una fase para poder seguir avanzando. Esto se consigue en forma de llaves que se obtienen al completar cada uno de los niveles. 
Pero hasta que se llega al punto de prueba-error el juego es de lo mejorcito del g√©nero con con un control exigente pero fiable. 
Este es otro de esos juegos con una BSO de esc√°ndalo.

Coste: 0,28 eur.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989236581', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1440011820}
review:
When I discovered this game, i didn't expect it to have such great level design, tight controls, immense gameplay depth, amazing soundtrack and player freedom expression.

I also didn't expect it to be so hard.

This games follows in the shadow of other recent 2D platformers that makes their focus on beating tough as nails levels as fast as you can, like Super Meat Boy, Velocity or VVVVVV.

Personally I have always been drawn to games like this, ever since I first played Sonic the Hedgehog when I was just 4 years old.
As far as 2D platformers where the goal is to reach the finish line as fast as you can goes, this one stands out at the top of the list. It's no surprise, since the game clearly caters to the speedrunning community.
By that, I mean that it is possible to beat levels in less than a minute, without stoping or dealing with enemies, and the feeling is fantastic.
On the other hand, the game provides some moves that only expert players will learn because the game does not teach them to the players anywere in the game, but pulling it off in the long run makes you feel like a beast.

And that is my problem recommending it. It's definitely not a game for everyone. 
Only the most persistent and skilled will reach the end of the game, and only a few dozens of players will beat the game 100%.

But for me that is the beauty of it. The game has no story, it expects you only to get good at the game, and the most positive thing, is that it feels outstanding getting good at the game.

Also, play it for the music alone. It's god tier

author: {'steamid': '76561198086917932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1585104987}
review:
What a great addition to the platformer genre. Dustforce is an indie action platformer from Hitbox Team. Let‚Äôs get rocking.

The Good

I love platformers and Dustforce made me remember why I love platformers. Everything about this game is well done and polished until it shines.

First thing first, you‚Äôll be hard pressed to find another game with as good a soundtrack as the one that accompanies Dustforce. It is pure, relaxing majesty and nothing could possibly fit this game better in terms of music. It makes you feel good while you play.



The art is phenomenal. Character designs are simple and beautiful, enemies are original, and the environments themselves will provide you with a good eyeful as well.

The controls are smooth and fluid. You can easily transition from floors to ceilings in a matter of seconds, all the while cleaning the living hell out of dust ridden creatures and persons. Dustforce is, essentially, 2D parkour and I love it.

There are a huge amount of levels for you to play through with four different characters, all of whom have their own play style. Not only does the core game have over 100 levels, but there are a heaping amount of user created levels that you can play through as well. The fun doesn‚Äôt have to end with this one, ever.

The Bad

Nothing. Nothing at all my friends.

The Meh

See the above category, please.

Verdict: Yea

Dustforce is a lighthearted, refreshing platformer that serious and casual gamers alike can enjoy at their leisure. If you‚Äôre looking for something new to play, look no further. As always, thanks for reading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057219226', 'num_games_owned': 1368, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 2657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2653, 'last_played': 1453657255}
review:
This one is great. Truelly a new gen platformer classic like Super Meat Boy.

You can play "casually" and try to unlock every level or you can get familiar with levels and climb your way up to leaderboards. Both ways are fun but the later one is where the game really shines. The feeling of actually nailing that difficult run, incomparable.

The movement and responsiveness of the characters is one of best ones ever seen in games. All that goes wrong is fault of the player. Using keyboard is strongly adviced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064593541', 'num_games_owned': 1065, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4053, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3973, 'last_played': 1499138573}
review: This game was made for speed running.  It's about challenging yourself to complete a level as quickly and efficiently as possible.  The community and the competition are really what make this game great.  Apple% runs are one of my favorite passtimes to do with my friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033605026', 'num_games_owned': 1379, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1445366680}
review:
TLDR; Supermeatboy ftw.

I have played a few more hours than shows here.  Not that many more though... 

I really love the idea of this game. I wish I would like it. In the end it comes down mostly to control responsiveness.

Even the simplest jumps feel hard to accomplish, movement feels jerky and if you miss a wallrun edge by a pixel the outcome is completely different and unexpected. I guess you can get used to it and "get good", but in this day and age there are so many games that do this right and feel natural, responsive and tight from the get-go while still having a crazy high skill ceiling. Supermeatboy: I'm looking at you and blowing a kiss.

Because of this little mistakes completely ruin your runs. Maybe it's by design, but I don't like it. I feel little mistakes should screw you a little and big mistakes screw you a lot. 

Controller support exists (I play using an xbox360 controller), but it still feels funny. Some commands register on soft presses while others require full presses...

Ah and the game's pacing: While it demands big apm spikes there's more focus on precision and routing than hectic speed. So it feels weird: sluggish, complex and puzzling, kinda like that weirdly chosen soothing new age soundtrack. 

Few games can make me yawn and get frustrated at the same time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028286344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1551617961}
review: The only flaw with this game is they never made the "bosses" playable. I understand no boss fights (even though they could have made a "trail your shadow" stage that is done on some other games and would essentially just be a regular stage with a theme), but I don't understand designing them and the stages after them, and then programming them as replica antagonists of the main characters and then never doing anything with it. Feels like they had this weird backstory idea, left it all over the game and then tried their hardest to pretend it doesn't exist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 602, 'playtime_forever': 3503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3357, 'last_played': 1490945341}
review: A great platformer, but lives somewhat in the shadows of the likes of Super Meat Boy, which is a shame. Instead of just going from point A to point B, here you must travel and clean dust along the levels, while being consistent to not lose your combo. Each level can be beaten "normally", but only by getting SS rank on them you'll unlock keys to be able to unlock harder levels. Speaking of difficulty, the controls are a bit clunky and hard to get used at first, but soon you'll get better at basic movement which will allow you to clear the easy levels, while getting better to beat the normal levels, and with enough practice you'll be able to beat the hard levels. And this progression works well, because when you unlock the hard levels it means that you are ready for them. And once you beat the hard levels, you'll unlock the hardest levels, which are easily harder than Super Meat Boy (even some hard levels are). You'll also fail a lot, but there's some things that will keep you invested: the art and music are great, and a checkpoint system that will allow you to practice sections of a level instead of starting from the beginning every time. There's also 4 characters, and they feel different from each other. Also, the developers keep the leaderboards clean from cheaters, which is something rare. Lastly there are plenty of easter eggs to find, and only one precious achievement, but getting it displays true skill. And there's plenty of custom levels included for extra gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075658818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1446332993}
review: A very entertaining platformer in which you clean up all the dust, leaves, trash, or what have you in a veriety of different levels and location. You recieve a rating based on your competion of cleaning all the mess strewn across the level, as well as the finess you put into it. A the platforming feels really good if you can get into a rhythem, which can be difficult as many of the levels have only one intended path of completion and if you get off the path it can be difficult to get back on it. There are a number of enemies in the game which are all things covered in whatever grime coats the level and to defeat them you clean them off by hitting them with your cleaning tools. Its very fun to try to see how fast you can do a level, but its another one of those games where it doesnt matter how much you play, you'll be lucky if your place on the score board is anywhere lower than the sextuple digits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993530064', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1440883746}
review:
Nice game, seems perfect for speedruns, but I'm not a speedrunner, so I can't go into details on that front, but I can still do a list!

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Awesome Soundtrack

[*]Smooth Animations

[*]Addictive as fuck

[*]It's pretty beautiful.

[*]Easy to leanr hard to master. (In the sense, that it's easy to get the controls down, but hard to get double S everywhere)
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Shitty controls for controllers: Have to press two buttons on the digital pad to run on the wall/ceiling which even have the same combination of buttons to use them and I can't imagine that it's better with the analogue stick. Which sucks when you get to a spot where both moves are possible. (You usually get the move you didn't want to use) The other buttons are fine.
[*]Sometimes when you kill an enemy you can't jump again, even though it's a feature of the game and even get's explained in the tutorial. (Might be something wrong on my end, but I dunno. I can just tell what happened to me)
[*]Sometimes my character breaks in midair without my input to do so. (Might have a common cause with my jump problem in the last con)
[/list]
Neutral:
[list]
[*]This game is so fucking frustrating, that it's fun... And frustrating.... But in a fun way... but still frustrating.
[/list]

(Didn't test multiplayer yet, but I think it might be kinda nice)

author: {'steamid': '76561198163676958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1610183837}
review:
Dustforce, a very progressive platformer where stage design takes the spotlight. The mechanics are simple and elegant, yet hard to master. With a huge influence from games like Megaman X and the Physics feel like wave dashing from smash bros. melee I dont know how a classic gamer could go wrong with it. 

Difficulty curve is intimidating, I could not finish every stage. I did seem to understand a deeper level of gameplay, but I didn't care for some of the aggressive stages. I found it most relaxing trying to beat my previous times in the medium difficulty stages. 

This game does require patience and willingness to try new things. But this is how games should be.
7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198103033403', 'num_games_owned': 1906, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1437134205}
review:
Dustforce is‚Ä¶Dustforce is a fast paced, terribly difficult, hair pulling infuriating platformer, and I love it. I hate it, but I love it. 

You‚Äôre part of the Dustforce, charged with ridding the world from‚Ä¶ dust! Go figure, right? I had my reservations about it at first, but as it turns out, it‚Äôs a really fun platformer game. The gameplay is simple (and the keyboard controls are simple, too), yet at the same time, complicated. You clean this dust by simply touching it or smacking dusty creatures. You have jumps, double jumps, dashes, normal hit, hard hit, and a few wall and ceiling grabbing skills depending on key combinations used. This requires plenty of skills, because while you‚Äôre essentially only using like 3-4 buttons at most, you have to do so in a specific order with a specific timing in order to reach certain ledges/floors/areas. And this, my friends, is where it gets difficult. 

The levels are progressively difficult, requiring you to hone your button-pressing order/timing skills in order to complete them. While you don‚Äôt have to mop away every single trace of dust, you -are- graded at the end according to your performance, and you will need the keys awarded from this to unlock certain levels. The better you do, the easier to unlock those levels. There‚Äôs only one achievement for the game (which made me lol a little). 

The graphics are very nice and simple, they make the game stand out and seem pretty unique, and I really loved it. The character moves around the screen with pretty amazing fluidity, and I just love to see them dash and jump and double jump, and do all kinds of parkour-y things. 

Dustforce also has a level editor for you to play around in and fiddle to your heart‚Äôs content, and you‚Äôre able to share your levels with other users. 

If you‚Äôre a fan of platformers and/or difficult games, I really recommend it! 
If you‚Äôre not, steer clear, it‚Äôs bound to drive you insane!

review:

Thank you HItbox Team for this masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069398991', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1595463669}
review:
This is a game about ninja janitors. 

No wait, come back! 

It's not as weird as it sounds!

So as weird as this game sounds, it's actually a beautiful and fun game. It seems simple on the surface, but you'll sink hours into it slowly improving at levels. You play as a graceful janitor who can jump from platform to platform with ease. You have to strategically use air jumps, light/strong attacks, wall runs, and dashes to clean up a level (or just make it to the end) as fast as possible. You have to carefully pick which character to use on a level, as each of the 4 characters is distinctly different and has different strengths and weaknesses. Overall this makes for a seemingly simple yet actually complex game you can sink hours into getting better at. And to top it all off, the graphics and music are beautiful (see the trailers for proof). This has slowly become one of my all-time favorite games, and if anything I've said or anything you've seen interests you at all, I recommend this game.
