author: {'steamid': '76561197966716250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3125, 'last_played': 1644904485}
review:
I do like this game, but I have a lot of trouble recommending it to anyone. The decisions the developer made here seem actively antagonistic to new players. I would have to link the game along with 3-4 different guides just to make sure whoever I recommended it to had a decent chance of enjoying it. If you have all the information it really is quite good. It's just that the game never bothers to give you the information you need in order to enjoy it.

Here are the things wrong with this game.

1) The tutorial is too hard. Instead of spreading the 3 tutorial levels out over time the game requires you to be able to execute even the advanced mechanics right from the beginning. I imagine some casual players may not even be able to complete these 3 tutorial levels. These levels also lack any kind of flow, and so they're also just bad levels in general.

2) The tutorial is too short. The tutorial doesn't explain some very key movement mechanics that are profoundly unintuitive to the point that they are literally the opposite of reality. There's a hidden "charge" system the game never explains that allows you to either dash or jump in mid-air. Not all of the cases where the recharges happen are explained and so the player is left without enough information to even begin to tackle anything past the first 15 courses. The player is forced to look up a guide online or spend a lot of time randomly button mashing in order to progress.

3) The "overworld" is dumb and confusing. Instead of the devs bothering to figure out which order the levels should be in the game has you exploring these 4 zones between the worlds in order to find new levels. Sometimes this requires executing extraordinarily difficult platforming tricks as well as a key obtained from doing really well on previous levels. The layout of this zone is very confusing, and it is very very very very very frustrating having to deal with a dumb mini-game just to get to the next course. The courses are hard enough on their own. I already did well enough on the courses in order to get the key. Just let me pick them from a menu, and don't lock content behind meaningless redundant skill gates you didn't think through properly before you implemented. It's very easy to get stuck.

4) Keys aren't explained. The game doesn't explain adequately how to obtain keys. This leads to being stuck until you look up a guide online that explains how to get more keys. 

5) Key colors are difficult to differentiate. I'm a little bit color-blind. The game has like 5 key colors. I can only differentiate between silver and "the rest of them." They bothered to make the key icons look different, but not the locks. So good luck being able to figure out where to take a key you just obtained because a) the lock colors are all very similar and b) you might not even be able to get there due to point #3.

6) Character differences are not explained.  2 of them are quite similar while the other 2 are quite different from all others. It would have been nice to have been told by the game why I should ever choose a different character than the default.

In conclusion, I do like this game, but don't be afraid to look up guides on how the mechanics of the game work. It's really not fun if you don't do that.

I also want to reiterate again that the entire concept of The Nexus feels very much like the dev fell in love with their own "clever" idea, and never bothered to think through the ramifications of what they were doing. I'm sure it took a lot of time to build and design, but it only ever serves to frustrate and impede player progress to new courses. Just save yourself the trouble and look up a YouTube video that shows how to navigate to all the courses along with a map of door lock colors. You will have a much better time of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142333574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1438211558}
review:
It's a shame. I really enjoyed watching speedruns of Dustforce. I had high hopes that I'd be able to do the same stunts that several of the top players displayed in various playthroughs. Unfortunately, this game has ultimately taught me the difference between watching videos of Dustforce and physically playing Dustforce.

+Pros: Beautiful music (very relaxing!) and art. Fun to watch. Competitive for the speedrunning community. High replay value*
-Cons: Stiff controls, hard to master even after brushing and practicing the tutorial several times, confusing hub world, definitely not worth the $9.99 price tag.

Summary:
While the gameplay looks impressive, the controls are extremely stiff and difficult to master (actions like jumping are delayed once the button is pressed, not immediate). After the tutorial, you'll have to perform the actions you just learned to enter a door that leads to a hub world; this took me a bunch of tries (I just wanted to play the game already!). There's no sense of direction in this hub world; I found myself entering harder levels earlier just because I was wandering around aimlessly. Without a sense of direction (especially on a first playthrough), casual players will find the difficulty going all over the place rather than easier--->harder levels. With an insanely steep learning curve and a non-linear flow of gameplay, I don't feel enticed to explore this game further after 5+ hours of trying to work with the game's mechanics.

*Because Dustforce drives players to complete levels as fast as possible, much of the core gameplay revolves around beating your personal best time. I've had some experience with speedrunning games and personally, I can't find enjoyment from trying to beat my times if I cannot enjoy the controls and core mechanics of the game first. Dustforce isn't something I can recommend to anyone unless they find entertainment in learning every inch of mechanic possible in this game through countless repitition and muscle memory

author: {'steamid': '76561198043346855', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 629, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1656746878}

author: {'steamid': '76561198153553219', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1437831988}
review:
It's clear the dev put a lot of effort into this game. It's a shame the controls are fiddly and unresponsive, which makes the platforming incredibly frustrating. I'm not the best gamer out there, by far, but I've been through Super Meat Boy, and come out battered, but not dead. So, why, oh why, do I find the first level so frustrating? 

Uncontrollable Sliding. It ruins the game for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082985782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1439004383}
review:
Who would have guessed: a 2D indie platformer can be challenging and difficult and yet be--gasp!--ENJOYABLE?! Considering there seems to be a trend for games that confuse challenge with stress and difficulty with laboriousness, this game is kind of a miracle.
For starters, it has a learning curve. Yes: an ACTUAL LEARNING CURVE. You have some brief tutorials to help you get the hang of the controls, with are fairly complex and prety tricky to get right, and soon you're in a "nexus" which you can traverse and unlock levels. These levels come in different difficulties, and you hve to beat a certain number of easier levels to get keys and unlock the harder ones.
As usual, the controls define about half of the playability and the fun of the game, and they work quite well here. It strikes a balance between fast, fluid, complex and challenging. Yes, it can get annoying and a little innaccurate at times, but those flaws seem to be more due to the natural limitations of keyboard controls rather than the game designers letting them suck deliberately because "that makes it HARD!!!". The only thing that does annoy me is how the gravity works: within a millisecond, you'll switch from "gently floating down" to "plummetting like a stone". I don't think this adds anything to the game.
The levels are good, and range from flowing and pleasant to devilishly hard. So far, I've played more than half of the levels, and only one was seriously beyond my skills. The others, at their most difficult, are reasonably doable. Also, you're not expected to simply reach the end of the level: the more dust you clean up, the higher your "Completion" rank goes up, and the higher the combo you get at the end, the higher your "Finesse" rank (it took me ages to understand what that meant). The higher your ranks, the sooner you get keys to unlock the harder levels. Also, if you're really perverted, you can try to improve your time and improve your rank in the scoreboard. If you like speedrunning, you'll have a field day.
Finally, I really enjoy the art style. The visuals are pretty, cartoony and slightly dreamy. The music is nice, and whomever wrote it did a pretty good job at imitating Tycho. Also, you get to choose from four different characters: the guy in blue, and... er... four others. (another gripe I have is that you have to choose your character EVERY TIME you start a level. Sheesh, why not choose once, at the beginning of the game, and let me change it later if I want to?)
I'm glad I got this game, and I'm glad for the time I spent on it. I still have quite a lot to play, but I'm already satisfied. Fans of platformers should definitely take notice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995640963', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1437479722}
review:
Pro:
1. Great soundtrack.
2. Clean, simplistic graphics.

Cons:
1. Controller support is bad, as game was seemingly designed with keyboard controls in mind. You need to literally press UP instead of slightly UP+LEFT or UP+RIGHT which usually is the result of a fluid D-Pad motion and as one has come to expect from 2D platformers.
2. There's a deliberate fuzziness to the controls and delay between inputs and response on screen.

If you're coming from SMB and alike and are expecting a challenging platformer with tight controls and actual progress with every new attempt, look somewhere else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159847093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3329, 'last_played': 1533693861}
review:
As a big platformer fan, I can say with great certainty that this is the best platformer I have ever played and I do not belive that will ever change. 
First of all, this game features a momentum mechanic which requires you to put in effort to go faster. You will not jump the same distance every time by pressing a key or two- you need to do things perfectly. That and the fact that you are ranked on your performance makes this a good game for perfectionists. 
It is also great for speedrunners- I became a fan of speedrunning when I played this game. 
Be prepared for challenging yourself! This is not an easy game, if you are a perfectionist, and many techniques are hard to master.
You will either spend way too much time playing this game or way too little. Go for the first one.

10/10. I never give 10s.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962165534', 'num_games_owned': 1742, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1435766408}
review:
Keyboard controls require exact precise movements to make jumps.  There's a lot of "momentum" movements, so it may feel floaty, but that's part of the game mechanic.  I thought I was pretty good at platformers, but this game shamed me.

Honestly, it's a pretty good platformer, however I don't think the average gamer would enjoy it, so this is a "No" unless you are a platforming expert.  It is EXTREMELY difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994397124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2398, 'last_played': 1416672880}
review:
If you can bear with the difficulty, this is one of the best platformers ever, period.
The controls are hard to master (more complex than in a game such as Super Meat Boy) but mastering them is very rewarding, you feel in complete control and able to accomplish incredible stunts.
Climbing, dusting and wallrunning have never been so much fun.

This is technically quite clean for an indie game, too. No annoying bugs I could notice, quality updates (with minor rebalancing), a level editor which I have not tried but seems to work great judging from the quantity of good maps around, a nice level portal for browsing and downloading these maps, a good replay and ranking system. I so wish Super Meat Boy got these implemented ! They make for an experience a fair notch better overall.

Keep an eye on Hitbox Team's upcoming game, Spire. If they get 3D platforming right as much as they did for 2D platforming, this sure is going to be good :)

If you like platformers but are not into hardcore platforming, well...I think you should still get the game you get the chance. Just do not expect to finish it. The levels available on the level portal have a difficulty rating, so using the right filters should give you a few more hours of gameplay even if the base game is getting too hard too quick for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048480170', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1436231299}
review:
UPDATE: I've returned to the game to earn its Steam cards, trying the DX release. My impression this time around is more favorable: they seem to have eased the difficulty curve, with a wider variety of levels available at the outset. Maybe I'm just better at it this time around, but the combo system seems more forgiving, too. My overall rating is still "not recommended for most people," but it's definitely been improved since I played before.

---

I obtained Dustforce as part of a Humble Bundle, and it turned out to be one of the weakest entries of the set. Having enjoyed Super Meat Boy, I thought taking on another challenging speed/flow platformer would be good fun, but Dustforce didn't measure up.

In premise, Dustforce seemed like a lot of fun. Ninja janitors! Fighting-game style uppercuts and kicks, used to navigate hazards and literally clean house! Some lovely sprite work and a fantastic soundtrack enticed me to give it a go.

Unfortunately, Dustforce turns out to be one of those games where only the hardest of the hard core need apply, and no lesser player has any hope of wringing some entertainment from this sharp, unforgiving stone of a title. Unless you master the moves immediately (perhaps by some years' experience playing Street Fighter on the competitive scene?), you will fail constantly, progressing to the end of even the earliest levels only by determination and brute repetition. That in and of itself is not irredeemable--that's part and parcel of SMB's shtick, after all. However, the insult to injury is that speedrunning is mandatory. You cannot barely squeak out a level completion and advance in the game; you *must* achieve a ranking score in speed and thoroughness in order to earn keys to open additional levels. If you don't, well, enjoy replaying the first world a lot, because that's all you'll get to see.

There is something to be said for defying the predominant game design pattern of "if you just play long enough, no matter your skill, you will win." And no doubt a truly elite button-pusher would revel in it here. But if you don't consider yourself such a chest-thumping master, you would do well to give this game a pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014331886', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1439774285}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979724838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1435282068}
review:
This game is clearly way too hardcore for me. Levels are available in 3 basic tiers of difficulty, unlocked by sufficiently besting some levels of the previous tier, and then actually GETTING TO the level entrances in the hub area, which is oftentimes more sadistic than the levels themselves. I have gotten to exactly one of the third tier levels, and couldn't manage to get back to where I was afterwards.

At a glance, it's a great concept, you speedrun levels while dealing with all the cleaning hotspots and keeping a combo going from start to finish if you want to S-rank it. In practice, unfortunately, I find myself wrestling with the controls twice as much as the level design. Entirely too often I'm kicking off of a wall when I was attempting to do a double-jump, clinging to the ceiling when I was trying to do a dash-jump, or dealing with the bizarre inertia that makes it impossible to just nudge yourself a half-inch in any direction when trying to set up for some precision platforming or just attempt that double-jump from a little farther away from the wall so I don't do a goddamn wall jump by mistake again.

Still recommended, but eh.

It does come with a level editor at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083714959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1434819805}
review:
Before you read my review, keep in mind I've played, like, a few minutes of this game. All of this is first impression stuff.

[b]What I like:[/b]
‚Ä¢ The soundtrack is goddamn GORGEOUS (I even discovered this game because of the soundtrack, Lifeformed is awesome)
‚Ä¢ The vector-like graphics are really nice

[b]What I dislike:[/b]
‚Ä¢ Control kinda sucks, it feels inaccurate and somewhat floaty, and doing the tricks like walljumps isn't easy or that intuitive. It isn't [i]terrible[/i], but it isn't great either...
‚Ä¢ It feels all... zoomed in... like a 3D game where the FOV is jacked down to like 30

So concludes my first-glance review. To be honest, I'll probably never play this again. If my review is inaccurate, it's because I've barely started. It doesn't help that I went into this game expecting the quality of Super Meat Boy or World of Goo (because I bought this game in a Humble Bundle with those two also in the bundle).

author: {'steamid': '76561198024994929', 'num_games_owned': 1191, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2261, 'last_played': 1677643277}
review: This is one of the most incredible games I've ever played. Let me just start by saying if you're looking to blaze through this game to play every level it won't be that easy. You will need to dedicate some time to mastering the gameplay, and acquire the skills nessecary to complete it. The control is unreal for me even better than Super Meat Boy's which is insane, because I thought Super Meat Boy's control was absolutely perfect this just pushes the limits of polished controls. This is what difficult platformers should be where you learn by playing one level later get to a more advanced one, and can already feel and percieve what you need to do to accomplish the tasks at hand. It has four different characters each with their own unique playstyle and feel. It's just such a rewarding experience to learn how to pick up every piece of garbage, defeat every foe, and keep your combo up in each level and perfect them bringing you one step closer to completing the game. The only con I have for this game is that you have to complete every level 100% in order to complete it which might lower the accessibility a bit. I highly recommend playing this game on controller I felt so lost playing it on keyboard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052486056', 'num_games_owned': 700, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1436185168}
review:
[h1]Dustforce DX Review [/h1]

[i]This is my personal view on the game, and though you may disagree with some of the statements I make I stand with them nonetheless.[/i]

[i]Game was purchased in the Humble Indie Game bundle.[/i]

Dustforce DX is platformer game like many other platformer games, with the primary objective of the game being to gain the fastest possible time accompanied by style and completion of a level as possible. It has a large player base, many levels to choose from, a level editor and plenty of UGC. Here's a list of pros and cons I've compiled which I felt summarise the game:

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Tidy graphics that are pleasing to the eye.
[*]OST's that can be enjoyable to listen to.
[*]A plethera of levels to choose from with varying levels of difficulty for the player.
[*]Solid gameplay mechanics that aid the game in differing from other generic platformers.
[*]Full gamepad support (Which I also highly recommend if you choose to buy this game).
[/list]

With those positives, you may wonder what made me not recommend this game. Well, here's the list of cons that detracted from the game, mostly personal preference:

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Somewhat repetitive gameplay, as of many generic platformers. Gets exceedingly boring over extended periods of playtime, I had to resort to 15 minutes each session.
[*]Can feel extremely unrewarding at times, given the 'speedrun' feel to the game. Completing a section of a level you have been stuck on for a while does not mean success, but rather spending time trying to complete levels decreases your final score, which leads onto the next point.
[*]Can grind to a halt at certain parts of gameplay. By this, I mean some of the early levels can be gruelling and seem out of place, as early users as myself may find certain parts of a level too difficult to proceed on, meaning the rest of the level goes to waste as one part of the level cannot be completed. Ties in as hard parts of levels that take multiple tries to complete can be pointless in the end to complete.
[*]Speed problems. Not running speed, such as lag, but rather play speed. The game at times can feel sluggish, and over long stretches of rock can feel slow. The game can also lose momentum when you make a minor slip and parts of the level such as loops are impossible to make, ergo reducing your final score and sometimes making you backtrack.
[*]No threats. This one being more personal preference than the others, but every enemy I've encountered in the game so far (Around 20-25 levels in) has posed no threat, and at the most has only knocked me over for me to only recover again within a matter of a second. This makes levels seem somewhat bland, as the only enemy is the level itself.
[*]Again, somewhat more personal, the dash-jump mechanic is frustrating to carry out. The mechanic intends that you dash then jump on solid ground to jump a long distance without the need for a run-up, although for many times I have found in levels it is intended to be used I cannot carry out the dash-jump. This, for me, was mostly experienced on the Advanced Training level, where the game does not tell you HOW to dash-jump and the level is also seemingly harder than the previous two tutorials by far.
[/list]

For the points listed above, I cannot recommend this game. This game by no means is a bad game, as can provide some entertaining gameplay at points and is well made, but due to the way it plays, I would not recommend this game to a friend.

Overall rating: 6/10
TL;DR: Well made but frustrating to play at points and can be rather generic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038001710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1435397528}
review:
Amazing level design and incredibly satisfying gameplay. The music is also fantastic and suits the art style and areas very well. Great variety in difficulty too. Some nice easy levels to start off with as well as some insanly harder ones further down the track. Just getting to some of the level doors can be a challenge. 

My only criticism is that there's a there's a disappointing number of levels. Now, 75 levels may sound like a lot. However, most only take a minute or two to complete and if you're going for a perfect run, sometimes as little as 20 seconds is all it takes to get to the finish line (or giant leafy bear in the case of this game.) 

Most of you're game time comes either from the community made levels or perfecting the defult ones to get the last few keys. An interesting point is how unless you've got perfect on all previous levels, you'll never unlock the final door. I don't really mind (I like a challenge) but some may find this quite frustrating.

Due to it's length, it probably isn't worth time full price unless you're really into platformers, but if you see this on a decent special, I can't recommend this enough.

review: Game looks nice, not much into platformers but there a re a few I like provided they work right,The same sequence of maneuvers will not consistently produce the same results in this game, making the game frustrating, and the player's progression through the level isn't nearly as fun or precise as it should be in a platofmer. It seems very very hit and miss even if you KNOW what to do and press the right controls and combos. It's a very hard on the fingers game and seems to not respond correctly, as most of the negative complaints revolve around this issue. Looks nice, but controls are whacked in that they do not respond as they should, when they should, making it frustating as opposed to challenging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025902156', 'num_games_owned': 734, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 3322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1535, 'last_played': 1664939527}
review: One of the reasons Dustforce sticks out from so many games on the market right now is because it knows EXACTLY what it is, and doesn't try to be anything else other than that. It is essentially a speedrunning game, in which you play an acrobatic broom clad hero (there are four playable characters with varying stats). The goal of each level is to clean as much as possible as fast as possible. Completion and Finesse (which is your cleaning combos) are both graded, and it's oh-so enticing to shoot for an S rank. It's a simple idea, and executed quite well. The movement system is precise and interesting, and all of the levels are designed the system in mind. This creates a really strong gameplay experience which can be missed in a lot of games. The soft visuals and calming tunes create a very warm and pleasant mood. (I'd like to add that the animation is absolutely superb!) Dustforce is an excellently done and unique game, and those looking for an addictive platformer will likely be satisfied with it's cleanly charm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008620069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1433425256}
review:
I really tried to like this game. But after about four hours of play time and not one minute of fun I gave up on this game. Here are the reasons for this.

Instead of moving smoothly you kind of "trigger" fixed movement schemes (e.g. pressing right ones makes about two or three steps to the right). Because of this your input does not always have an effect on the movement. This means that precise timing and reactions are less important than pure mezmorizing and in the worst cases playing felt more like a long boring quick time event. Personally I can't stand QTE's.
In order to progress you have to collect every single piece (!) of dust in a level. To me this feels like a goal that should clearly be optional. Suppose some Mario game that says: "Oh, you didn't collect every coin in the level. Go back to the beginning." Another problem is that this completely breaks the flow of the gameplay. So instead of going for a quick smooth run you turn around and do backtracking to collect the last pieces of dust. In most levels this acutally seems to be what the level-designers intended.
In order to progress to must also make sure that your combo-chain does not break, whichs happen if you didn't collect dust for some time. I think this is supposed to force the player to make a "smooth" run, but it doesn't. The problem is that usually there is dust in so many places that messing it up first try and clumsily turning around is a valid option. I really don't understand what the developers were going for with this. Why is going through a level fast not rewarded in a game that (I think) is basically designed to be a speedrunner-heaven. Also it should be way better indicated when the combo-chain breaks.
Another minor complaint is that the tutorial just does not give you enough information to play the game. You have to figure out  the details of the gameplay-mechanics yourself, it is never explained what the finesse-ranking is based on and neither does the game explain that you actually need double-S ranking in order to unlock all levels (which is by the way stupid as (insert insulting word here) anyway).

author: {'steamid': '76561198023559435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2879, 'last_played': 1677458466}

author: {'steamid': '76561197987459477', 'num_games_owned': 780, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 4697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4234, 'last_played': 1640930194}
review: The learning curve for this game is very steep and the difficulty ramps up quickly as well. That said, finally unlocking the double S achievement after 50+ hours of trying was immensely satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042698724', 'num_games_owned': 637, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1692114017}
review:
I love everything that this game is about.

Right off the bat, the most admirable features of Dustforce are its depth and the multifaceted ways there are to complete each stage with a perfect rank. It's a speedrunner's dream. The basic moves are simple: run, jump, dash, attack. But [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DS8bmh_U1RU] check out what the most talented players can do with them.	[/url] There is a path laid out for you, and it's up to you to decide [i]how[/i] to traverse it. Mechanics like dashing at the end of a slope or boosting downward to increase momentum illustrate how the gameplay is meant to be experimented with, and it feels awesome. 

My personal favorite part of this game, though, is the atmosphere. It's self-aware, but not "I-am-self-aware"-self-aware; there isn't an attempt at a story, there isn't any humor, there isn't even any characterization beyond some subtle win animations (without the internet, the only way we'd even know the names of the characters would be looking through the game's files). It's just the ever-so-video-game-ish premise of acrobatic janitors sweeping up and down the walls, and it's done so smoothly. The controls are easy to get used to, the animations are smooth, the environments are beautiful, and the music is soothing, composed by the awesome [url=http://lifeformed.bandcamp.com/] Lifeformed [/url].

Also worth mentioning is the awesome community surrounding Dustforce. The subreddit is a pretty active place, and with replays being attached to every rank on every leaderboard, the best way to learn how to get better is by watching and learning from others.

In short, if you like platformers, you should try it. If you like speedrun-able/"perfect run" type games, definitely try it. If you're a janitor, it just might change your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145993674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1469950282}
review:
Highly recommand this game.

The game is with great graphic detail which is nice for any 2D games. The art style is fancy. Movements animations are smooth and swift. The actions are well connected. 

Musics are also well developed and fit every map well.

This is a skillful game, and the gameplay is flexible. Some complained about the fast gaming and the hard combos; I regard these the real fun of this game. In any map, I can finish the game in anyway I want and try to have it perfect, fluent. This gives players unlimited possibilities. The combo throughout each game is fascinating for me, compared to the games with slow rhythm and always inconsistent and broken in moves. This game never prevent the chance to be consistent. The way to finish is always flexible. When checking out the record of the game, I can always find the best players finishing with unusual way and skills.

The game have great feeling of control. Though it got to be a speedrunning game, Dustforce still gets the nice feeling when you strike down, jump or attack. It has nice timing in the air to react into next move.

The only cons for this game I  may say is the UI is not so welcoming. It is not well decorated. And some transactions in the "Main World" are too abrupt.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983025643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 13193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9348, 'last_played': 1696957892}
review:
I'd let my hours played speak for itself, but some nuance perhaps could be useful : )

Especially now with the DX upgrade, Dustforce is as complete as a platformer can be. Plus, though perhaps you don't aim to be the fastest (and good grief that's hard), the game offers plenty of challenge to first get through the levels, and then try to get through the levels perfectly. Which in itself is its own reward.

So do you want a challenging platformer game that isn't just about stomping on the heads of walking mushrooms and can make you feel very accomplished as you tear through the levels perfectly? Dustforce I'd highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975599804', 'num_games_owned': 1465, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1430496395}
review:
A game i really wanted to like, but couldn't get into.  This game looks great - it has a soft pastel color scheme coupled with fluid animations.  The softness can get on your nerves after a while.  The controls are a bit of a mess.  The rules double-jumping is confusing as the game doesn't give you any kind of visual feedback of when you can double jump.  The dash-jumping is somewhat inconsistent as well.  But maybe that's because i was trying to use a gamepad... the support for which is minimal.  You have to manually set up each key and as you change your direction and select keys, you have to use the new keys that you assign for them even in the customize controls menu.  This gets worse if you want to try multiplayer.  After going through the horrid experience of setting up all the controllers one by one, I loaded up the survival mode and was duly greeted with "no levels found."  Apparently you have to go to their website and download it from there.  

I suppose if you can get over the controller customization, finding multiplayer / custom levels, idiosyncratic controls, you might really enjoy this game.  Otherwise, I hesitate to recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086819730', 'num_games_owned': 839, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1429998711}
review:
This is one of the best games I've ever played. I'm fucking serious.

This is the tightest and most fluid aspects of platformers combined and given a steady milkshake of steroids. You will die so many times in this game and you'll love all of it.

The game revolves around the satisfying act of cleaning stuff, albeit very precisely. You swipe and dash through each stage cleaning up leaves, dust, and enemies made of... leaves and dust. The stages can be cleared in a variety of ways but ultimately it is up to you to find the most efficient and fastest route.

There is one single achievement to get, and it requires you finished [i]every[/i] stage with an 'S' mark in both 'Completion' and 'Finesse'. [b]Good fucking luck with that[/b].

The music is absolutely [i]incredible[/i] and as clearly well-made as the game itself. The whole thing just oozes quality and if you like platformers and doing stuff insanely precisely, you'll probably like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019205444', 'num_games_owned': 4251, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1427906355}
review:
Dustforce is a beautiful, traversal style 2D platformer with a lot of parkour, wall running, ceiling hanging with some light combat. If you're the sort of person that likes exploration and collecting in platformers, Dustforce is right up your dirty alley. First is its beautiful art style that makes it stand out from a heap of other platformers. Then you have a great sense of movement control. You can double jump, dash, run up walls for a brief time, wall jump, cling to a ceiling and move along to it before you ultimately fall off.  You can slide down slopes and Yaba-Daba-Do your way off inclines at the end to launch yourself.

The game introduces you to all these incredible mechanics via three tutorial levels. One for traversing, another for combat and the third for advanced techniques such as dash jumping into a double jump to run up a wall. I had to return to the advanced techniques 2 hours into the game to complete it. You are never forced to do anything in the game, but there is definitely a need to perfect these skills.

As a member of dust force, your goal is to clean the world of dirt by touching it. Its easy enough to just run across dirt, making it disappear, but the challenge becomes getting up walls, onto ceilings, and beating the dirt from enemies that gives harmless things a sinister new life. The object of each level is to dust trails of leaves, green glop and other forms of dirt all the way up to defeating a few enemies at the end. There's nothing to differentiate these enemies, one dead end full of enemies might not be the dead end full of enemies you're looking for.

Combat gets relegated to two buttons, a weak attack and strong attack. The strong is only good for larger enemies, because defeating a smaller enemy will only scatter the dirt covering them and you'll still need to clean it. Light attacking enemies in the air gives you an extra jump, so you can double jump, hit an enemy and then jump a third time. As you play, you're also building a meter. When it gets full your character will color trail and pressing both attacks will give an automatic beating to enemies and dirt on screen. Assuming your character will be able to reach them.

There are a few different types of enemies, big hopping heads, angry bears. There are more mundane hovering types either balls of leaves or gargoyles. Green balls of goo that will punch you back, hovering barrels dumping goo beneath them. Even a sort of porcupine that shoots quills or sharp leaves at you. The biggest threat is spikes that cover large areas in later parts of the game. Each spike death or pit in the Nexus or in a level will respawn you.

When going through a level, you don't have to sweep every bit of dust or leaves, but at the end you're graded on your completion and finesse. For everything you clean, enemy or trail of dirt, you build a combo. Finesse gets determined by how high of a combo you score in each level. Getting hit or taking too long to clean something new will break your combo and hurt your finesse grade. Each level is also connected to a global leader board. Getting a "S" rank in a level will give you one of three colored keys (copper, silver and gold) to unlock new levels.

The problem is you need to find every level in the game via a hub world called the Nexus. This hub world offers. a real sense of exploration and challenge even to get to these level doors. Some doors are clustered in easy to access areas, but others are for more skilled players. You'll need to slide down ramps and vault over pits, or double cling to ceilings to make it across a bed of spikes. There are even areas that you'll need to time jump, dash, jumps to make it through and then do it again. For every path you take in the Nexus, you'll need to make your way back. Its never as simple as doing the same thing a second time. You'll need to figure out a way to do it or take a different route and hope that it circles back. Other doors are completely hidden and you'll need to get into every nook and cranny to find secrets.

Its not like Metroid where you unlock a new ability, getting there relies completely on your skill. After the first two dozen levels, everything gets a lot more difficult. Its this difficulty that some may love, but it hindered my enjoyment of the game. This Nexus is big and it has to be to fit over 70 levels in it.

Each level starts by letting you select from one of four members of Dustforce. They're all color coated with different looks and ways to clean, but they all play the same. No one has any ability over one another. These characters definitely give the game character and charm. An old man wearing green carrying a vacuum, a brunette in purple with pom poms as dusters, a blue clad janitor with a humble broom and a female version with red overalls.

In fact style summarizes the game as a whole, from the beautiful world with rich backgrounds in a washed out color pallet to the movement and flow of your character. Even the soundtrack has a style that fits the art. Its tranquil synthetic ballads fit perfect into the background of the beautiful cityscape, caves and laboratories.

Outside of the Nexus is a different sort of hub. Its a place that lets you visit the tutorial levels, and even go through previous levels you've beaten. These tomes come in four different books, each for different themes of each level. There's the cityscape, the castle, laboratory and. I'd much prefer flipping through a book to find a level rather than exploring the Nexus, but whatever.

For anyone creative, there's a level editor that lets you make levels in game as rich and beautiful as you'll find in Dustforce. You can even go online to download levels from your web browser. It seems like an extra step that should just be in the game. These levels all have ratings, difficulties and keywords tagged with them so you can find whatever you have a mind for.

There's even local multiplayer survival and king of the hill for up to four local players. I didn't test this or anything so I can't review it until I get a party together on my wide screen to play Dustforce.

Now for the bad stuff, by default there is no controller support, but you can rebind the keys to support your controller. The only problem with that is you still need to hit the ESC key to bring up a menu. Having a menu bind would have been nice, but its hardly a big issue. I've managed to get myself stuck outside of the screen and the camera just wouldn't follow me. Are these enough to ruin a game, no certainly not.

While this is a beautiful game with a lot of fun mechanics, it just feels needlessly difficult to get to levels. Some may like the exploration to find a level or get to a door they see high up above, but it feels like extra padding. Even with all these mechanics the game still just didn't feel like fun. It felt like a chore to go into a level and touch every place with dirt, dust and leaves. Sure I didn't have to, but if I wanted a key I'd have to. In the later hours of my play through I spent more time just getting to the levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985969658', 'num_games_owned': 999, 'num_reviews': 685, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1427415298}
review:
Was excited to try the game, and then thurougly let down. It is an interesting (albeit kinda boring) idea you just sweep everything up. There is not story whatsoever (meh). Music seems fine. Then the problems happen. The game requires all these tricky movements and long fluid combos, but the controls and mechanics and super finnicky, inconsistent and dont work half the time. Sometimes I will be able to jump after a wall-run, while other times I won't. Sometimes I will only get a single jump and sometimes I will get a double jump. It seems stupid to me you can't double jump, wall run, and double jump again. The wall running and ceiling running is the worst crime. Sometimes I will be able to run up a wall, and other times I will hold against it and my gun will just run a tiny bit or won't even start a wallrun. One part to get to a new area my guy runs up and then on the ceiling, then just stops for no reason. I try to jump to the next area and hold over because the ledge is right there, but he just won't react to any buttons and falls down. This makes no sense. Sometimes you can run on the ceiling and then around on to the wall, and other times it won't. It just seems the people want to game to be more fluid, but the controls aren't consistent enough. The movements are also floaty and you will try to jump next to something and overshoot it or you will try to double jump next to a wall and instead it will make you run up it. 

Same goes with hitting, which you can hit up, but at and angle. Countless times I would be next to a guy and hit, only to go through him because I was TOO CLOSE and I wasn't at the perfect spot where the end of my broom ended exactly on his body, but thats like saying you can't hit someone with a sword because they aren't at the tip......I still hit him with the rest of my broom it should count. Very questionable hit recognition. Then there is the level design. Instead of making the levels easy to get to, like the level book, you can only look at them and replay unlocked ones, which seems dumb, because I'd rather be able to play the ones I haven't yet. Instead there is this open map with tons of different platforms and branching paths, and I am supposed to find every unlockable level by exploring....what this does is make me wonder if I have missed levels, and the only way to find out is to backtrack and try to make sense of things. Why not have the levels you created that you want people to play accessible, not in a convoluted area where people can easily miss them. Then there are levels and are like impossible to get it. I went through and played all the levels that seemed accessible and apparent how to get to them, and I know there are more but have no clue how to get to them, and then other parts I am wondering if there are other ways to get to. This shouldn't be that way this early to leave this many levels on the table like that. I don't understand why they would add the monotony of walking from door to door and retracing steps and trying to figure out how to get to this impossible looking spot, just to play the levels of a platformer, it seems counterintuitive to me. Why waste time with boring things when we just want to get to the good parts.

Also they say controller support, but it doesn't automatically detect it, and you have to manually reset all of the buttons, and even then you can't use just the controller, because you can't program start to pause or use the controller on the menus very well....for a platformer thats a mistake by them.

And i know there are people on here that are tryhards that are like "I don't have any of these problems" and "you're just bad" but the fact is I'm not, I've played tons of platformers. I recently played a game called freedom fall that had tight controls and I had no problems with. The people that I mentioned above that will say those things, put like 70 hours into the game, and it shouldn't take that long to try and get consistency out of movement controls, they shouldn't take that much repetition and effort to figure them out, they should be obvious. I have played other games that do wall-running, air juggling, and sliding, better than this. Also there is the keys and the scores. I mentioned in my "AAAAA for awesome" that scores are cool for the tryhards like the ones that want to SS everything and spend 20 hours on 20 levels, but you shouldn't force that. I shouldn't have to get certain preset scores to unlock more levels by getting keys based on my score. Just let me play the levels you created. I do like how they included level editor, multiplayer, and the community maps, although those are just a lot of dumb ones with all spikes created by tryhards that want you to be perfect with moves and have spent 60 hours like them, so I wasn't impressed with some of the creations. 4.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009219777', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 5197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4849, 'last_played': 1705165953}
review: Dust force is one of the best platformers ever made. The visuals of the game blend with the music and gameplay of the game to make one incredible experiance. Adsd that to superb level design that not only tests the skillls of the player, but also allows for tons of strategy that will be seen as soon as you decide to take a peek at the top ten leader board. This is one of those platformers that has a difficulty comparable to other games such as Super Meat Boy, but only if you decide to challenge yourself. This allows gamers of all levels to participate in the game from the most casual player that wants to just get to the end of the level to the most hardcore player that will spend tens of hours to get # 1 on the leader board for a single level. If you have ever found any enjoyment from a platformer I emplore you to give dustforce a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037039305', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1576973445}
review:
Honestly this is one of my favorite indie games on Steam. The platforming is super fun; really easy to pick up but super hard to master. Finishing the levels is one of the most satisfying feelings in this game, especially when you beat a time or make it through a level with an S ranking. The way momentum works really sets you up with some really cool opportunities. It just has that whole speedrunning feeling to it, like what you would feel like when playing Mirror's Edge or the early Sonic games. 

The graphics are wonderful. I don't doubt you can't run this game on any machine, but the game still looks gorgeous despite being somewhat flat and minimalistic. The music fits VERY well with the art. The game is worth to buy just for the soundtrack. I'd say the art style and music are in the same league as Fez or Hotline Miami, if not better (fight me if you disagree). 

There's nothing much to complain about. I didn't like the standard controlls, but you can rebind those. My fingers kinda get tired after playing also, but that's definetly not because the game does something wrong, it's because I can't stop playing it sometimes. All in all I think this game is great and everyone should at least give it a go for ten bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071358326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1425938920}
review:
I am not a speed runner. But if i was, this game would be awesome. You play as one of four types of cleaner ninja and try navigate levels in the shortest time with the highest score. After each level you get your leaderboard ranking and can watch runs of other ranked players to try and figure out how they pulled this stuff off. The game also has a level editor and a lot of user created levels. The soundtrack is amazing both in game and out. There is also a multiplayer component that i didn't get to try out. If speed running isn't appealing to you, then you probably won't like this. If its something you are interested in getting into, then yeah give this a go.
Note - If you are visually impared, SOME levels will have contrast issues where distinguishing between various ineractable objects will be difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088594452', 'num_games_owned': 354, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1437301447}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997671603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2217, 'last_played': 1590269881}
review:
Easily one of the best precision platformers ever created.

Not only are the controls tight and responsive, the visuals are amazing AND the soundtrack is one of the best I've ever heard. There are replays and leaderboards for every level, so you can study and learn from the best players as you learn/discover some of the more advanced maneuvers. Sure, the difficulty may not appeal to everyone, but if you are a fan of difficult platformers; do yourself a favor and sink some hours into this gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061249750', 'num_games_owned': 1173, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1423027223}
review:
Dustforce is the kind of game I want to get good at, and feel like I am, until I see my rankings on the leaderboards. 

Mechanically, I haven't played a platformer that responds so well. Once you wrestle out the way to bind your keys to your gamepad, prepare to be blown away by the insane amount of love put in to make this godly platformer. Gameplay and animation is insanely fluid, and while controls can be a bit floaty, they lend themselves well to the levels designed around it, and gives generous space failure, even when your inner speed demon does not. This game must be noted as one without any notable story, and is built solely around replay value, so if you're like me and enjoy a veil of plot to your games, you won't find it here. Honestly, with how much the game screams of personality, and with all the bear-cleaning and animal smacking, I felt like there was a missed opportunity in set up, but this is not a detractor. There is a lot of humor to be found in just the enviornment, and like any good p0rn, you're not here for the story.

 Wonderful game if you want to feel inferior and still have a great time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006245602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1067, 'last_played': 1438864590}
review:
Pleasing to the eye, ear and mind, dustforce is a great platformer that will keep you sweeping for hours on end. 

-Gorgeous art style, full of charm and character with consistently themed levels with sprites to match. One of the things I love most about this game is the soundtrack, its mellow tones are relaxing and blend seamlessly with the gameplay, softening the frustration at my inept cleaning.  

-Gameplay is consistently challenging, but as you repeat levels you gradually learn the layout and the best/fastest way to clear each and every obstacle. There is nothing more rewarding than when you get that perfect run (well, not perfect, but as good as I'm going to do). The momentum based character movement did take some getting used to, but after much practice it allows you to flit through a level like a breath of wind.

-The main area in which Dustforce is lacking would be the tutorial, it provides a good basic understanding of the movement mechanics and will make a player reasonably competent. However, to play dustforce to its full, flowing potential it is a necessity to go on youtube and watch tutorials and examine the manouvres and tricks used by the best of the best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096439278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1420916073}
review:
If you're a fan of ninja-styled mechanics in platformers, I would say to ignore this title. There isn't any real way to maintain speed, the keyboard assignment is terrible, and the jumps and movement in the game seem to be too consistent. That's right. TOO consistent.

Think games like Mario Bros. or N+, where you can just tap a jump or movement key and only move a small amount.

This game doesn't follow that at all, at least on keyboard controls.

While playing, I found a set of ledges with a gap just big enough for the character to fall between, but for some reason, the game will still "jump" you from one platform to the next even while trying to walk and fall between them. Again, there is no small movement in the game. In trying to make a time-based fluid movement, they have done away with sensitivity, making technical parts of levels more difficult than they should be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004835991', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1420840380}
review:
Support manette partiel, ou comment alterner clavier et manette pour naviguer dans les menu du jeu... Lamentable !
Le principe √©tant de faire des tableaux en SPEEDRUN, pourquoi nous INFLIGER du SLOWMENU ? 
Du coup on se retrouve comme un *ours brun* √† utiliser la touche ECHAP du clavier de la main gauche pour ensuite avec la main droite descendre dans le menu et s√©lectionner RESTART du niveau en cours (qui n'est √©videment pas en premi√®re position), puis appuyer sur le bouton d'action de la manette. Avouez que pour l'intuition on aurait pu faire mieux. Action que vous allez op√©rer en moyenne toutes les minutes, puisque vous allez forc√©ment vous rater un max de fois avant de maitriser la topographie du niveau en cours. Je fulmine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048752110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1419554700}
review:
A tough, speedy platformer in the vein of Meatboy with some minimal combat mechanics. 
and each of the four characters have some minor differences in stats that make them play just slightly different from eachother. 

And that's pretty much all you need to know. If you enjoy difficult platformers that depend on timing and reflexes, then this is for you. 
The visual aesthetic is also really pleasant to look at.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972370196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1426963557}
review: So, I love this game. You pick one of four janitors and glide around cleaning up messes, and fighting enemies possessed by dust.  It's one of those precision platformers where its all about getting faster completion times and better scores. The base game has dozens and dozens of levels, but there is a pretty active mod community that has made a ton of maps. Also the music is AWESOME. I ended up paying additional for the soundtrack because it is so good. The artstyle is a great animated style, and when you get the hang of the controls it feels great to glide through levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080343643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1420732957}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028575366', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1420603132}
review:
"Cleaning up dust wasn't as much fun as I thought it'd be." 5/10

I never thought I'd see the day where I wanted to play a game that revolved around cleaning up dust particles, but nevertheless, here we are. They say never judge a book by it's cover. Well, never judge a video game by it's screenshots. For this game appeared to have it all, but managed to fall short. Let me start out by saying that I loved the art style though, along with the soundtrack. In fact, the soundtrack is probably the best part about 'Dustforce' and is exactly what you want in a platformer. As for the controls, they are nowhere near as bad as some of the people on here make them out to be, and personally I found them to be quite good. The only thing that stinks is how they make you assign the controller buttons yourself, as opposed to just having them preset for you. I wouldn't even dream of using a keyboard to play this game. 

As you may already know, this game was made with speedrunning in mind. Speedrunning is something I enjoy watching, but not performing, and had I known that beforehand, I would have skipped this game entirely. I mean, who makes a game specifically tailored for speedruns? Getting to the end of a level as quickly as possible? Where's the fun in that? No, I like to take my time, look around, really take in my surroundings. And besides, isn't the whole fun in speedrunning, coming up with the fastest method on your own? It just doesn't make much sense if you ask me. Aside from that, there's pretty much nothing else to do in this game but run from door to door playing level after level for the best time. No bosses, no enemies, just jumping from one platform to another, climbing wall after wall, sweeping up that dirty dust. 

There just doesn't feel like much of a reason to continue playing 'Dustforce' after an hour or two, unless you care about posting the highest scores for all to see. Which is basically where 99% of the incentive to continue playing comes from; the highest possible score. On the other hand, I can definitely see how people enjoy playing this game. Like I said, the soundtrack is great, the art style although simplistic, works quite well, and the controls are pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028674152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2984, 'last_played': 1645039129}
review: Most people do not realize that the greatest scientific breakthrough in recent years has been of the Dustforce.  For too long have we struggled to marry gravity with the electro-weak force, but finally we have our grand unified force; Dustforce.  Don't underestimate it.  This was a truly life changing event

author: {'steamid': '76561198011615762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1480012057}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966440492', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1420324046}
review:
Dustforce is slick, fluid, relaxing. Well, providing you're any good at it.

I'm not very good at Dustforce, but I still enjoy it a lot. I'm pretty clumsy with both a keyboard or a controller, I'm fairly certain the input doesn't matter, a skilled player can dance through the levels whilst a clumsier player like myself will find multiple ways to blame the controller whilst really it's the player at fault.

Completing a level isn't good enough, you have to go over and over, to get that S / S rating, shaving off seconds, perfecting a route, figuring the perfect peaceful and flowing pattern that will earn you a perfect and you can move on. Practice makes perfect.

The animations are beautiful and smooth, matching the gameplay style and giving everything a wonderful flow. The soundtrack is amazing, helping your mind hit that half-focused, half-zen-like concentration zone.

I'll never complete Dustforce, I'll never get S / S on many of the levels, I'm not even good enough to even GET to many of the levels in the hub world (they're hidden away out of reach, requiring a certain precision and timing of skills to climb to them)... But I still enjoyed the game, and I'd recommend it to others... It's a fun way to spend a couple of hours. Providing you're not going in for 100% completion, anyway. Only madness or a godlike zen-state await those who would dare.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043327000', 'num_games_owned': 1108, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1420124348}
review:
Well, first game i will review in 2015 (i wish you all a good year), now about Dustforce DX, is a good game, if you like Super Meat Boy, Bit Trip Runner, games like that pretty sure you will enjoy Dustforce DX. 

This game is not hard at all, plus i found it more easy than Super Meat Boy, but there are two things that i didn't like too much on game, the controls and the BGM. 

The controls are not smooth, they take a while to respond and for some odd reason i could't connect a controller, and the BGM is bit annoying.  

Still is a game that is worth playing! 

~ 7/10 

PS: This game is good for improve your cleaning dust skills :P

review: Surprisingly one of the toughest games I've played. If you like fast paced yet smooth flowing games this game is for you. There isn't a wall you cant run on or slide on basicly. One of the best things about this game I must say though is the soundtrack, LifeFormed makes amazing music! This music will even out the fast paced feeling of the game, letting you enjoy every minute of it. Recommend this for the music and alone the game is just the cherry on top.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978511705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 15709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1635092116}
review: This game... is so much fun !!! Great relaxing soundtrack, smooth non-restrictive gameplay and a lot of hidden techniques to compete with other people. Retrying is extremely quick, dying animations are fast and let you try again instantly. Best leaderboards I've seen in a while. You can watch every single replay whether it's the current world record time or some dudes 10000th ranking try. It's awesome and it's a must buy for everyone who likes to be challenged !

If you're a fan of platformers and have a little money to spare, it's definitely worth your time, but it could take some time to learn and get used to.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994480308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 296, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1427087807}
review:
I don't like Dustforce, and I can't really put my finger on why, though I have my suspicions. Let's start with all the things this game does right, though:

-Cool theme/graphical style
-Fun characters (all functionally identical, but visually distinct)
-Pleasant music

So what's wrong with Dustforce? It's hard to put into words, as the vocabulary for platform video game reviewing is still in its infancy and words like "floaty", "mushy", "heavy", "satisfying" and so on are all very subjective. If I was forced to put it into words, I'd say that your character is too heavy, yet doesn't have enough inertia - it takes a while to get up to speed, and it's very easy to lose that momentum with the way that levels are designed. It's fairly fluid when you play perfectly, but it falls apart in the hands of an inexpert player. 

What else?

The overworld is directionless and confusing. There are no (threatening) enemies, so this is purely platforming for the sake of platforming. Rarely are you directly challenged - the game is clearly designed for speedrun enthusiasts.

Here in the modern era of gaming, you have tons of options if you're looking to run and jump on some platforms. If I were you, I'd be cautious about this one. Check out Super Meat Boy instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989773498', 'num_games_owned': 1064, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 92063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 33515, 'last_played': 1710215066}
review: Dustforce is a very niche platformer, complex physics that aren't easy to master, endless challenge, tons of custom levels.  Chances are it'll make you angry when you are having trouble sometimes, but once you get over your gap, the reward is great, and a new challenge is there.  At some point you just realize, everything it has you do is fair, and you start to really enjoy the challenge.  Probably played this more then any other platformer ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122355273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 13628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3919, 'last_played': 1578916422}
review:
Dustforce is what most would classify as precision-platformer, a genre that I disliked. Yet this game somehow managed to be one of my favourite games. This game is just that good.

First thing you'll notice is its gorgeous graphic and sound. It's very pleasant to the eyes and ears, which is something you'll need to soothe the frustration that come from this game's harsh difficulty.

The gameplay is superb. When most games of the genre give you simple controls and requires you to press them at the exact timing, Dustforce has a vast array of traversal techniques for you to choose from. The game also put more emphasis on momentum. Which is why (outside of the tutorial) the game has 64 levels to train (and test) you about the more complicated techniques.  Even the overworld itself is designed in a way that requires you to perform difficult techniques to reach harder level.

One last thing, you will want to have the game run at stable 60FPS because any drop in frames can spell doom to your run.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043356212', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1418959792}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047210200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1418725766}
review:
This game helped me find out I'm an idiot, cause how else can I explain the fact that it's been an hour and I'm still struggling to finish the tutorial. 

Yeah, I get it, it's meant to be challenging, difficulty is its main concept, it's a "precision" platformer, but come on, the controls are bad as **** when using a menial keyboard. I love indie games, but some of them are way too pretentious to deserve all the appreciation they sometimes get for free.

Thank God at least it comes with trading cards. Also the soundtrack seemed pretty nice, at least during the tutorial part, cause getting any further is clearly not something I'll get to do.

Or maybe the tutorial is ****ed up?!

Anyway, let the downvoting begin, but I couldn't possibly ever recommend this game. If you pretend on being focused on difficulty, provide some damn proper controls first!

author: {'steamid': '76561198033672107', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 253251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1266, 'playtime_at_review': 27580, 'last_played': 1710899565}
review:
Very challenging but rewarding game. The physic smight take a bit of time to get used to but the platforming is truly top notch. The leaderboards system is really well-implemented and interesting, and always brings me back trying to eek out those last few fractions of a second to get a better time. 

The game has no story, but the beautiful style and amazing soundtrack make the game very aesthetically pleasing. On top of all that, the community is truly one of the best; they're creative, friendly, and helpful to any newcomers. This is one of my favorite games of all time, and I would most definitely recommend it to anybody who wants to have a good time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006768995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1577220815}
review:
Dustforce ist nicht leicht. Aber gerade, dass geh√∂rt zu einem guten Arcadespiel dazu. Nach mehrmaligen Versuchen darf ich mich endlich im oberen Mittelfeld der Rangliste befinden. Und dennoch gibt es selbst bei Abschnitten in denen ich die beste Punktzahl erreiche (Doppel S), kann ich mich zeitlich noch um eine ganze Minute verbessern.
Neben dieser Herausforderung und dem Aufbau eines gewissen Frustfells, darf ich w√§hrend meiner stilvollen Putzaktionen eine atmosph√§rische, manchmal sehr entspannende Musik genie√üen.
Grafisch passt das ganze Spiel sauber zusammen und auch der Service der Hersteller ist bisher ausgezeichnet. Haben sie nicht zuletzt einen Patch hervorgebracht, in welchem sie neue Level hinzugef√ºgt haben, sowie ein neues verbessertes Tutorial und eine neue Oberwelt, die zum Erkunden wieder einl√§dt. 

Und selbst, wenn ich √ºber Wochen dieses Spiel nicht spiele, es gibt immer wieder Zeiten, in denen ich f√ºr 10 Minuten gerne wieder eintauche, um erneut stilvoll gegen den Schmutz zu k√§mpfen.
Uneingeschr√§nkte Empfehlung

author: {'steamid': '76561198009935902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1418189257}
review:
Overview: An excellent precision platformer that puts emphasis on fine tuning each run and getting as close to impossibly perfect as possible.

This game is designed exceptionally well. Everything feels intentional and like meticulous thought was put into it, this caries over into how you learn to play the game as well. 

In the Dustforce you progress in an spawling overworld by beating levels, gaining keys and subsequently unlocking harder levels. In reality you progress by obsessing over every fraction of a second you could have done better in order to get higher on the leaderboards. You can watch replays others playthroughs of the levels, which is a great resource for new players and works splendidly within game.

You can play as 4 characters with slightly different traits, which really wont matter initially for the casual player but can make all the difference once you are acquainted with the game and aim to shoot hundreths of a second off your speed run.  

The controls felt a bit loose (or more floaty) to me persoanlly, having just finished playing several other platformers, but it was easy to adjust to and may have just been me. You have an insane amount of mobility and the levels are designed to show this off, letting you fluidly slide around walls, ceiling floors, and lay down some beatdown on enemies when they show up. 

The music is mostly mellow and slow and almost seems contrary to the pressure of trying to perfect your run. It does a nice job at keep you calm after several trails on the same level. 

Local Multiplayer works well and is fun to play, and is a wonderful addition. 

The animations and style of the game look great, just look at dem screen shots above.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049177095', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1520, 'last_played': 1607794246}
review:
An amazingly smooth and chill platforming game with insanely good music, pleasing visuals and excellent level design that runs butter smooth on almost any machine. The focus here is mechanics, which are all well implemented, and once you master the basics movements and learn how the dash can be used, it opens up a whole new world of possibilities.

Some levels can be very frustrating at first, no doubt about it, but the aforementioned great music can keep you calm for long periods of time. The immensely satisfying feeling of seeing an SS ranking and a good time on the end screen after working hard to get there makes this such an easy title to recommend. It's time trial without the stress.

The flow of movements and consistence is more important here than in other platformers, and these are probably the defining properties of Dustforce. There's never a time where you'll get lucky, and perfect a level, and there are few random elements in the game. Being able to see records of other players and friends can help you improve by a ton, and gives you something to strive for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011231592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1417275961}
review:
In this unique and challenging platformer you play as an acrobatic janitor, it is very HARD as some levels requires perfection to complete but I never thought that cleaning up leaves could be that funny. The soundtrack is great and the well polished animations makes the game always entertaining.
The  only downside is that you need to configure your controller (xbox360) manually.
