author: {'steamid': '76561198060328335', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1417128522}
review:
When I first found out about the crew of Dustforce and their follies in amateur game development, I became very anxious to play this game and to support them. However, playing the actual game has shown me that good intentions do not necessarily translate into a full experience.

I think that Dustforce's biggest problem is how it defines 'skill' and 'difficulty'. Dustforce has very little in the way of rewarding a player, only giving out keys which are used to unlock a handful of harder levels. When most of the game's content is unlocked from the start, the player's only remaining motivation is the scoreboard. When one takes a cursory glance at said scoreboard, one notices very long strings of players who complete the level in virtually the same amount of time, give or take a fraction of a second. Not only that, but the requirement of sweeping all dust in a level for a perfect score causes every level, regardless of size, to develop a 'one true path' that sacrifices exploration and player experience for the sake of a higher score. This makes the game extremely tedious to play, boiling itself down to memorization of a level and restarting the level at the slightest mishap.

I'm aware that the game is designed with the speedrunning community in mind, but one reason as to why speedrunning is so highly valued in those circles is the fact that speedrunners interpret a game in a different manner than the developers, and play it at a much faster speed than intended, entertaining others who are only familiar with a more down-to-earth means of beating the game. Meanwhile, Dustforce's design mentality is rigidly geared towards beating the levels as fast as possible, causing the practice of speedrunning to be rendered pedestrian, and therefore moot. 

Aside from the core gameplay, which is admittedly quite interesting despite its flawed implementation, there is honestly not much else to say about Dustforce. I did like how the game's various sprites were traditionally animated, but the artstyle itself is so minimalistic that the subtlties and quirks that normally come with such techniques are lost. The music on its own is good, but not exciting or emotional, causing it to simply blend into the background, when music should enhance the player's experience by being memorable or unique.

When looking at Hitbox Team's upcoming Spire, I'm glad to see that the team is taking more consideration to the skill of the individual and motivating the individual to get better in order to progress further. Hopefully, it'll make for a more rewarding and engaging experience than Dustforce, which, in my opinion, feels like more of a chore than actual dusting.

review: Probably in my top 5 best games of all time. I might stop playing for a few months sometimes, but I always come back to it. (Most of the time because one of it's songs comes by on my playlist). A wonderful mix of beautiful levels, ingenious level design, and simple but extremely deep gameplay. In my opinion one of the only games that intrinsically makes people want to speedrun, and with a miracle of a learning curve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024989833', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1429745303}
review:
Simply amazing.

Previous version was not that good due to learning curve, but DX version solved it all.

You can spend hours trying to master each of difficult levels, that requires almost the same precision as super meat boy sometimes.

If you enjoy games like Bit Trip Runner and Super Meat Boy this game is a must have.

Word of adivce: use a keyboard or you must be quite precise using analog stick or quite good with digital ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980330652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1381119809}
review:
Its a swell platformer belonging in anyones library who appriciates challenge to the point of demanding perfection.  The levels have some nice flow to them and the concept is somewhat unique.  You don't just run and jump from A to B you glide, fly, and sweep up dust in style from A to B.  Being a fan of solid platforming action I give this title a 9/10.

That being said I have heard criticism that the game demands perfection in order to continue unlocking levels and while this is somewhat true I have this to say: If you can't get an A or S rating on early levels there is no way you will even have fun on later levels.  The game eases into increadably difficult from fairly easy and the way it ensures you are up to the task is by only unlocking levels once you have cleared a previous level in style.  The goal isn't to get to the end but rather getting to the end in style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061624585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1416132473}
review:
2 hours first impression, well maybe this game isn't my thing. I'm a huge fan of metroidvania or megavania and this game has kind of weird control that I can't get used to in 2 hours. Ok, this game has an interesting concept where you have to clean the rooms as fast as possible. I think this is the problem because the usual metroidvania fanboy like me love game with quests and things that this game lack of.

I recommended this game if you love platformer where you can challenge your skill, to test how fast your hands and how good you memorized the level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041543513', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1414909084}
review:
[b]tl;dr -> In Dustforce DX you play as a master warrior-janitor on a never-ending quest to rid the world of all dirt and dirt-spreading creatures while listening to a fantastic electronic soundtrack.[/b]

I got this game in a bundle, and was really excited to try it because of all the technical gameplay mechanics - like the complex executions you have to use in order to make your run look as seamless as possible. I had watched a few speedruns on YouTube and was pleasantly surprised with the quality of experience provided by Dustforce DX.

If you like cleaning, artsy and smooth platforming gameplay, a stellar electronic soundtrack, chaining combos, score attacks, and challenging mechanics, then you will really enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are great - the detail in the different levels is very high and well-done. The music and sound effects are awesome, and I will provide a link to the OST here because it is that good; I think the only other game OST I ever linked in my review was NEOTOKYO's.

[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8_B8ekeZTCM]Dustforce DX OST[/url]. 

The controls are a bit tricky to learn, but the tutorials are very helpful and will ensure you get a firm grasp on the game's mechanics before you start your janitorial runs. You can try using a controller, but the keyboard bindings work just as well. The learning curve is minimal to moderate - one of the most difficult elements of the game is combining the different actions in order to achieve a smooth run. Combos are also essential for reaching many areas in each level and progressing deeper into the game. For example, you may have to wall run upward, double/wall jump several times, and hit a dustball/enemy at the top in order to reach a higher level (and if you do everything except hitting the object at the top, you will not be able to make the climb). Practising and repeating levels will really hone your skills.

Overall, the gameplay is very quick and technical - chaining the proper actions is critical. Once you can achieve a seamless run, the visual aesthetics are so satisfying and rewarding. The main hub will allow you to access the options and all the levels, however, you must unlock new levels by completing preceding ones. There are a good number of levels available for you to test your skills, and the game offers a lot of time value if you are really into speedruns and 100% completion. During your playthrough, you must complete each level in a set amount of time, while maintaining a smooth (finesse) run. If you can finish the stage within the time limit and maintain a good combo bar, then you will achieve a double S rank (best possible score).

For the achievement junkies, there is only one to collect, and this requires you to complete every level by performing the most perfect possible run. I really, really love this type of achievement system in a game, and not the stupid, meaningless artificial-game-lengthener types found in games like Lucius (which I will be reviewing soon) - where you need 20 and 40 game hours when the game takes ~10 hours to complete. No, in Dustforce DX there's just one, challenging achievement that involves you spending quite a bit of time refining your skills and experience so you can obtain those perfect runs.

The game can get a bit repetitive once you've invested a large amount of time, however, the variety in level layout and different enemy types adds lots of playability. There are also different characters with slightly different attributes, allowing for a unique playstyle depending on who you select (ex: one character has quicker drops and longer jump range).

If you like challenging platformers with an emphasis on finesse and score attacks, then you must give this game a try.

Definitely recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/djsfsroguereviews]@DJSF's Rogue Reviews[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198011227903', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3304, 'last_played': 1616521425}
review:
This game is beautiful. I often get utterly lost in it and forget that I'm playing a game. The soundtrack consistently completely engrosses me. The gameplay is so enjoyable throughout the game. The visual aesthetic is absolutely wonderful. The overworld is designed perfectly for easing players into the more advanced levels, although in the DX update, it's much harder to unlock the harder levels. Every level, despite most using one of four visual styles, is very memorable. Now: a quick warning. This game can eat up a ton of time on a few levels as the hard levels are very hard. I have almost no background in platforming, so maybe i just suck, but I still can't beat Backup Shift. Be prepared for very exact platforming.
This game is basically perfect. Even any glitches are just really cool. Get it, people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022044264', 'num_games_owned': 610, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2236, 'last_played': 1570323313}
review:
Dustforce is a beautiful platformer with a very high skill cap. The premise of the game is to sweep each level while never letting your combo drop; which occurs when you have not swept up any dust after a set period of time. A flawless continuous sweep gives you a 'perfect' rating, which can unlock keys which you can use to enter more difficult levels. This is not necessary to enjoy the game, though, as many levels are available without unlocks and community made levels are plentiful and just as enjoyable. You can complete levels without perfecting them, though this gives you a worse rating and no key. Earning a perfect rating on difficult levels is really a challenge as the mechanics in Dustforce take hours, maybe even days of playtime to perfect. 

The game contains a leaderboard where you can watch replays of the best times to get a feel for how to perfect a level and different paths to take. Only a small handful of players have perfected every level, and I am not one of them. The challenge does not take away from the game, though, it is still a fantastic game with gorgeous visuals and a calming and beautiful soundtrack that I have listened to for nearly 3 years now. I highly suggest picking up Dustforce if you are a fan of difficult platformers and want a real challenge fit for a perfectionist. 
 
Pros: 
-Beautiful art style and soundtrack, both go great together. 
-Difficult but rewarding controls and mechanics. 
-Tons of levels varying in difficulty. 
-Map editor and thousands of custom made levels from the community to keep you busy. 
-Leaderboard with a replay system which helps on more difficult levels. 
-4 different characters with their own slight differences. 
 
Cons: 
-Some advanced mechanics are not taught in game and are to be learned via the replay system or fanmade tutorials on youtube. 
-Multiplayer mode is local only (I have never touched it). 
-Some of the most difficult levels are possibly too hard and require a lot of time to figure out and perfect (may not be a downside to some).

Overall I'd I give it an 8/10. Also I suggest using a controller when playing, though this is personal preference.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038604011', 'num_games_owned': 914, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1414686425}
review:
I actually found myself rather excited to see Steam Trading Cards brought to Dustforce so late into it‚Äôs life. They gave me a good reason to go sink a few more hours into game when I don‚Äôt know that I would have played it again out of my own interest. I was absolutely dreadful at the game but the art, music, world and just the overall premise of the title really charmed me. I personally would have never bought Dustforce had it not been part of a bundle, but everything about the game was well done and lovingly put together and it really showed.
Sadly, something has changed. I booted the game back up to sweep some leaves and collect some cards and all of the mechanics are just broken. The controls are floaty and imprecise, the character seems to have a bizarre response time and beyond the fact that I openly admit I was dreadful at the game upon it‚Äôs release, whatever updates that have been put in place since then have made it completely unplayable. It‚Äôs truly a shame, but I can no longer say I recommend Dustforce.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041333258', 'num_games_owned': 815, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1426705400}
review:
This is a brilliant precision platforming game. The controls are tight (though it's best played with a gamepad) and the asthetic is gorgeous. The focus of the game is to complete levels with the most amount of debris cleared, a huge combo, and a record time. There's also tons of replayability in the community made levels.

 If you enjoy games that challenge you to get a faster time on each level, pick this one up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058203761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 566039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 152, 'playtime_at_review': 265707, 'last_played': 1710562311}
review:
admittedly a niche game, but definitely worth a try if you like indie platformers.  while the game has a steep learning curve (made worse by some pretty shoddy tutorials), if you persist the game has an enormous skill ceiling and some really rewarding difficulty.  the game is all about self improvement, and applying small things you learn to various other scenarios the game throws at you.   gameplay aside, the soundtrack is amazing, thousands of custom levels are availible online, and an online speedrunning leaderboard (with ingame replays!) makes it satisfying to watch yourself improve and climb ranks.  

i've spent over three years improving at this game and will never reach perfection, but it still feels rewarding to try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999405918', 'num_games_owned': 1775, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1415034777}
review:
Para empezar, decir que este juego posiblemente no ser√° para muchos, como creo que no es para mi. Si os gusta, como a mi, ir rebuscando con calma para dejar perfecto todo, aqu√≠ no hay sitio para ello. Esto se basa en hacerlo lo mejor que puedas (que puede ser perfecto, claro) pero a toda velocidad y si te saltas algo, pues nada, otra vez ser√°. Porque el juego va de limpiar polvo, hojas secas, residuos t√≥xicos o basura que hay por el suelo, paredes y techos, lo que significa que tienes que tocar esas zonas. Y a toda velocidad, porque cuando acabas, te dan una "nota" seg√∫n lo perfecto que hayas limpiado y lo r√°pido que lo hayas hecho y luego con eso, te van dando llaves para avanzar a nuevos niveles.

Eso s√≠, el juego es una peque√±a joya indie. Aspecto y graficos muy amorosos y cool, una de las mejores bandas sonoras de m√∫sica 8bit-retro que haya oido, dise√±o de niveles muy bueno, y plataformas de esos dificiles hasta decir basta con mil y una tecnicas para saltar m√°s, por las paredes, el techo, doble saltos, etc... pero el objetivo principal es hacer los niveles a toda velocidad "limpiando" todo lo que puedas por el camino.

Yo creo que como digo, es una peque√±a joya, pero sobre todo para los m√°s masoquistas que les gusten los plataformas  imposibles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040920335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 3821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2715, 'last_played': 1691879270}
review:
The main reason why this is such a good precision platformer and just platformer is because you have complete control over your movement. In Super Meat Boy, I found that in boss fights, it would force you to make precise jumps under pressure, which is hard enough, but you could slip, and the controls in Meat Boy felt generally slippy. In this, it's the opposite. Great OST, beautiful visuals, and tight platforming. This game pushed me to restart a level 60 times, to get a perfect rating, or playing the same level again and again to find that you're finally rank 250 out of 7500 for speed. And if that feeling isn't satisfaction, I don't know what is.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198037586730', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1427992224}
review:
This game is just terrible when it comes to learning how to play it. If you can learn to play it, then I imagine ti would be an awesome game.

The learning curve. You look at hard platform games like super meat boy or electronic super joy, these are hard games. But the learning curves are pretty good.  But this game just lacks that entirely.

Before the "DX" update, it was impossible to "get into the game" without already having knowledge of it. In the new DX update, things are easier, but they are still not perfect. I mean, for goodness sake, in order to even reach the 3rd tutorial, you seem to require the knowldge that is taught to you in that 3rd tutorial. (i.e. dash-jumping) It is very badly designed.

Having not been able to play them, I can't speak for the design of the later levels.

The control scheme for this game is impossible to use. In order to set it up to use a controller, you need to set up each button manually. And if you do set it up with a controller, it is impossible to switch back to keyboard without again manually resetting each button, via your controller. And god help you if you can't connect your controller again to do this. Also, I can't seem to figure out why the menu can't be opened by the controller. It can only be opened by pressing Esc on the keyboard.

Now, as for the music and art in this game, it looks really good.  Kudos to the dev team for that. The music is very calming (which is helpful in alleviating frustration), and the art style is simplistic, but avoids feeling "flat".

To summarize, I really think this game is lacking a lot in the way of easing new players in. It is just impossible to learn how to play it. Even with help from snipppets of conversations in the forums, it just feels like it's missing something. That, or I am the one missing something here.

[Incidentally, if anyone knows what it is that i'm missing, please tell me, because I really want to be able to play this game].

review:
Apesar de ter uma ideia interessante de gameplay, o jogo deixa a desejar quando falamos de mec√¢nica e jogabilidade. Al√©m de possuir uma s√©ria de bugs de qualquer jogo de plataforma, √© quase imposs√≠vel calcular a distancia e precis√£o de nenhum pulo. √â como se estivessemos jogando sempre em alguma fase em gelo, onde vc salta em um lugar, mais nunca para nele... Para complicar um pouco mais, o jogo colocou duas funcionalidades para parede, a de escalar e a de pular, o que exige do jogador uma mec√¢nica "dedal" inten√ßa, e que nem sempre surte o efeito que realmente deseja.
Acredito que se os desenvolvedores tirassem toda a cambada de fun√ß√µes, deixando o jogo mais "b√°sico" (tipo pular e andar) ficaria bem mais legal e jog√°vel do que da forma que est√°.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106568077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1450499336}
review:
This is quite the unique platformer. Instead of simply jumping from any ordinary platform to the next, it takes some sort of pseudo-Sonic approach of fast paced, all-surfaces high-octane super-platforming.

Let me be frank: this game is hard. Sure, it does a good job of easing you into it, but this isn't just some casual romp. Be prepared to put all your effort into getting constant SS ranks if you want to explore all the game's content.

The visuals are pleasing and colorful, just a nice view for the eyes. The music is likewise calm and soothing techno, which is just as well to ease you from the rage that will transpire.

The game controls butter smooth, and has a lot of depth from a rather simple means of traversing the maps. I did have one complaint about the controls, namely the lack of complete controller support. Most basic buttons are there, except the menu button. I can't even count how many times I've had to restart, and I have to do it all from going to the keyboard to press escape. Is an extra respec option too much to ask for?
EDIT: Though there is no option to respec the escape menu in the controls, I found that the "instant restart" key in another menu is able to be bound to a controller button, which is quite swell.

Another complaint I have, though not with the game, is the lack of community attention. When exploring the nexus, it is entirely up to me to find the one bronze door that I still have a key for, and it still eludes me because no one has a nexus map uploaded.

All said, it's crazily addictive to the right people, namely: twitch-reflex, practice-based skill games that never stop the action.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029788155', 'num_games_owned': 1451, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1413665070}
review:
As a mouse heavy gamer (RTS, FPS, point n' click) I should not have picked this game up. For me it's really hard to understand and even harder to play considering the complete lack of finger coordination I have with the keyboard. If you're a heavy mouse gamer, I do not suggest picking this game up.

BUT if you're an inbetweener (MOBA) or a keyboard heavy gamer (twitch Platformer, Racing, MMORPG) you should probably pick this game up as I have heard from very many people that are keyboard or inbetween that it's a great game. If you're mouse heavy, I suggest spending your money on Reciever instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041463492', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1168, 'last_played': 1672461223}
review:
Dustforce is a well-constructed platformer that emphasizes precision in such a flowing manner that it's easy to feel like the technique required is more luck than skill. It isn't really a platformer for someone looking for a quick drive-by game, and while there are lots of technique intensive platformers this one definitely stands out. Going through the motions of the game and then watching replays of the top runs through each level makes it very easy for the player to feel very unskilled at the game. 

I think it's easy to have a love/hate relationship with the controls in the game. Be willing to change them to something more comfortable if you find their initial configuration unpleasant to work around. Try the game on a gamepad or arcade stick. They ARE responsive controls, but I know that I didn't feel like that immediately. Adapting to the idiosyncracies of a game makes it more intuitive and this game will most likely require some adaptation. The game physics and the controls will require precise timing and attention to detail to progress through it.

The game looks fairly nice, and the soundtrack is beautiful. There's lots of levels to run through, and an editor if you like playing around with the tools.

DO buy this game if you enjoy technical platformers with non-combat goals.

Dustforce DX changed the layout of the levels a bit, and added different tutorial levels to explain a few techniques a little better. They're much better at teaching some of the techniques, but don't think of them as a barrier to the rest of the game. Go out and try a few of the levels and just run around the Nexus to get a feel for the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964306170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1351926000}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998299023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1113, 'last_played': 1671822376}
review:
Worth every penny. 10/10

Game's core features:
Dusting/Sweeping
Different Playable Characters
Platforming
Parkour
Special Gague
Level Evaluation/Grading System (S, A, B, C, D)
Easy Controls
Semi-Open environment

Dusting/Sweeping: If you couldn't tell already the main idea behind this game is dusting levels with a tool that varies depending on what character you play as.

Different Playable Characters: There are four playable characters, each have different tools they use to clean up the dust with: A kitchen Broom, a Push Broom, Feather Dusters and a Vacuum, each of these somehow seem to complete the characters personality, even though [i]so far[/i] there hasn't been any dialogue. Each character has a different "Style" of moving about, not really sure how to describe it, but there is a slightly different feeling between each of the characters.

Platforming: Not much to say here, you jump from platform to platform, however i will say the platforming isn't very repetitive and just feels right.

Parkour: Not Minecraft-Style "parkour", we're talking runing up a wall to jump to the next wall, then jump off of that wall to reach a platform, dash to get speed jump and RUN ON THE CIELING of the next platform to procede to the next section of the level, it's incredible and you feel like a champ for pulling off these stunts.

Special Gague: As you progress through each level and clean up dust, a gague at the bottom of the screen will slowly start filling up, once this gague fills completely, you can use a special move. This move is incredibly useful and does not change depending on which character you are (in one way I am glad that that's how it works, however in another way I am slightly dissapointed...) when you activate your special move your character will flash across the screen cleaning up all the dust within a certain radius of the character. It looks very much like a scene from a typical fighting anime show, but it's funny cause it's just them cleaning up dust.

Level Evaluation System: You are graded on two criteria after completing a level: How much of the dust you clean up in a level (Completion), and how many times your combo meter gets set back to 0 (Finese). S is the highest grade you can reach and D is the lowest (at least I think, it's the lowest I've gotten...). Once completing a level you will be awarded points towards different keys whih will allow you to complete other levels in the game.

Easy Controls: At the begining of the game you are bombarded with lots of information that seems a bit overwhelming at first, however the levels in each area ease you into learning the controls and before you know it, it's like second nature to you and you're pulling off nice fluid parkour tricks.

Semi Open-Environment: Each actual level is actually not connected to another, however, you don't choose the level from the menu, instead you're navigating your character to the next doorway wich will take you to the level. It would be like the old Mega Man X games met Super Metroid. Even the game menu is navigated this way.

Other Features: Hand painted graphics and a really nice "chill out" styled soundtrack. Reminescent of an old Sega Genesis or SNES game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040623585', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1663389059}
review:
This is not a game for the light-hearted. I'm being serious - if you want to get a perfect on all of the stages, you are going to need to set aside a significant chunk of time to devote to this. The way your janitor controls also takes some getting used to, you have to stop yourself from pressing the jump button one more time when you get started, and the precise timing may be off-putting. However, the new tutorials in the DX update are vastly better than the old ones, and once everything clicks you realize how d*** brilliant everything is.

There are few things more exhilarating than flowing from platform to platform, effortlessly cleaning up all of the trash in your way. There are few things more satisfying than, after many restarts, nailing every jump and pressing every button at exactly the right time. There are few things more rewarding than racking up a 300+ combo and taking out all of the end-level enemies with the press of a button and seeing your janitor jump effortlessly around the screen, turning everything into a cloud of dust in slow motion, then falling to the ground with your newly-cleaned buddies, pumping your janitor's fist triumphantly. As said before, once everything clicks, you'll have a blast.

TL;DR: Once you get the hang of this, you will experience one of the best platformers ever to one of the best soundtracks ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013042553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1414318555}
review:
There is nothing bad to say about this game. Nothing.

The soundtrack is a unique, atmospheric montage of skillfully crafted musical sounds. The gameplay is flawless and exciting, and can be quite the challenge to those who think they've seen all the game has to offer! With an intricate overworld, gorgeous scenery, and riveting gameplay, this is a must-have game for anyone who enjoys platformers or video games in general.

There are hidden spots in every level where you can sit and enjoy the scenery for as long as you like, all while relaxing to the fabulous soundtrack. There are hidden secrets which add to the game's depth as you struggle to find at least one in every level of every one of the four worlds. For an indie game, it does everything right.

The controls are responsive and they will not miss an input unless you put in a dash while you're in the air (as that won't happen on any game anyways). Each level is better than the last, and there's a Tome of Levels for you to visit your favorites if you choose not to run through the overworld to get to it. Please play it with a controller, as keyboard takes getting used to.

All in all, this game is wonderful. For me personally not worth 10 bucks or whatever it goes for, but you can get it every few months in a bundle for a dollar with some other games, so there's always that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142418020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 10288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1812, 'last_played': 1639711584}
review: Fantastic. Dustforce is brilliant: the minimalist art style looks fucking beautiful, the soundtrack is perfect backing to the great visuals, and the challenge ramps up quite fast (I still haven't SS'd all regular levels.) You're awarded a rank from D to S for completion (how much dust you sweep up), and Finesse (doing it all without losing the combo). All 4 characters, in addition to looking cool and unique, also play quite differently (dustkid has three jumps compared to everyone else's two, and dustworth, the old green guy, has the largest reach on his attacks). If you're looking for an engaging, very atmospheric platformer, you can do no better. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197972909058', 'num_games_owned': 1547, 'num_reviews': 476, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1414329560}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047395514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1355, 'last_played': 1496167646}
review:
A pretty difficult precision platformer, where the goal is to get through the levels while cleaning all the dust and trying to not lose your combo. It's more exiting than it sounds, really.
What really makes dustforce stand out is how you, once you have achieved a certain level of competency, really get into the "flow". The smoothness of the gameplay and fun but hard technical sections make it stand out for me. And when i say "hard" then i mean it. The later levels get ludicrously hard, to the point where you can spent more than 7 hours trying to SS (perfect score) a level. But at the end it feels worth it. 
Dustforce offers a ton of replayability, if you like the gameplay and dont give up too easily, then you can spend a lot of time on it. I personally have around 22 hours at the time of writing this and havent even gotten to the mega difficult levels yet and i imagine it will take me another 7-8 hours to do so at least.
And after that there are still a ton of community made levels left to be explored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091385278', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2706, 'last_played': 1533015083}
review: This has to be my favorite platformer on steam at the moment. I've put in 35+ hours as of writing this review, and I'll put in plenty more trying to SS every level. The difficulty ramps up quite a bit as you make your way through each level, and the seemingly simple controls open up to some fantastic speed tech once you learn a few tricks. With a replay system that allows you to watch anyone's play through of a level, you'll want to go back and improve your time trying new techniques you see other players use. It can get quite competitive between you and people on your friends list as you try to one up each other. The music is absolutely glorious. The OST itself is a great buy, definitely have that on rotation in my playlist. The art style is simple and clean, the animations are smooth and the game looks and feels better and better the faster you go. If you enjoy difficult precision platformers, or love games with mechanics that allow you to go fast, this is a purchase you won't regret.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022698027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 5376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2308, 'last_played': 1525156981}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028954041', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1433253892}
review: Become the worlds #1 DustBuster for $10.00.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063942960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1481, 'last_played': 1674304102}
review:
Dustforce takes platformers tested by time, such as Megaman and refines the genre to it's maximal potential. Everything is spot on, you are in full control, precise and absolutely magnificent. It takes a while to get used to the gravity, controls and all these essential elements in the game, but even after you got the hang of the basics, there are many more things to master. From combat to [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nKDaU-1PS4Y]advanced techniques[/url], there is always room for improvement. 
Dustforce was made for speedrunning, you can clearly see it with the leaderboard and replays of playthroughs of every player's best runs. You can see the best players what exactly they did at every level and learn the routes and have the wonderful experience of speedrunning, where you play the same level for half an hour to get that 0.07 second advantage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996055627', 'num_games_owned': 1244, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1661225804}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996810354', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3914, 'last_played': 1589482690}
review:
Tough-as-nails platformer. But god damn if it doesn't feel incredible to flow up ceilings, walls, and over spiky spiky pits once you get good at it. It's pretty much got all the bells-and-whistles move mechanics, including wall and celing runs, double jumps, 4-way dashes, and screen-clearing special moves. The mechanics are tuned to the point where there are 4 characters that ostensibly are amost identical, but those with a trained game-feel can tell they are worlds apart.

Plus the music is incredible. It will get you laid at parties.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076207962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 18266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1988, 'last_played': 1692813807}
review:
Dustforce is perhaps the best platformer of its kind that I've ever played. It's slick, beautiful, and most importantly the movement feels perfect.

The gameplay is what you expect it to be - you progress from level to level, attempting to complete it as fast as possible (with global leaderboards on time). Additional depth is added by the inclusion of your broom, used to sweep 'dust' as you run and hit 'enemies' with, building up a combo which you are rated on along with the time. Although initially the game may seem laggy or unresponsive, within a few hours you become accustomed to how the momentum and motion works in the game and begin to understand that the opposite actually holds. The game gives you perfect control, and punishes the tiniest of your mistakes.

That's really where the beauty lies. The skill ceiling is incredibly high, obvious to see if you watch a speedrun of this game. The game encourages you towards this perfection, and indeed the only achievement in this game is one of completing it - a feat few people (myself not included) have achieved. There's no RNG in the game, it's just you and how you play. This is certainly not for everyone, but for those few who don't like grinding and obtaining perfect muscle memory, the game hits all the right buttons

It is also worth mentioning the soundtrack. Some games have terrible music. Some games have good music for the game. Some have soundtracks that are amazing standalone, and this is one of them. It's (largely) calm, electronic stuff that's perfect for relaxing or concentrating too. Look it up on youtube - Fastfall by Lifeformed is the album.

For me, it's one of my favourite games ever, and I haven't even put that much time into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980100449', 'num_games_owned': 1130, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1478631937}
review:
A nice spin on... I don't even know what to compare it to.
If you combine Super Meat Boy, Mirror's Edge and N you might get something like Dustforce.
You try to run and jump your way through a large number of levels as fast as possible while, well, cleaning dust or to be more accurate, foliage.
The combination of wall jumping and multiple jumps by dusting of flying enemies gets you into a flow in which you will want to complete every level. But the difficulty rises fast and this game will make you retry a level many many times even if you somehow beat it, especially then.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074051494', 'num_games_owned': 1494, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6494, 'last_played': 1658063640}
review:
One of the finest examples of a precision platformer to date.

Tight controls, fluid movement, high skill ceiling, amazing level design, secrets, local multiplayer, a level editor, an unbelivably great soundtrack, and art style all make this title entirely unique to the 2D platformer genre.

As much as I have played and loved this, I will never get the single achievement...

Edit: After having played the content in the DX update, I would recommend this game even more. The new content moves every level into one mega Nexus to no longer require separate themed nexuses, adds 16 new core levels and a whopping 109 of the best community made maps, fixes the ranking bug in Wired, and includes yet another excellent new track by Lifeformed. As an avid Dustforce fan, I could not be happier with the update.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050681430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1404068311}
review: lots of fun, really gets you hooked on doing  100%

author: {'steamid': '76561197996288687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2236, 'last_played': 1451786539}
review:
Here's a little indie title that I absolutely LOVED to death. It's a free running, precision platformer (and mind you, I'm not the BIGGEST precision platformer) but I fell in love with the art direction of this game. The controls are tight and the levels are solidly routed to be as free flowing as possible depending on the character you choose (though some characters are better suited to specific levels than others fyi).

It's a simple game with simple goals and you can start and stop any time. I personally aced every level until I reached the bonus level whereupon I gave up because they required godlike reflexes that I simply do not possess but I had fun nonetheless. Give this a try if you have some cash and time to spare, even if it's only 5-10 minutes at a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989729246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3241, 'last_played': 1673700118}
review:
Thanks for creating this game, HitBox! Everything fits together, it is a true masterpiece. For beginners a challenge and for perfectionists an endless pursuit. The music is excellent, the graphics are tight and the animations fit perfectly. Character design is cool as well. The concept of sweeping dust is strange indeed but that gives it the originality to lift it from other games in its category. Level design subtly teaches you skills gradually.

It is a matter of taste if you like the concept of time attack. Speed running. Split second timing, and endless attempts at perfection. But it is very satisfying once you belong to the best 1% in a level - of course you'll never beat Thor and his homies, but his replays serve as a good reference and may inspire new techniques.

If you liked the dashing in Mega Man X on SNES and don't despise the thought on a game that revolves around the moveset in the named game - while expanding it in mobility, variety and speed - then this is a title you will most certainly enjoy. No guns - but whacking bears with a mop proves equally satisfying if well performed.

Every little detail seems to be intended - even if you find out something that appears like a bug (for example keeping high momentum by dashing after a long slide) you will soon find a level that solely revolves on the perfection of this technique. This makes the game difficult to like at first, since you have to invest some hours to get used to it and to realize the little moveset combos that exist intentionally but don't appear intended. You will have to scratch off the surface if you want to see it's true genuity. I predict, you will either play this game for 10 hrs and get bored due to it's difficulty, or forever if you realize and accept the challenge it poses.

I highly recommend this game either way, it is one of those games that i will never forget - and i have been playing videogames for some decades now. I know that many other people agree. It's quite cheap, for the thought, the design and the music that went into it. The level editor potentially increases gametime by many hourse  -  but in practice most people will have enough by the levels given by the creators. I myself have by far not cleared them all, but i just love beating the "noob" stages and perfecting my basic techniques. Beating my own records gradually on daily basis and belonging to the fastest 1% is actually a quite low set goal, but a good way to improve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015322748', 'num_games_owned': 732, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1610814255}

author: {'steamid': '76561198075556410', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1407719305}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969515473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3863, 'last_played': 1595398086}
review:
Dustforce is a videogame.

In it, you go very fast, sweep up the dust, you're a janitor man, lady, girl, old man, start at the start, end when the level says it's over, sweep the dust and wack the dust monsters as you go

The dust leads the way, so that your instincts are all you need; make the jump, do the slide: the power is in your hands

The music sooths and checkpoints about. There is no need for a game over screen when the point is graceful iteration. there will be frustrating hiccups, but the game is earnest: it wants you to succeed, and it does its best to get out of the way 

Levels teach you the skills you need to advance, with the grace and subtlety of a janitorial mr miyagi, and you say why have i been sweeping all this time, when am i going to learn karate? you knew it all along. but you're supposed to sweep anyway, you're a janitor. please be serious.

the elevator pitch: sonic the hedgehog, if sonic was actually a good game and had good levels, with an emphasis on speed, grace, fluidity, and perfection

it is one of a few games i've ever bothered getting 100%. this one's worth every penny. god bless

author: {'steamid': '76561197964410359', 'num_games_owned': 5229, 'num_reviews': 273, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1427284325}
review:
Un jeu de plateforme "you die you rage" √† la super meat boy, pics partout, glissades sur les murs et graphismes color√©s. Le jeu s'annonce directement comme un truc ultra difficile r√©serv√© aux fans de la rage. 
Du coup, pas de sc√©nario du tout (dommage, perso j'aime bien qu'il y aie un fil conducteur quand m√™me), des leaderboards et 4 zones de 12 niveaux. 
Les 4*12 niveaux se r√©partissent en fait en 4*3*4 niveaux, chaque zone ayant 4 portes standard, 4 portes argent√©es et 4 portes dor√©es qui repr√©sentent les niveaux de difficult√©. (moyen / dur / super dur, grossi√®rement) 
De base, uniquement les portes standards sont ouvertes, faire un perfect sur une porte standard vous donne une cl√© argent√©e, et faire un perfect argent√© vous donne une cl√© dor√©e. Faire un perfect dor√© vous donne une cl√© rouge qui ne sert que si on a toutes les cl√©s rouges du jeu (= si on a perfect tous les niveaux de base, moins de 0.3% des joueurs ont r√©ussi √† faire ceci) et qui permet d'acc√©der √† la s√©rie de niveau "ultra difficulty" ( :lol: ) pour les gros tar√©s. 
Du coup, point noir encore, si on est pas d√©j√† un bon gros tar√© impossible de jouer √† tout le jeu, puisque pour explorer ne serait-ce que tous les niveaux de base il faudra perfect tous les niveaux de base + tous les niveaux avanc√©s ce qui n'est d√©j√† pas rien (disclaimer: je me suis arr√™t√© l√† perso parce que je voulais juste finir tous les niveaux de base, j'ai donc SS tous les standards + avanc√©s ce qui m'a permis d'ouvrir tous les niveaux dor√©s et de les terminer (sans faire de perfect sur tous non plus parce que je suis pas autant maso...) 
Niveau jouabilit√©, il y a une grosse courbe d'apprentissage parce que les physiques sont vraiment tr√®s particuli√®res, et les commandes r√©pondent certes mieux que dans 95% des jeux de ce type, mais ne sont pas parfaites, et quand les niveaux exigent que vous soyez parfait, c'est un peu frustrant. Une fois qu'on maitrise le jeu on peut faire des trucs vraiment tr√®s sympas ceci dit. 
Vous l'aurez donc compris, si vous n'avez jamais r√©ussi √† avancer bien loin dans un jeu comme super meat boy et que mourir vous √©nerve, passez votre chemin, mais les fans de ce style avides de challenge qui sont pr√™ts √† passer 7 heures d'affil√©e sur un niveau de 2 minutes pour le perfect adoreront.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045149740', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 451, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1424592976}
review:
Who knew vaccuming would be so hard

[u]What I liked:[/u]
[list]
    [*]Challening Platforming ( I mean to get a decent rating)
    [*]Great Soundtrack

author: {'steamid': '76561198127823135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1406911458}
review: This game has everything I love in a platformer: fast pace, fluid controls, and a pointless-yet-addicting objective to complete. It took the good folk at CAPCOM to fully reallize every man, woman, and child's dream of being one of four of the fastest dusters in known history. The mechanics and ideas are not only simple to latch onto, but each area you set your mind to cleaning is gorgeous. You can ignore the fact that there are doors requiring keys. You can ignore the muffled cries made by small furry animals and scientists covered in leafy debris. All that matters is that if you wall-jump perfectly for about four minutes, you can find a small alcove with a telescope. Then when your friends boast about having the 30th fastest time on a stage, you can smugly smirk and smartly say "So what? I can climb seven stories to find a bookcase in that time!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198083573119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1416777422}
review:
Free flowing and clever, I liked the game from the start. 
Like most puzzle platformers it gets frustrating, having to go through a trail and error style of gameplay to progress, but it's worth the occasional rage quit.
The game moves very fluidly with a design and theme that is very fun to play around in. 
An 8/10 game that's worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019694474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 94280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7221, 'last_played': 1645669278}
review:
I was just browsing one day and I found a video talking about Dustforce. It successfully caught my attention and I dove right in.

I sucked, I was awful and I couldn't figure out all the mechanics at first. But the game does everything in steps, It's harsh but indifferent. As I kept playing lightbulbs would turn on, routes I would never consider started showing up. 94 hours later I found myself having all the stages fully completed. I should be putting this game down but I still feel motivated to keep improving my times.

This is a product made with a lot of thought and love. If you want to be challenged by a game, this is the place to be. The community is really helpful and there's a lot to do with the custom maps being avaliable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131507031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 17861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9589, 'last_played': 1622088821}
review: This is one of the best indie games I have played. The game concept is so simple yet it is executed so well. The artwork and animation is amazing and fluid. It's one of those games that if you're really good at playing it looks so cool. Soundtrack is one of the best I heard of, I have a hard time getting these catchy tunes out of my head. Controls are nice and smooth as well; however, I recommend you get a gamepad, if you don't hate yourself (default controls on pc are pretty bad, but that can be changed). The only bad side really is the difficulty. I have beaten every level except Yotta Difficult(really game designers? I like a good challenge but jeez), and I have taken so much time. I'd be lying if I said I didn't rage when I almost got an SS rank on a hard level after 3 hours. So yes, there is a high-learning curve to this game, but you get exponentially better as you play more so don't let that discourage you. There is always a challenge in this game, which would appeal to any hardcore gamer. Still, this game deserves 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025483614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1230, 'last_played': 1661290263}
review: It's a charming blend between soothing and infuriating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992105833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1367737200}
review:
I really really wanted to like Dustforce. I wanted to recommend it to everyone. But it's very... bland.

Like, really bland. And hard. That's almost a feat in and of itself. Even "I Wanna Be the Guy" had some charm to it. How do you take a controller breaker kind of game and make it so flavorless?

Apparently some people are really good at the game. Maybe get a controller and try a demo and if it clicks buy it. Everyone else should probably stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025484216', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1660813261}
review:
A game for competitive, experienced players, Dust Force combines the fast-paced action you'll get from a fighting game and combines it with a cinematic parkour experience that's perfect for speed-runners. With four characters to choose from, you'll be slowly migrating between these characters and learning how they work. Your first gold level you've unlocked will seem like a walk in the park once you're in the later stages. There's a ton of levels, a slew of hidden mechanics, easter eggs in seemingly all stages, a local multiplayer mode for up to four players, a fantastic level editor, and an experienced community filled with tons of downloadable maps.

All in all, if you like fast-paced platformers involving wall-running, timers, an unforgettable soundtrack, and hidden mechanics, this is your game. Thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054713049', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2199, 'last_played': 1413605340}
review:
If you have a completionist personality and get addicted to things because of it, you will most certainly get your money's worth out of this game. There's no guarantee you'll enjoy it all, but at least you'll get your money's worth.
Dustforce combines speedrunning and combat to create an intense "race against the clock" battle in each level. The basis is to clean up as much of the level as you can in order to advance on to the next levels, each one being more difficult than the last.
This game prides itself in its level design, and therefore also in its aesthetics. Its levels, characters, enemies, and even movements are visually pleasing, which helps when you play the game for hours on end in order to beat it. The sound design is similar, having a bit of the "fresh" element to it in order to keep you from getting sick of playing. Secrets are also scattered around levels, awaiting the player's arrival to reveal themselves--and then unfortunately yield no product. All of this wrapped in a thoroughly-vetted world makes for an overall good game, worth the buy.

However, if you're not a completionist, I would approach this purchase with caution. As I said before, because this is an extensive game with many, many levels, you'll get your money's worth, but only if you're able to play them. You can only advance on to the more difficult levels in this game if you beat the previous level well enough, and eventually this stops your progress entirely until you return to fully complete the previous levels (which can be extremely difficult later on). Most importantly, if you're not enjoying it, then you'll more than likely quit and never return. So, again, think well before buying it if you don't want to be completionist and then waste your money.

(Also, there is a multiplayer function to this game, but I don't have friends who own the game so I can't say whether that's worth a try or not. Given the game's speed-combat combination, I imagine it would be fun but can't say for certain!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198046595340', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1534711562}
review:
As an acrobatic janitor, sweep away grime from dust drenched dwellings and soot soaked forests in the accommodation of an equally as sweeping soundtrack - perhaps the most tranquil one you've ever heard. Dustforce's unique, minimalist visuals perfectly convey the beauty of the game's uniquely arrayed horizons, from which you will enjoy purging filth. Hope your fingers are dexterous enough to tame dust bunnies in record time.

It's a rare case where you will actually have FUN climbing the scoreboards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057715882', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1457251688}
review: This game may just not be for me. I picked it up in an old Humble Bundle, thinking I would like it. I did, at some points, and also the soundtrack is prime. However, there is a very serious learning curve. Honestly, this game pissed me off more than Demons and Dark Souls combined. There, I was given feedback on what I should try and do differently, and the rules stayed the same throughout the game. Here, however, sometimes when you land on a block you need to clean, you can stand on it, other times you rip right through it and die. I dunno. I might contine trying it, I don't really see myself seriously enjoying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005109607', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2049, 'last_played': 1597351383}
review:

Porta il giocatore ad assumere gradualmente un livello di padronanza del gioco che sembrerebbe impossibile di primo acch√¨to; il layout di alcuni livelli √® davvero diabolico, ma solo finch√© non avrete imparato come muoversi nello stesso. La grafica √® stupenda in movimento!

E la colonna sonora! Merita una menzione a parte, tanto √® bella!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032566672', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2153, 'last_played': 1420306713}
review:
I would give Dustforce a 10/10, for being an excellent, addictive, and challenging but rewarding platformer.

Dustforce is a platforming game where your goal is to navigate rooms in different levels of a mansion in order to clean them, for you are the worlds most awesome custodian. Don't be turned off by that description, for each of the 4 characters you can choose from has special abilities that make them able to clean in no way seen before. You are more like a ninja than a cleaner, and you can dart through levels creating combos as you clean dust and fight off enemies to clear the level. You earn points for how well you do, which eventually unlocks keys to more rooms, etc.

In order to unlock every level though, you must eventually complete each level by cleaning every speck of dust without breaking your combo. The combo window is long enough to allow you to use differing forms of strategy, but just short enough to induce high levels of muscle tension when you are trying to keep it going over long distances. This can easily be the biggest turn off of the game, and the level of perfection required to fully beat the game is astounding when you reach the veteran levels. Some may find that frustrating and too much of a roadblock, which is understandable. On the other hand (I have never beaten all the levels, and never will) Dustforce has enough content to provide a fun playthrough to suit the difficulty level you wish to attain. More of a casual player? You have plenty of levels that are loads of fun to play. Looking for a challenge after getting the basics? Dustforce provides a good set of intermediate levels, all the way up to insanely hard.

The controls feel great, the characters move fluidly, and no 2 levels are the same. Each character can provide a different strategy, and some are much more usefel than others on specific levels. The game provides the opportunity to watch the playthroughs of any player who has completed a level, meaning that you can learn some good strategies from some very good players.

Especially for only a few bucks, Dustforce is a great game that shouldn't be missed if you like platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004565666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 295, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1410045997}
review:
As a general rule, if a game can really make me feel like a ninja, it is automatically good in my book. Great level design and controls make this game hit that mark; you'll be doing all kinds of fancy acrobatics easily. Thanks to the fact that a good score requires you to keep up a combo you'll also be doing it in one continuous string for the whole level, but almost never feeling like you're in a time crunch if you plan your route right.

Other good points include: Great atmosphere, lots of secrets in both the levels and the hub (in fact you have to find most of the harder levels by exploring the hub), four different but balanced characters (all of whom can still beat every level), and the harder levels often make you think to solve them and can be quite difficult.

Play it after that if you're a hopeless masochist.

review:
Lovely visuals, excellent soundtrack, and tight controls. These together with online leaderboards, the ability to watch other people's runs (along with your own), and the level editor make the game challenging and fun and give it longevity. Dustforce is pretty much everything you could hope for from a platformer focused on speedrunning and score attacks.

If I had to name a downside, it would be the lack of online multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042751331', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1442972901}
review:
This is a 2D platformer that has you cleaning the "dirt" from the floors, walls and ceilings of the platforms. You are graded on completeness and finesse and getting high grades can earn you keys to unlock harder levels. And there are four different characters with minor variations in ability that you can play as.

I played thru each level that I could with each character once or twice, But I don't really feel compelled to do any more. The graphics and music are good, But there are either some control issues or I'm just not any good at it. But, Whatever.

Edit - Closer to a thumbs up than a thumbs down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041932478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1684, 'last_played': 1622093203}
review:
This game is good. I'm not an enthusiast of the platformer genre, but I've enjoyed this game immensely. Within 24 hours of buying it, I'd already spent half of that time playing it. The levels are challenging, and you'll fail a lot, but that's part of the fun. The soundtrack keeps you relaxed all the way through, and it's an amazing listen even without the game. The devs hit the art style right on the mark, with the minimalist designs working with the gameplay to add some clarity to the scenes which are very nice to look at.

Buy it. This game is underrated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034017515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1132, 'last_played': 1625270942}
review:
Looking for a relaxing game that can be difficult at the same time? Want a soundtrack that is on par with the Bastion/Transistor soundtrack? Want the most well designed levels you've ever seen?  Get this game right now.  Why are you still reading this review?

Anyway the game is rock solid.  It has great physics, amazing level design, solid controls, and the best damn soundtrack i've heard(tied with bastion and trasistor).  Difficulty can range from easy to balls hard, but the kind of difficult that is fair.  If you failed, it's your fault, not poor level design or RNG.  

Please just buy the damn game.  You will never regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042084942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1417736829}
review:
Dustforce is a lovely game for those that enjoy speedy platformers with an emphasis on control over one's character.  The janitors in Dustforce can jump off walls, run up walls, run up ceilings, and perform multiple double jumps by defeating enemies.  Gameplay consists of mastering the route through a level to sweep up all the dust while continuing one's combo (which can be done by running over dust or hitting enemies) and avoiding spikes, pits, and enemy attacks.  The game employs a ranking system that judges based on completion (how much dust was ran over and how many enemies were defeated) and finesse (how few hits and restarts taken).  This game is perfect for those who go for perfect ranks in modern Sonic titles.

However, later levels in the game approach unfair difficulty, spamming spikes and requiring jumps and dashes to be timed down to the millisecond to succeed.  Thankfully, it is not necessary to play any of these levels, and the game can be obtained at a price cheap enough to warrant playing only the well-designed levels in the first half of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999797567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1455589666}
review:
One of the most compelling and challenging speedrunners that I've ever played, Dustforce is not a platformer for the casual player. Even though you think you won't go back and try to perfect every level, the game will call out to your inner OCD, not just in the gamer's sense, but also the cleaner's sense.

In fact, this is probably not the hypochondriac's kind of game. Unless, of course, you're into that sort of thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051636071', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1457310723}
review:
This is an absolute gem! If you are the type that loves a challenge and enjoys platforming, this is a must-try game. This game is deceptively simple as there are a few sets of moves and mechanics that govern its world. But, as each level goes on, you start to use them in ways that did not seem apparent to keep your momentum.

Some of the great features this game has are the quick-reset. Guys, you are likely to mess up, fail, over and over and OVER again with this. So have a quick-button reset is a great feature, especially for speed runner enthusiasts. This game is built to be played to ways, 1) complete the whole level with 100% finesse at the fastest time possible, or 2) reach the end of the level as quick as you can. Either way, there is something satisfying to both aims, and much more gratification once you see your name inch higher into the ranking boards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081043975', 'num_games_owned': 633, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1596419480}
review:
Dustforce is the most satisifiying platformer I have played in years, and heres why:

Story: NA/10
There is none.

Gameplay: 9.8/10
The gameplay is a mix of mirrors edge and janitorial duties, allowing your character to leap off the walls and traverse the enviroment in fluid, dynamic movement. It's nothing short of simply breathtaking, and looks just as good to watch as it is to play, but only slightly. Everything has this great sense of weight and momentum to it- your air dash is small, but builds momentum insanely quickly, sending you into top speed in a flash, running up walls is quick and sticky, meaning getting around on walls, ceilings and ramps is a breeze. The combat, while simple, serves as an excellent momentum booster. Smack an enemy in the air, and your air-dash or double jump becomes replenished, increasing your jump distance and allowing you to pull off some crazy crap. It's utterly fantastic.

Graphics: 8/10
They're simple, stylish and beautiful. The leaves, slime, dust and trash all liven up the levels, and even suggest where to go next. They add a lot of charm.

Music: 8.2/10
Great to listen to in and out of Dustforce, and is relaxing enough to not make you frustrated.

Overall: 8.6

author: {'steamid': '76561198025726121', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 31078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26245, 'last_played': 1693109863}
review:
I have a shit-load of hours in this game, so there may or may not be a hint of bias here.

I fucking love Dustforce. 

Probably the biggest challenge, aside from the hardest levels in this game, is getting the hang of the controls. It takes a special amount of dedication to truly master the techniques and proper methods to control your character. I played the game for a pretty decent amount of time (10 or more hours?) and I kind of stopped playing at a certain point. It wasn't until I came back into the game that I found a control scheme that actually worked for me, and went on to complete most of the levels in their entirety. Fast forward to the time I wrote this review and I have over 400 hours put into the game. Oops.

So you're probably wondering "Bbop, how the hell did you manage to get 400+ hours into this game and never truly 100% beat the game?" Well, to tell the truth, most of my hours spent on this game doesn't even come from playing the main levels.

atlas.dustforce.com gives you a massive archive of user-created levels. I've also spent a LOT of time creating my own levels! I would recommend checking my stuff out whenever you get the chance. ;)

Dustforce might just have some of the best level-editing tools a platformer could ever give you. I know this because I've spent about as much time making Dustforce maps as I have playing them.

Also time-attacking both custom and vanilla maps is addicting as hell, since every map in the game AND every map that gets published on the Atlas has their own leaderboard. The best part about the leaderboards is that they save replays of each run so you get so see how the game's most dedicated players got such amazing times.

So yeah, is it the best platformer ever? I would say no - I honestly have no idea - but it is surely the most addicting one I've ever played. Atlas gives Dustforce a near-infinite amount of replayability, whether you like designing levels or playing and reviewing them... or both. o_o

Wow I can't believe I wrote a review this long. Most of my reccomendations are shitty jokes, but there you go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034984659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1444064262}
review: A most enjoyable platformer that's equally pleasing in aesthetics, gameplay, and music. The (customizable) controls are limited in number so as not to be overwhelming, yet despite this the character actions, including inventive combos, are fun and enjoyable to watch. I absolutely LOVE the overall design/style of the game -- simple shapes, visually engaging worlds, and cool graphics -- and the soundtrack alone is worth the price tag (seriously, I'd be content with just listening to the soundtrack for hours; music can be a make-or-break deal for me in a game, and this one certainly delivers). My only complaint is that it's a *bit* difficult sometimes getting on ledges because of how the up button/control works in conjuction with jump, but that's a minor, more personal, issue. If anything, it makes the game more challenging, which is welcome in itself. For just $10.00, this thing is freakin' awesome. If you love platformers, fun and engaging environments, and awesome music, your money will not go to waste on Dustforce.

review:
Extremely demanding platforms game but very enjoyable to play once mastered. 
This is not really a die and retry type of game as Meat Boy though, as you'll have to learn how the gameplay works rather than learn the levels by heart. The music is also shockingly awesome, and the game is long enough if you can survive the first painful hours of learning.
One of the best underrated indie gems out there.

review:
This game is not for everyone, but if you can dig it, you're gonna dig it really hard. Skill cap in this game is huge. But the amazing soundtrack, clear and beautiful art direction, and tight mechanics will help you along the way. Watch some videos of the gameplay if you want to know what kind of platformer this is.

As a side note, this is the only game by this game studio, so buying this is a huge way to support them with their future releases. I recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009835420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 38456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1706138591}
review:
Choisissez parmi 4 personnages aux contr√¥les diff√©rents et partez nettoyer une for√™t, une ville, un laboratoire et un vieux chateau. Les contr√¥les sont aussi r√©pondants que dans Super Meat Boy mais il vous faudra quelques heures pour en ma√Ætriser les bases. Les maps sont class√©s par difficult√©; les maps de bases, les silvers (il faut gagner une cl√© en argent pour les ouvrir), les golds (cl√© gold) et les rouges qui sont proches de l'impossible.

Le but est d'arriver au bout de chaque map mais plus votre nettoyage est propre, plus vos cl√©s gold et silver arriveront vite. Au final il faudra tout faire √† 100% pour d√©bloquer les maps rouges. Pour obtenir un score maximum il faut obtenir S en completion  et S en finesse. La completion est votre pourcentage de nettoyage (tout nettoyer donne un S). La finesse depend de si vous perdez votre combo (se faire taper par une entit√©, tomber ou ne rien nettoyer pendant quelques secondes). Pas perdre le combo donne le S.
Donc on peut dire que le vrai but est d'avoir SS sur toutes les maps.

Je trouve ce jeu tr√®s difficile mais une fois qu'on √† la main sur les contr√¥les on peut faire SS sur les maps de bases et les silvers apr√®s plusieurs essais. Faire SS sur les maps golds est beaucoup plus dur m√™me si certaines maps se font en 20 secondes. Je dois avoir 3 SS sur les gold.

La musique est fantastique, la fluidit√© sans pareil. Il y a un classement en ligne ce qui donne un peu de challenge pour les v√©t√©rans du jeu (on voit le joueur Thor dans tout les top 10, il doit faire que √ßa)

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025843884', 'num_games_owned': 859, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1484693895}
review:
This platformer is pretty great, once you get the hang of it. 

The game controls just fine on keyboard, though I personally found I had a better experience with a controller. 

Dustforce's difficulty has got some pretty sharp spikes, people who don't like to put time into games will get easily frustrated. You'll die to spikes. Alot. But, once you get the hang of things pulling off a good run feels great. 

There's honestly not a whole lot of content in the game, but if you enjoy getting good at levels and bettering your time, you'll like this game.
