review: One of the most difficult and yet satisfying games I've played in a long while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042786997', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 4796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1472, 'last_played': 1607706864}
review:
Had I written this review a week after buying Dustforce, the text box would have been filled only with the words [b] TOO SODDING HARD [/b] in bold type. Now, after about 20 hours of playtime I can safely say that this game is really worth the effort.

Dustforce is a single-player speedy platformer clean-‚Äòem-up with resemblance to games such as Super Meat Boy. The aim of each level is to dash around cleaning the objective dirt off the various walls, floors and enemies in the fastest time possible, and by "enemies" I use the word very loosely. When you come across one of these dusty creatures you simply smack them a few times with your broom until they are thoroughly clean. The woodland animals then drop to the floor unharmed, which I find easier to live with than the Tomb Raider style destruction of wild animals; this way they‚Äôre just getting squeaky clean.

At the end of each level you are presented with two ranks: one for completion and one for finesse. The aim is to get the highest rank in both areas by cleaning up all the scum in the level without breaking streak. When you do so, you get a key to a harder level. One of my favourite aspects of Dustforce is the menus, which are like independent levels where the goal is to find the actual levels of the game. All the game mechanics and physics are present here, so if you can‚Äôt access a level it‚Äôs either because you don‚Äôt have a key to it or you just suck. Another great part of the game is the replays that get uploaded at the end of each level and the scoreboard that is also shown, as it lets you know who‚Äôs the fastest duster in town. For most of the levels it‚Äôs a guy named Thor claiming #1, and by clicking next to his name you can watch Thor diving through the level.

It‚Äôs a game I have 20 hours in and still believe I‚Äôve only scraped the surface. If you do get round to playing this masterpiece beware of spikes, stone faces and the fact that you‚Äôre not Thor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995532620', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 9553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1436, 'last_played': 1644180210}
review:
Honestly, this is one of the most awesome platformers I've ever played.
It's also the most difficult platformer I've ever played.

Visuals are amazing, soundtrack kicks ass, presentation is very slick. But the real reason this game shines is because of the platforming.

The way that you move about the environment is, for lack of a better term, beautiful. You can double-jump, dash around, slide down slopes, and run up walls and across ceilings. All of the levels test your ability to string together and combine these skills as you run through.

At first, just trying to complete some levels is a daunting task. Many of the harder stages require some pixel- or frame-perfect actions to maneuver through tight corridors full of spikes. I never became frustrated with dying in this game because I always felt like a death or a combo break was my fault and not the game's. But once I cleared a difficult stage with a double-S rating, it was an awesome feeling every time. Getting through a level on a perfect run looks and feels like an intricate dance, and it provides a level of satisfaction that surpasses any other platformer I've played.

All that said, I don't think I will ever beat this game. The late-game stages are just insanely brutal, and I'm not sure that I can spend the numerous hours needed to optimize my movement through just one of them to get a double-S. But I'm quite okay with that, and I'll definitely try anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048888462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1398533528}
review:
It's been a while since I've played a good parkour platformer beat-em-up, and I can say one thing for certain about this game...

It miserably.

It feels like a game meant to be played on a controller, but when you play on a controller, it feels awful and clunky, and every move you make makes you put finess into every strike. It's very tiring on the thumbs.

And the keyboard controls are even worse! Even more clunky than a controller! A CONTROLLER!

It feels like you're swiping at cotton candy.

And worst of all, YOU CAN'T TAKE DAMAGE! THERE IS NO LIFE BAR!

There is absolutely no challange to this game!

The game is a grind fest. No way of sugar coating it.

I want to like this game but there's no way in hell I will.

Sloppy, unresponsive, uncontrollable, and just needs to clean up its act.                  3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197999812009', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1595281625}
review:
You know that a game is good when you have fun even before entering the levels. It doesn't explain much aside from basic mechanics, and then forces you to become good by creating the perfect learning curve, where for you to proceed to the next level, you actually have to master your moves so that you can even reach the level gate.
While it suffers from a low selection of main levels, you can easily go to the game page and access user-created levels in just a few seconds.

tl;dr: this game is pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031849748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1412305426}
review:
Awesome game!! I've only been playing this game for a little while now, but I must say this is one heck of a game! DustForce is perfect as a wind-down game with lovely graphics and pleasant music. The way everything flows is nice and peaceful. I do have only some things I do not like, for one thing when I face a certain direction and you hit attack you seen to be facing the opposite direction you were facing, makes it tough for fighting and hitting attacks in the air. Another one is a similar problem when I jump up to a ledge and hold the up button as it says, I still end up in the wrong direction jumping off the ledge instead of grabbing.

But that's the only problems I've had. This is worth every penny!

review:

¬øPor qu√© no cambiar la din√°mica de un videojuego? La estructura tipo/s bueno/s vs. tipo/s malo/s no tiene que ser la bandera de todo t√≠tulo que se precie. Aqu√≠ es donde un juego va a resultar (o no) novedoso, sorprendente. Y √∫ltimamente, salvo honrosas excepciones, este es un lujo que solo se ‚Äúmarcan‚Äù los juegos descargables. En este caso, el estudio Hitbox Team es el encargado de sorprendernos con un t√≠tulo en el que vamos a dejar cada escenario barrido de suciedad. Literalmente.



                No creo que ninguno de los presentes desee legar un mundo sucio a las pr√≥ximas generaciones. No, no es un manifiesto pro-medio ambiente. En Dustforce protagonizamos una aventura de plataformas y acci√≥n en la que debemos librar cada rinc√≥n del escenario de polvo y hojas secas. Disponemos de cuatro h√©roes a elegir, diferenciados por el color de sus ropas y su aspecto. Dos, chico y chica, usan escoba. Otra jovencita empu√±a plumeros que podr√≠an ser la envidia de Kratos, y el restante lleva una potente aspiradora. Todos ellos se mueven como aut√©nticos personajes de acci√≥n, saltando, planeando para golpear en el aire, se suben por las paredes, dan volteretas, pueden corre por el techo‚Ä¶

                Antes de nada, decir que gr√°ficamente estamos ante un trabajo muy bueno y positivo de cara a suplir la ausencia de un apartado t√©cnico a√∫n m√°s potente. Todo est√° envuelto de una atm√≥sfera agradable y encantadora, fr√≠a por los colores pero llena de matices, y con muchos detalles, como el vuelo de las hojas por nuestros impactos. El movimiento de los personajes es muy estilo ‚Äúcartoon‚Äù, pero todo funciona con mucha fluidez incluso con un PC de gama intermedia. Y esto, para un t√≠tulo descargable, se agradece.



                Hay varios modos de juego en Dustforce. El modo individual es un ‚Äúdesfile‚Äù de fases en las que vamos haciendo limpieza sistem√°tica de todo el entorno (recordemos que estamos ante un juego bidimensional, por lo que todo lo que exploremos va en sentido lateral, no en profundidad). Da igual si es simple polvo, hojas o incluso personajes que parecen haberse zambullido en residuos, que se comportan de forma especial. Nos toca devolverlos a la normalidad a golpe de herramienta de limpieza. La agilidad con los botones (tampoco son m√°s de tres, sin contar las teclas de direcci√≥n) es esencial. Los dobles saltos, los rebotes, la escalada o el sujetarnos al techo temporalmente son nuestras herramientas para llegar a todos los puntos. Esto nos permite ir ganando combos, de cara a mejorar nuestras habilidades llegado a un punto, y esto a su vez facilita las cosas para dejarlo todo como los chorros. Si somos totalmente limpios, desbloquearemos niveles, y esto se agradece enormemente para hacer del juego una experiencia m√°s duradera.



                Pero esto es como la realidad, y esto lo sabe todo el que no viva solo, sea con la familia o comparta vivienda con otra gente: es mejor si limpian varios. Lejos de querer hacer menci√≥n a las divertidas trifulcas de las viviendas de estudiantes (t√∫ no has limpiado, esto te tocaba a ti, me has llenado de porquer√≠as el suelo de‚Ä¶) en Dustforce podemos disfrutar de un simp√°tico multijugador, de uso Local, eso s√≠. En √©l, caracterizado por la velocidad del desarrollo, habr√° dos bandos, y pueden participar hasta 4 jugadores. Unos limpian, otros ensucian, y este enfrentamiento puede llegar a violentarse en muchos sentidos, pues debemos elegir si atacar golpeando, limpiar detr√°s del enemigo‚Ä¶ y √©ste podr√° seguirnos deshaciendo nuestro trabajo.

CONCLUSIONES

Que tengamos entre manos un juego de barrer no convierte a Dustforce en algo que pasar por alto. Lejos de los simuladores de cosas de la vida cotidiana que se han hecho tan famosos en las consolas gracias a sagas que hacen uso de pantallas t√°ctiles y c√°maras, Dustforce es un encantador juego de plataformas y acci√≥n en el que la habilidad lo es todo. Este modo de juego ‚Äúde la vieja escuela‚Äù se adapta a todos los jugadores, y nos har√° querer seguir adelante y exprimir cada nivel. ¬øAlguien tiene ganas de quitar el polvo?

author: {'steamid': '76561198000215501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1292, 'last_played': 1661144889}
review:
Dustforce is an amazing platformer.  It feels, looks, and sounds extremely smooth and pleasent.  It's a score chase of sorts, where you can race for the best time, but I feel like I'm always trying to get the smoothest run possible, not the fastest time.  It's incredible in that you can fail over and over again and yet not feel frustrated.  And when you finally succed, you are rewarded by feeling completely amazing about a run you just made that never had any mistakes and looked super grateful.

Of all the platformers I've played, I like Dustforce the most.  The music is absolutely perfect, the gameplay is extremely solid and consistent, and graphics are beautiful.  It also has multiplayer and a level editor!    

The replayability is great too, because sometimes you just want to go back to old maps and perform them smoother than you could before.  I would rate Dustforce a 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012878379', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1669708709}
review:
Dustforce, a game that has stuck with me through the past two year that I still enjoy taking on the challenge of some of the harder levels in effort of getting my time down as low as possible with the most mesmerizing, ambient soundtrack that I instantly fell in love with.

Anyone who loves action platforms where speed-running them is fun, yet difficult then this is a game I encourage you too purchase as quickly as you can.

I have a version for the PSVita and the PC and I love playing it on both systems

author: {'steamid': '76561198012449438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 902, 'last_played': 1450711536}
review:
challenging platformer with emphasis on ingeniously engineered movement mechanics to master. 

taking the role of a janitor (lol) you clean up basements, parks, appartments, and other dirty facilities. the game is already hard if you attempt to beat all the levels, but becomes a beast when you try to prefect-speed-run them. the visuals and music contribute to create a great gaming experience. a definite recommendation to those who love "super meat boy", "they bleed pixels" or the "mega man X" series.

took some time until i found this gem!! you normally got a double jump and a dash, while air dash is also possible. in addition, you have kind of a drop dash at your disposal which can only be performed at the apex of a jump, but also after you double jumped. you may cling to walls and ceilings and move along them for a fixed distance, however, you cannot jump-climb walls since the do not "load" the double jump. you gain enormous speed if you use your environment, like drop-dashing (you can mash it) on a slope, which is essential for speed runs. it's tricky tricky :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198076603646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1412821989}
review:
This is a game that does so many things right, but yet so many things feel wrong too :/ 
First, there is this funky air physics where you stay suspended for some time, then drop like a brick, timing is really hard with this kind of twisted movement. Also, the character goes in directions you never wanted it to when wall or ceiling-riding...
So yeah the game handles not so great, but a game like this should handle like a freaking formula 1, especially as the levels in this game are freaking 24hours Le Mans long and you must not do any error while playing one session or else you won't unlock levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034389199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1453594464}
review: The sheer difficulty of this game is so ridiculous that words cannot express how frustrated I am with it. It's an interesting concept, but the horrible checkpoints along with the insanely sensitive timing and precision required to complete the more advanced levels caused me to put away the game permanently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020588718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1394063403}
review:
Kind of mixed tbh. If you love hard games or have stupidly reflexive fingers, then you'll love this. If you're drawn to this game but don't, well you'll like the first few levels of each world, but anything further will become a dying spree of repeating difficult manouvers. A game really for a select audience that's good, but went too far to not appeal to all. Would have been nicer to see it focus on unique level mechanic flowing as a game (like how rayman origins does) rather than a competetive difficult speedrunner game. Even just making it to a level gate can be agonizing = /. Characters are inventive with fun designs, but there's nothing inventive about the level design variety to put you in shock-and-awe. Sparse and a little bland.

More of a humble indy game to collect, rather than to buy straight out of steam, but that's just my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986920132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 19126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11928, 'last_played': 1500127096}
review:
No reviews for Dustforce? Surely this is a bug...

Dustforce is, and most likely will be, my favorite indie game of all time. I've never really even been into speedrunning platformers, but I absolutely loved this game.

The visuals. They're so simple, and are perfect for this game. It has a lovely look that never gets tiring to look at.

The flow/feel. Dustforce just feels great to play. Whether it's on keyboard or controller, this game has a flow that feels like you're riding through a musical masterpiece.

The soundtrack. Naturally, achieving flawless runs is what you aim for in this game, and naturally, it can get frustrating as the difficulty increases. Thanfully lifeformed (the artist) has created the absolutely perfect soundtrack for this game. The calming tunes are insanely catchy, as well as soothing to the soul as you unfortunately realize you missed a piece of dust 20% through that track you've never SS'd.

The devs. They just seem like awesome people who love making games. They've released their financial information on Dustforce after all it has been through (steam, humble bundle etc), which is a rare thing to do. They also created a level editor and website for people to share! They are currently developing a new game called Spire, which will be an instant purchase for me =]

tl;dr - If you have the tiniest spark of interest after seeing some screenshots or gameplay, buy it and play. You will not be dissapointed; only pleasently surprised.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053292326', 'num_games_owned': 1134, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2633, 'last_played': 1422181804}
review:
there‚Äôs a softness, an altogether pureness, in dustforce. it is a starkly wholesome game beyond its surface. the magnitude of how pure is even idealistic and immovable. it‚Äôs something that is hard to find in a video game that seeks new horizons. relations, though. the most amazing part about dustforce is the result of its softness. even if you lack the ability to play it - and nearly everyone does - it holds wide appeal. the art and music match the gameplay to a refined elegance. it‚Äôs a pacifist game and a performance game without being tailored to either, because it‚Äôs still clearly a platformer with all of the philosophy behind it. in motion, it‚Äôs wickedly cool and aesthetically moving. skill and display meet innocence and whimsy.

dustforce is ludicrously difficult. it belongs to an elite faction of games I‚Äôd describe as harder than hard. the way it‚Äôs presented, that fact lays dormant. though loss is common in dustforce, there is no mean-spirit. nothing is out for your blood and none of the platforming is dishonest. what you need to do is nearly always set clearly ahead and it‚Äôs all up to your fingers. consequently, and not in a bad meaning, the stages end up feeling more like race tracks than levels. mind you, very stylized race tracks, or race track stages, but very laid-out and bare compared to genre tradition. this feel is accented, arguably engineered, by dustforce‚Äôs mode of progression. it doesn‚Äôt matter if you only get to the end of a stage in dustforce. you will, it‚Äôs always fun to clear a stage, it just won‚Äôt let you fully continue.

dustforce‚Äôs inspiration and idiosyncrasy is speed running. platformers have always been a speed running favorite. converting art into performance and display, manifesting game and human potential. speed runs are incredible, but there‚Äôs an equally incredible entry barrier. the time expenditure needed to participate means that few will experience the overwhelming play. dustforce acts as a bridge. its ranking system enforces perfection. it does not simply weigh down your time a ranking. clear time is not relevant. to unlock levels, you need SS. to get SS, you need a perfect combo with full completion. dustforce‚Äôs ranking deals with links. dust you collect on the stage builds up links. hitting dust covered enemies continues links. they are lost when you are hit, go out of bounds, or have about a five second pause since your last link. there cannot be mistakes. speed runs contain no mistakes. though complete perfection is not required, dustforce is unforgiving to even the smallest mistake. finishing a long level from beginning to end, allowed only stylistic mistakes, puts dustforce above a precision platformer to a speed run simulator.

dustforce isn‚Äôt the first platformer to demand perfection. I personally love contra for its sheer display and skill or die gameplay. dustforce‚Äôs pacifist aura and dedication to a track indeed separate it from any other perfection platformer, but what is most important is dustforce‚Äôs fluidity and sense of speed. though in plain movement it is slower than a mario game, a speed run never stops and dustforce doesn‚Äôt want you to stop. borrowing two key elements from other very fluid series - mega man X‚Äôs dash and modern sonic‚Äôs magnetlike fast-fall - and adding their own radical innovations with air dashing, wall runs, and jump refreshes, dustforce has constant varied movement. the combinations and radical changes in input keep you more than engaged, with the coolness of each character‚Äôs movement drilling in your performance. the rhythm, intensity, and constant movement translate to feeling unstoppable speed. dustforce‚Äôs core is an incredible renovation of tried mechanics with unbelievable vision in its additions. it has its idyllic goal of speed running and it refused accepted conditions. it contributes altogether on its own making both its direction and its core individual and fantastic.

dustforce has a special presentation with a unique goal and altogether new gameplay, so I would be skeptic to ask: how are the levels? by my language, well, this is pretty easy to anticipate. dustforce‚Äôs levels are masterful. they allow for all kinds of different and often new naturalizations, realizations, and combinations of their gameplay. the tracks have clear and differing focuses, requiring techniques, hopefully building your repertoire while it remixes its challenges, playing on your expectations. there are huge clearings to cross, towers to climb, ceilings and floors to repel, narrow spiked corridors to squeeze through, enemies to chain your airtime, small platforms to caustically land on, expansive hills to slide through, beautiful spirals to loop around. dustforce isn‚Äôt just a very personal and unique idea, it‚Äôs a masterpiece of level design. I have qualms for the lack of linear pacing, there isn‚Äôt a way to know how difficult a level is going to be, but that‚Äôs a very small criticism, and the game still builds from easy stages to hard stages, it‚Äôs just done in blocks.

plain to say, combat is not dustforce‚Äôs strong suit, and it feels relatively forced. so it is with an absolute lack of understanding that there are four small and constrained levels dedicated to fighting masses of around twenty enemies. to compensate for keyboard controls, for better and worse, dustforce ques moves. when platforming, it gives the game a sort of rhythmic and planned feel based on anticipation and expectation. in the heat of combat, it is awkward. you‚Äôll find yourself locked into quick strikes and unable to dodge obvious enemy attacks, which is frustrating and unrewarding.

another actually affecting flaw is how much singular input influences the character. slight adjustments are impossible. this again compensates for the difficulty to make smalls presses on a keyboard, however it removes from dustforce‚Äôs most important aspect: its fluidity. an obvious expression of this is a single block-wide hole with ground on either side of it. pressing right or left will walk over the hole and onto the terrain on the other side. there is no possible way to enter the hole from the ground, you must jump and make the adjustment. yet even if there is slightly more control in the air, it still involves much too large movements, and makes landing on small blocks or falling down in a specific direction imprecise and very much out of your own control, which is somewhat of a deathblow. the hideout is an infamous stage that brings this flaw to light but also serves as a great way to learn how to make the flaw work for you. the keyboard-tailored control is impossible to ignore, and while it is a noble effort, it sadly stains a perfect formula.

dustforce is performance art. the fluidity feels like a dance. the speed feels like superimposed mastery. unlike a rhythm game, there is pure and awesome actualized design depth existing in-addition to the performance. unlike a perfection platformer, dustforce is rarely stressful, instead being meditative, being conductive, being pointed, being beautiful. it doesn‚Äôt demand perfection, it encourages it. as dustforce opens up, grows and evolves, so do you as the player. it shows that difficulty can be symbiotic to achieve fully wholesome results. dustforce isn‚Äôt do or die. it‚Äôs be or don‚Äôt be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999447553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 87472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49744, 'last_played': 1606847083}
review:
Disclaimer: This game is hard as balls!
But if you look past the difficulty you'll find a life consuming challenge, an amazing soundtrack and endless amounts of content provided by the level editor (over 1000 custom levels atm). 
The learning curve is massive which may not be appealing to some people but that's the thing keeps me playing after 800+ hours. I'm pretty sure that I'm capable but haven't gotten what's called SS score on the last level so I'm technically not even done yet.
The level design is amazing and blends perfectly with the soundtrack. And the best part of the game: the leaderboards. Every level (including custom maps) have a leaderboard for the best SS time (cleared everything in the level) and the fastest time just to finish. And every run has intant replay so you can see how the best player does or how the worst player doesn't :P
Many may compare Dustforce to Super Meat Boy but I would disagree mostly because of the controls but also because of the fact that dustforce has some brawler elements. At first glance you may feel that dustforce has floaty controls where meat boy feels more slick but dustforce's "floaty" controls imo Allows for more precise maneuvering. A thing to mention on controls is that I recommend using a keyboard or a controller with a good D-pad (instantly ruling out 360 controller) like PS3 or 4. You could use analog sticks... but you're gonna have a bad time if you do that.
So my honest opinion: The best platformer ever made. A very hard but fair challenge. The best comunity in a game I've encountered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076721797', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 774, 'playtime_forever': 7630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4771, 'last_played': 1691995983}
review:
I could start and end my review with "buy this game" but I like elaborating even if that would be sufficient.

Do you want fast-paced platforming with a focus on flowing smoothly and learning what your character is capable of?
Do you want a game that makes itself as difficult as you want it to be without ever being frustrating?
Do you want a game that makes simply "beating" it feel rewarding, without any unfair artificial difficulty to speak of?
Do you want a game that has near infinite replayability due to a massive selection of custom levels?
Do you want to have fun?
Yes, I think you do.
Dustforce is for you.

review:
There are a few easy levels. Then it gets hard. Then it gets impossible. Then there are the levels you never even see.

Sometimes I'll play the levels I'm stuck on over and over just listening to the music. It's a very relaxing game with beautiful music-- if you don't get too uptight about having to restart things over and over.

For some reason my time played has been cleared. This has been one of my favorite games. Don't play this without a controller!

review:
This is the hardest platformer I have ever played.  Its controls are fluid, its difficulty is fair, but I now understand why only about two dozen people in the world have completed the game.  Most of the levels will apear easy at first, but getting a perfect score on even the simpliest levels will take a lot of dedication,

This game is awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042432992', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1246, 'last_played': 1595294645}
review:
This is an excellent buy at a good price. The platforming in this game is very good, the controls are responsive. The game can get difficult, but for the most part it's fair, because it's skill-based gameplay. The aesthetic is very good, but you can judge that from screenshots and trailers. The music however, is, in my opinion, great enough to justify the price of admission on it's own.
The aesthetic, tight controls, fair difficulty, levels, and the music all tie into one sublime experience. I would reccomend this to anyone who likes precision platformers like Super Meat Boy, and probably platformers in general.

review: One of the most fluid and beautiful looking (and sounding) platformers i've played in years. The intense feeling of flow you get when you run through a course and everything clicks is really amazing. Not for the faint of heart, of course, but for those of us who've always loved platformers, i would say it is a must :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197962634032', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1487926614}
review:
Dustforce is the kind of platform game that requires determination, as you will have to play most of the levels several times before getting a rewarding Double S score, wondering which character would be the best for this level.
There is no real time trial mode for the scoring system (the time you take only impacts the world ranking system): as long you don't break your Combo and clean the whole level, you will get your Double S score and be able to unlock new levels faster (that get quickly harder).

And the soundtrack sets the mood, helping you to relax even though the new level you're trying to finish is hard as hell.

Also, like most of this kind of platformer, you "should" really using a controller.

review: Das Spiel ist wundersch√∂n gestaltet, die Animationen sind weich und extrem h√ºbsch anzuschauen. Die Charaktere spielen sich sehr verschieden und zeigen kleine witzige Eigenheiten. So saugt sich der Hausmeister mit dem Staubsauger an der Decke und oder Wand fest. Das Spiel ist insgesamt sehr rund im Spielfluss und als durchaus Herausfordernd zu bezeichnen. Leicht ist anders aber das ist gut so! An manch einem Level sitzt man schnell mehrere male um doch noch etwas besser zu sein und in der Rangliste am ende des Levels weiter oben zu stehen. Unbegrenze Empfehlung von mir. Das Spiel wird mich noch einige Stunden kosten. Alleine schon wegen des Soundtracks der wunderbar stimmig ist!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998039540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1671219409}
review: A fantastic stylish platformer with incredible controls, music, and art style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085679336', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1419911786}
review:
This game is a fantastic precision platformer. The main basis of the game is finding your way through the various levels with parkour style platforming. You play as four janitors whose objective is to clean all the waste (leaves, sludge, etc.) and defeat all the creatures infected by the waste in each level. There is one achievement in this game: double-S ranking all the levels. In order to do that, you need to clean all the waste and never lose your combo. This game will give you many hours of joy and frustration. My two complaints for this game are (1) it's not very easy for people new to platformers to get into and (2) the controls by default are mapped very awkwardly. Luckily the controls are rebindable. You should really pick up this game. Dustforce gets an 8/10.
-The Pixelated Gamer

author: {'steamid': '76561198116921918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1484583257}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986685988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2754, 'last_played': 1642736403}
review:
Great game, at first it may seem simple or easy, but the harder levels will make you want to tear your hair out trying to get that SS score. Great feature is that you can watch the runs of other players if you want to find an efficient way to beat a difficult part.

Once you get a hang of the controlls, (I reccomend a game pad), the game is amazing and the sountrack and visuals are very chill, which helps because as I said it can get frustrating to make it through an entire level only to hit that spike right before the last piece of dust. 

If you like a challenge and have fast fingers than this game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024348300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1467003625}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024993029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2156, 'last_played': 1688482936}
review:
In Dustforce speedruns aren't the meta-game, they ARE the game. If you can enjoy the precision and timing involved in such endeavors you won't be disappointed. If you enjoy watching other players' speedruns you won't be disappointed (and in a sense, this is your reward for at least finishing a level).

I think Dustforce stands out in the design more than actual gameplay (you can get a similar challenge from e.g., Super Meat Boy). The game is distilled in the art design, character design, and level design. That's not to say it's sparse, the levels are often beautiful, but there is very little that doesn't directly serve the game. There's very little narrative. There's not a lot of moving parts and gimmicks. It's simply: here's an obstacle course, find the shortest course and execute perfectly (with a few exceptions for arena stages; here's a room full of enemies, flawlessly defeat them).

The soundtrack to the game is excellent, and one of my all time favorites. Definitely check out the composer's web page.

This is a game for all ages and abilities. I often play this with my 2.5 year-old son. He likes to watch the colorful characters run around cleaning and making the animals and people happy. In the hubs he will just make the people sweep and jump around and narrate the action. He likes the music, too. Older kids will be able to finish a lot of the levels and have fun doing it. Parents might be interested to know there's next to no violence in single player, since the sweeping "attacks" are really cleaning off the inhabitants of the stages and they are largely greatful for it. 

The biggest drawback to me, is that progression is entirely linked to perfecting skills. Most of you will eventually reach a plateau where you've unlocked every level you can and you're stuck trying endlessly to improve your times and combos on the hardest levels. There's no "grind" to "brute force" your way forward, you either get good or accept defeat. Judging from the global achievement (there's only one) stats, around 90% of players will not unlock the highest levels. Less than 1% have perfected every level. You can't see everything even as just a tourist.

I'm disappointed there isn't a wider set of achievements to build some meta-game around.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998392648', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3992, 'last_played': 1616703189}
review: Probably one of the most well designed games I've ever played. The game guides you along in a way that teaches you the game without any intrusive tutorials telling you exactly what you do. As you progress through the game, you can actually feel yourself getting better and better at this game. Not to mention it's amazingly addictive. You always want to get that SS, you'll play that one level for hours trying to perfect it. Do not be fooled though, this game is not for the weak of heart. It is very difficult. But if you have enough determination, you'll find one of the best games to be released in recent years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016689085', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1668693590}

review: It's a skill/performance game in the same vein as Trials, but focused more on fighting-game level animation control and timing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965940511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1434520381}
review: Alright, while I personally found this game hard as crap, its quality, polish, and gameplay are solid and smooth as butter. It seems like one of those trial-and-error, play-til-perfection games ala Super Meat Boy that I just would get frustrated and don't have the patience for. Great soundtrack and visuals though! Just not my kind of game. It feels weird to go around recommending games that 'might be good if I enjoyed the genre' or 'its good, but its not for me.' I -can- recommend it though, for people who -like- that sort of thing; the controls are there, the mechanics, the competition and community. So in the end, I can at least recommend it for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038148027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3934, 'last_played': 1681560723}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970870886', 'num_games_owned': 917, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1430874329}
review:
Dustforce is a relentlessly unforgiving platformer, even moreso than Super Meat Boy. In most platformers, there are usually a few different ways to approach problems. In Dustforce, however, you are forced into a single kind of "perfect run" to progress normally through the game. You can complete stages without these perfect runs, but by doing so, you lock yourself out of so many stages. Perfection is demanded of you in this game.

I'm the kind of person that really enjoys a challenge, but the level of timing, reaction, knowledge, and control demanded of the player is so insane that I made it about 75% of the game before finally stopping to retain my sanity. When you can pull off what it demanded, it is an amazing feeling. But sometimes the game feels incredibly inconsistent, and I know that's only because the timing on everything in this game is on a hair-trigger. 

I find it really hard to recommend this game except to anyone who is masochistic about challenging games. I did actually really enjoy it myself (I am one of those people), but I also know this is not the kind of game that almost anyone else would be able to enjoy the way I was able to.

3 out of 5 foxes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963577190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1449299890}
review: Addicting as hell. I never thought sweeping floors would take this much finesse. Replayability is high because of leaderboards and there a lot of variety to the levels so they never get boring. Oh and did I mention secret areas and unlockable characters? 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197966844573', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 12982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4073, 'last_played': 1454048409}
review:
The best janitorial emulation I've ever played.

Jokes aside, what originally attracted to me to Dustforce was a feeling that something was missing from Super Meat Boy, something that the game didn't seem to quite capture or address. It was difficult, but in a way that let me put it down and step away from it, knowing I could always come back at a later date and defeat it. The music was good, but I don't know that I could hum a tune from it right now. The level design was well thought out, but often times only allowed for one method of play.

Dustforce takes every one of these (admittedly small) complaints and addresses them: the technical skills required to beat some of the levels that ensure you can't set it down and come back to it without having to remaster things, the decision to design the game from the get-go with speed-running in mind, and a soundtrack that is as catchy as it is lovely...the list goes on and on.

Without gushing on for too long about it, I recommend Dustforce as highly as I can recommend anything, provided that you know what you want in a platformer. This game will be hard and it will be unforgiving, assuming you attempt to play it at the highest level. The level design will keep pulling you back in, making you wonder if you could have shaved off a second or two by doing this loop slightly differently. The technical skill required will make you consider purchasing a keyboard that actually works (Apple keyboards are now my chief complaint with Apple computers). In short, if mountains were video games, Everest almost compares to Dustforce.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995555431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1552, 'last_played': 1594798873}
review: One of the most enthralling platformers Ive played in a while. Its got a bit of a learning curve but once you get there it offers a zen like experience. On the other end, it has some incredibly punishing levels that I have yet been unable to finish but thats what keeps you coming back, its nice to have a mix of difficulty and fun like that. The art direction is fantastic, each area and level has a unique and cohesive deisgn that just feels right, not to mention the beautiful layered backrounds. But if that wasnt enough, the soundtrack is mezmerizing, I absolutely love it. Definitely a good buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010171906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1439892799}
review: A slick platformer with a really cool art style that plays like a rhythm game. Rare in that it's a difficult game that is neither cheap nor obsessive. S-ranking a level looks as cool as it feels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059261733', 'num_games_owned': 443, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 999, 'last_played': 1449652827}
review:
For its length and number of different worlds and characters available, Dustforce offers almost no variety at all. Worlds are only thematic variations, repeating the same kind of level structure over and over with no unique mechanics between them, while the characters themselves all play pretty much the same, with some minor tweaks from one character to another (with some of the more subtle changes not even being hinted in-game).

If that wasn't enough, the game demands "perfect" double-S scores for players to be able to make standard progress. Scores that in any other game would exist only as a side challenge to those who truly want to spend their times mastering it. Here, you'll have to clear every single stage flawlessly if you ever hope to see those final levels, and there are MANY stages to be mastered ‚Äî enough to make one feel like the game overstayed its welcome after only a few hours.

Bottom line is: Dustforce gets old. Fast. It offers almost no variety in its gameplay and the absurd requirement to progress through stages is a cheap way of stepping up the difficulty, which only helps to add to the incessant repetition the player will experience. I cleared one world + a bunch of other stages and saw no point in continuing. It offers no reason to go on beyond getting a good performance on stages, so you can move on to more stages and repeat the process in the exact same way, everytime. I felt like I had already seen all the game had to offer, and that more arrangements of the same stage elements weren't really worth stressing over.

It's a shame, really. Dustforce has tight controls and a unique core theme and aesthetics (though it keeps the same kind of mild/serene atmosphere all the way through. I got bored of it after a while). If it just presented new mechanics for each world and/or character and reduced the overly-demanding difficulty a tad (a double-A ranking requirement to get keys for further stages would be a huge improvement) this review could have been a "Yes" instead. The way it is, though, I'd only recommend this game to the most time-attack obsessed players with plenty of time to burn and that wouldn't care much for a more varied and rich experience.

For everyone else looking for an interesting platforming experience, you're better off looking elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996473015', 'num_games_owned': 784, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1380942430}
review:
Dustforce is one of my favourite  platformers ever. The animations are really smooth with a lovely style, the music is soothing and the later levels are incredibly hard and requires close to perfect precision and timing. If it wasn't for the quality of the art and music I would have quite of frustation quite early, it's really enjoyable to play despite frustation and once you get the hang of it you're able to pull of really awesome moves.

The game also saves ghosts for every players best run which are automatically uploaded and really easy to access. It's helps a lot when you aren't able to figure out how to do a close to perfect run in some of the harder levels.

My only gripe with dustforce is the limited controller support. I'm generally using a xbox360 controller and it required some fidgeting to get it to work as I liked. It's a wonderfull game and you should definitely get it if you're into hardcore platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052694133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2409, 'last_played': 1637642571}
review:
No Frills, just good solid platforming. Precise timing and perfect execution are required to progress to the difficult levels.  If you want a casual platforming game look elsewhere, because this is for the people who want to punish themselves with retry after retry to get that "perfect" run.  It's frustrating at times, but just making it through one of the later levels feels like an accomplishment in itself.  First runs through levels are like platforming puzzles, and it's really fun to see the creative skills you learn to get through the more difficult sections.  

There is something else here though, and I can't recommend this game without mentioning it.  This game has such a great flow to it that, along with the sweet soundtrack, put me in such a mood that hours in this game, even if those hours are re-dos all on one level, are super enjoyable.  Hitting all the dust on a run without slowing reminds me very much of hitting a platinum on trials evolution.  

TL;DR If you enjoyed the difficulty of the hard levels of Super Meat Boy and/or Trials Evolution, then I would recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996969560', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1350975600}
review:
Dusforce is a 2D indie platform game developed by Hitbox Team. The game is short, simple, and tells the story of four custodial protagonists who attempt to sweep away a world corrupted by dust and filth. The game was released on Steam in January of 2012 and will be pushed to the Playstation 3, Playstation Vita, and Xbox 360 consoles in January of 2014. 

The game consists of roughly 50 levels in which the player has to use a number of acrobatic skills in order to clean up small sections of leaves and defeat filth-covered creatures to score and progress though the level. Some of the skills that the player will have to master to complete each level in an efficient manner are the double jump, wall jump, mid-air dash, and the ability to cling to the walls and ceiling. The player also has the choice of a light or heavy attack with which to defeat the enemies in the levels. The levels themselves are laid out very well and tend to vary from horizontal to vertical design, which pushes the player to master the controls of Dustforce (a game best played with a controller, if possible). The game tracks your progress through each level with the combo meter, which is influence by the player's ability to move through the level and eliminate both enemies and leaf piles in an efficient manner. At the end of each level, the player is "ranked" by their abilities to achieve a high combo and how quickly they moved through the stage. The game also comes with a four-player multiplayer system with some typical variants such as Survivor and King of the Hill, along with a level editor that was introduced via patch after the games initial release. 

While it's certainly an interesting way to promote level completion, the biggest problem with Dustforce's ranking system is that in order to access many levels of the game, the player is required to complete each previous level in a near-perfect manner. I found myself running through previous levels over and over just so I could access the next one. This certainly speaks volumes about Dustforce's ambitious gameplay, but also says a lot about how the game is put together. Forcing a player to run through previous levels 10-15 times will often make it feel as if the developers are simply padding out their game. It's a fantastic experience, but it would be a lot better if it were only longer and if it were easier to progress through the game. Also, the acrobatic abilities are hard to master, and it will take a lot of time with a controller in hand in order for an average player to perfect the play style that Dustforce presents. 

However, there are many things about Dustforce that makes it an indie game that you should experience for yourself. The game has a unique art style that is gorgeous to look at, especially when a player is whizzing through a level at top speed. The colors blend together in a fantastic way that makes the game visually stunning. Also, the techno soundtrack was created by lifeformed, and it is nothing short of amazing. The music is stunning, and is some of the best I've ever heard in an indie game. Since it's release, Dustforce has been compared to other indie games, such as Super Meat Boy and N+, and while it shares a similiar style, Dustforce is a game that stands alone. It's innovations seperate it from other games like it, and it's penchant towards speedrunning implies that the developers knew exactly what market Dustforce would do best in. 

Unfortunately, while Dustforce is a fantastic game, it is one that is more difficult than it's predecessors, and to the players that have never experienced fast-paced platforming gameplay, I would have to recommend that they play Super Meat Boy or N+ before this one. Those games are simpler, and typically will be a more casual experience than the one Dustforce provides. That being said, if you have experienced either of those games and hunger for more, then Dustforce is the game for you. Dustforce will impress and, hopefully, amaze you. 

A 5 out of 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198036618001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1495077942}
review:
Dustforce is a game about 4 heroic cleaners out to clean up some sort of sentient filth.  Leaves, dust and slime all coat the floors, walls and ceilings of each level and it‚Äôs your job to sweep, dust or vacuum it all away.  To do so requires precise, difficult control and levels are designed to be completed with finesse.  The game shines in its difficulty which drives the player to finish each level as quickly and elegantly as possible, striving for an elusive SS Rank.

Dustforce is not a game without some fault, however.  The controller support is limited, requiring some menu fidgeting to get it to work and the d-input controls override the keyboard inputs.  The game also doesn‚Äôt do a great job of guiding the player or setting a level curve, despite the door and key mechanic for some of the harder levels.  But really, those are minor gripes.

Despite its minor flaws, I‚Äôve really been enjoying this game.  The beautiful visuals and vibrant music have quite a grip on me.  The animation uses a lot of fluid animation smears and the the music presents a feeling of adventure without being over the top.  It‚Äôs very relaxing, which can be very important when dealing with a particularly difficult run.

One of the better mechanics also lies in the replay mechanic.  When looking at the leaderboard, simply click on any of the camera icons (including the one by your own run) to view a replay of that run in its entirety.  This is a cool way to see how your friends compare, how you can improve your own run and what the top players are doing to get such good runs.

In the end, this game is fantastic, and somewhat reminiscent of something like N+ or perhaps even Super Meat Boy.  If you‚Äôre into that sort of tough platforming, Dustforce is worth your time and money.  And buy the soundtrack edition; it‚Äôll save you a step later.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995351715', 'num_games_owned': 431, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 14396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10366, 'last_played': 1689285340}

A "Precision Platformer" that has an Incredible soundtrack and built in leaderboards, making for a game that can become very addictive.

It is easily the best Platformer I have ever played. I heartily recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053694857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1361692800}
review: If you're up to an 'Old School ' challenge platformer filled with charm and mystique then Dustforce is for you. Best enjoyed with a controller (I used a PS3 one). Visuals are urban-whimsical and music is captivating. Probably one of the best soundtracks I have heard in a long while. Really gets you into the game, whether you suck at it or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993426443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1389056552}
review:
Dustforce is an interesting little side-scrolling platformer where you play as one of four (approximately equal) characters to literally clean up various levels. To me, this game is a lot like Sonic the Hedgehog with smaller levels and more specific goals. All you really need to do is get to the end of the level and clean the 'boss'. However, to progress you need to meet certain goals: % of the level cleaned and point value, which you get by maintaining a combo for as long as possible.

The graphics are interesting but nothing terribly special- I think it could be best described as artistically minimal. The audio is there, but neither good nor bad. The story... well, a game like this doesn't really need much of a story.

Mechanically the game is pretty solid. There are times when it feels like the controls aren't as tight as they could be, and the objective-based advancement means you find yourself doing many iterations of the same frustrating levels. The game does have controller support, but you'll have to do a lot of rigging to make it work right.

Its an interesting challenge game, but lacks a certain something. It doesn't make it bad, just... not something I play at for long periods. This indie title is still worth playing though, so consider picking it up if it happens to be on sale.

If you found this review useful, please have a look at [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/essidus/recommended/][u]my other reviews.[/url][/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198023054863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2167, 'last_played': 1417928286}

Can be rage inducing at times, but manages to keep me coming back trying to beat some of the harder levels. The only thing I think should be changed is the editor. Making it more user friendly would be very helpful for people who maybe arent as intelligent. I recommend this game as a fantastic time passer. 8/10

review: This game is incredibly relaxing. The soundtrack fits the mood perfectly, and makes for great listening. The graphics are nicely stylized, the animations smooth. Some levels are so difficult I doubt I'll ever beat all of them, but I have a blast trying, and there's plenty of fun to be had improving my best times. This is a game I think anyone can enjoy, and certainly one that everyone should try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104520506', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4789, 'last_played': 1438899067}
review:
Even though Dustforce can be unforgiving and brutal to newcomers, no other platformer musters such a stunning display of beauty and fluidity once mastered.

If you don't mind honing your skills and being patient about progression, this game will certainly fall right down your alley, recommended for people who happily welcomes a challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970703152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 33147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31758, 'last_played': 1640932107}
review: Awesome precision platformer.  Tight mechanics, deep move set, smooth flow, great music & visuals, clever level design, custom level editor, leaderboards, perfect for speedrunning.  It's safe and accessible for all ages, yet it's depth, difficulty, and mechanics make Dustforce worth buying over Super Meat Boy and other precision platforming "greats".  After 500+ hours this game is still fresh and fun, and I have barely touched the 2000+ user made levels.  With this kind of depth and replayability, Dustforce is easily worth the asking price!  TL,DR: Janitorial Simulator 2014

author: {'steamid': '76561198055351711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1439316673}
review: Parkour + Platforming = Great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965069079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1470870770}
review: Ninja Janitorial Services are a vastly under-represented demographic in vidcons, but Dustforce does a great job giving them the spotlight. Wallrun, slide, leap, and clean your way to victory in this speed runner's platform paradise. Highly recommended if you like games like Super Meat Boy or They Bleed Pixels. It is extremely difficult in some levels, but there is a built-in replay mode that lets you watch the best player completions of each level to help you figure out what the best methods are. It also lets you compare your times to your friends in-game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043986260', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 86104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 193, 'playtime_at_review': 2446, 'last_played': 1710826027}
review: An amazing platformer with hundreds of custom level available at the dustforce website. The physics are different from most other games. It can be difficult to keep your momentum, but once you get the hang of the movement in this game, it can provide fun for hours. The difficulty spikes rapidly, and a perfect run of each level is required to unlock all the next tier levels until the X-Difficult levels, which are a long ways harder than any other set of levels in the game. The level unlocking method is rather lackluster, but the game is amazing once you "get it" after getting it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024985000', 'num_games_owned': 1910, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1611123592}
review:
So incredibly polished, and perfectly styled.  Aesthetically, this game is a masterpiece.  Go for the [url=https://lifeformed.bandcamp.com/album/fastfall]soundtrack[/url] edition too, as the music in Dustforce is absolutely stellar.  Gameplay is very solid as well, although people without a lot of patience need not apply.  The platforming is hardcore, and the later levels are absolutely brutal.

Four characters to choose from, each with different strengths, lots of levels to agonize over, and a wonderful, wonderful sense of style.  One of my personal favourites.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990250956', 'num_games_owned': 734, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1223, 'last_played': 1460582437}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998429837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1431122220}
review: You play as a ninja janitor bent on saving the world from dust and grime! This game is super fun, but horribly rage-inducing. There were times where I wanted to throw my controller out the window and beat my computer with a dust-mop. This is only easy if you have the reflexes of a ninja and the patience of a janitor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993699129', 'num_games_owned': 468, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1400, 'last_played': 1695167778}
review: Best side-scroller i've ever played.  Wish it was around when I had my SNES.  Very fast paced and simple. Only 8 yr old asians can beat it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998457166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1506658869}
review:
Dust force is a very deep game that uses symbolism to send an important message to the american people. Us aryans can no longer sit and do nothing but clean up the messes left behind by all these disgusting ethnics. We must stand together and remind the world why the glorious aryan race still reigns supreme. 
I for one completely agree with this message. I am sick and tired of all these ethnics clouding my aryan superiority.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993363806', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1413339685}
review:
Dustforce is the Sonic the Hedgehog to Super Meat Boy's Super Mario. Has the best soundtrack on Steam.

Unlike Super Meat Boy, survival isn't really the issue most of the time; it's not an impossible task to get to the end of 3/4ths of the levels, and there are checkpoints. Perfection is the challenge. To unlock the final stages you must clean every surface without loosing your combo. It has a has a really good flow to it. Some of my favorite stages are wide open grassy courses which reward mastery with speed and huge jumps into the air. Other stages are huge floating spike mazes. Expect to see a lot of those in the last quarter of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987998513', 'num_games_owned': 1280, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 206914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 317, 'playtime_at_review': 118278, 'last_played': 1710855649}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986421649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1447387768}
review:
Platformer through and through, it's strength is it knows exactly what it is. Harkens classic platformers. There's no cutscenes. No real "plot". It's a game, and it never stops you from being able to jump right in from the get go. It's accessible, solid, and FUN.

The art is pleasant on the eyes, and the music is ambient, akin to Donkey Kong Country.  It even has a fun local Multiplayer that feels like Smash Brothers. This game is great, and ten bucks is a worthy price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999332287', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 13111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1701485119}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041153620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1415405091}
review:
Dustforce is a compelling combination of Sonic the Hedgehog and Gunstar Heroes with a dash of Super Meat Boy thrown in.  The core gameplay is tight and demanding, and nailing a perfect run is as satisfyingly rewarding as it is aesthetically pleasing.
Excellent art, animation, music, and mood: Dustforce is it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053750532', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1482476367}
review:
Possibly the hardest platformer you'll ever play. The concept is a bit weird, but you play as one of various cleaning men, sweeping dust off the floor and defeating monsters made out of garbage. Using the abilities to cling onto walls and double jump, Dustforce turns out to be an extremely fast-paced game that taxes your reflexes.

This game is an absolute nightmare for achievement collectors: it only has one achievement--and that's for completing the game with 100% success--a task that is absurdly difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003782017', 'num_games_owned': 1793, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1469265296}

review: I haven't played this game and know nothing about it.  I put it on my wishlist as a joke and a very awesome gamer bought it for me.   Yeah, I thought it was funny to put it on a wishlist, but guess I shouldn't have done that.  That's my review.  Hope it helps you decide!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024054864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1459120592}
review: Get ready to get out your thumb splints and biting stick, because Dustforce is here to kick your ass and test your patience. In the same vein as the hyper-difficult, rage-inducing classic, Super Meat Boy, Dustforce is another tough platformer. Aside from gameplay, and like Super Meat Boy, both the graphics and the soundtrack are beautiful. You dash, jump, sweep, and fight your way through various dirty areas, trying to sweep up every last bit of dust or dead leaves, while trying to do it as smoothly [and beautifully] as possible. This seems like it might be an easy task, but dashing through increasingly difficult levels while trying to get that perfect combo is much harder than it sounds. If you're easily frustrated, this is not a game I'd recommend to you [though I probably wouldn't recommend Super Meat boy to most, either]. But if you're the kind of person with the patience to hammer through the levels and get that perfect double S rating after a great deal of trial and error, then this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004539126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1241, 'last_played': 1531740568}
review: I have played nearly a days worth of this game within 3 days of buying it. Hmmm.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998785170', 'num_games_owned': 1759, 'num_reviews': 247, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1424609689}
review: If you finished Super Meat Boy and need some more insane but very tight and polished platforming, this is probably one of the best places to head. It's a bit more complex in terms of the moves and controls you have available to you and which you need to master, but it only takes a few levels before you start getting a pretty good feel for how everything links together and flows. Doing it perfectly and as quickly as possible is another matter entirely, but it feels good when you start being able to maintain your momentum properly. The presentation of the game isn't nearly as slick as the mechanics (e.g. it can be a little non-obvious what to do after the tutorial), but everything necessary is distinct, recognizable, and functional after a little time with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049008396', 'num_games_owned': 1476, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1498730782}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999397923', 'num_games_owned': 1373, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1371559725}
review: Not sure how this slipped by with such little fanfare. A challenging precision platformer which in my opinion gives Super Meat Boy a run for its money. Easy to play but hard to master, the levels often demand quite a deep understanding of the game mechanics to get through them with full marks for completion and finesse. Recommended for anyone who likes precision platforming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060103492', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1450908063}
review: This Side-Scrolling Platformer about people who clean the floors, ceilings, and walls has beautiful gameplay with elegent movement and flow.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993266952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1434007380}
review: A mix of Super Meat Boy-like platforming with the rampant cleaining motif of Mario Sunshine. Fantastic art style and fun levels once you get the hang of the controls. One gripe I have is the low chance of a painless recovery should you mess up in a level at all. Overall it's worth the price so long as you don't mind the difficulty curve. Also, if you value your sanity, DO NOT attempt the advanced levels unless you have complete and full confidence in your abilities. That goes for the community maps too, most of which are horrifyingly sadistic to say the least.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995629098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1062, 'last_played': 1644727572}
review:
A demanding but fair platformer in the way of Super Meat Boy, Dustforce similarly combines an even difficulty curve with a level design and soundtrack that encourage the player to fall into a rhythm.  Each level has dust covering various surfaces throughout, and your job is to find the best way to clean it up in as quick and graceful a fashion as you can manage.  Unlike other platformers, the level design made sure that the dust is always strategically placed to always have one straightforward, continuous path that the player can follow.  Finding that path, and then skillfully navigating it, is where this game truly shines as the soundtrack's calm background melodies helps you lose yourself in the rhythm of gracefully jumping from platform to platform. 

 Buy this game to enjoy a great soundtrack and a tight platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968235225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1660333991}

author: {'steamid': '76561197978590783', 'num_games_owned': 867, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1403931263}
review: The TrackMania of platformers. Extremely fast and satisfying once you get beyond its somewhat obtuse controls and physics. Dustforce feels like it was made for speedrunning; in fact, it has a small racing scene on SpeedRunsLive, if you're into that sort of thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026454771', 'num_games_owned': 1211, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1661359649}
review:
Un ottimo piattaforma molto al di sopra dello standard.
Una soundtrack talmente bella che mi ha lasciato col fiato sospeso.
Un gameplay che prevede un sistema di movimento intricato e ben studiato per il quale si acquisisce una certa skill.
L'editor √® molto intuitivo e di semplice utilizzo.
Storia quasi inesistente.

Lo consiglio a chi ama i giochi piattaforma e le soundtrack dei videogame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027909720', 'num_games_owned': 1242, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1513, 'last_played': 1572489824}
review: The apocalypse has finally dawned upon mankind. Men and women from all around the world gather around to see society's collapse. An alien beam has pulverized all means of transportation on rails, and civilization as we know it has crumbled. The morale of humans as a species is at an all time low, and apathy reigns over the shadow of the world that once was. Apathy such, that it is up to a group of four survivors to clean the world, and eliminate all evidence of trains ever existing, so that mankind may start anew.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037514836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1651407115}
review: An excellently artistic and stimulating platformer. This game is all about precision and dexterity. When mastered you will literally zip across the screen with elegance and confidence. Recommended for the hardcore platformers, and could possibly be enjoyed by more casual platformers thanks to its lovely presentation and wonderful soundtrack. The soundtrack is worth a listen regardless. This game came after my Super Meat Boy fix and was splendid.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971098754', 'num_games_owned': 1403, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 12378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6938, 'last_played': 1709394955}
review:
Simply put: this is one of the best platformers to EVER grace a gaming screen.
Put some effort in it, look at some runs made by others, try to understand its wonderful mechanics, and you'll be in for the platforming ride of your life.
A Masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960555577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1589782739}
review: Great game but difficult.  Requires Asian precision to even attempt any high score, but somehow some armo I know  posesses those highly evolved twitch reflexes developed by the roaming hermit made obese grape eater himself.  I would have loved to see more of it's atmosphere be used in some story sense or even a really long level which utilizes the elegance of the gameplay mechanics to make something artistic rather then just speedrunny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020010533', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 166119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 723, 'playtime_at_review': 17041, 'last_played': 1710827389}
review: Most amazing, challenging and gratifying platformer I've ever played. If you are a fan of precise, tightly controled, fast-paced platformers you OWE yourself to play this game. It's ridiculous how they were able to make this game so complex and yet so fluid at the same time. The difficulty curve ramps up really naturally, and though it may intimidate more casual players at first this game rewards your efforts like no other, as you run up walls and ceilings, fall, dash and jump, cleaning everything in your path, you look back at what you just did, and feel like a god of gaming. Truly a masterpiece.
